igdb.name: SOMA
igdb.summary:
SOMA is a sci-fi horror game from Frictional Games, creators of the groundbreaking Amnesia and Penumbra series. 
 
The radio is dead, food is running out, and the machines have started to think they are people. Underwater facility PATHOS-II has suffered an intolerable isolation and we’re going to have to make some tough decisions. What can be done? What makes sense? What is left to fight for? SOMA is a sci-fi horror game from Frictional Games, the creators of Amnesia: The Dark Descent. It is an unsettling story about identity, consciousness, and what it means to be human.
igdb.storyline:
The radio has gone silent on PATHOS-2. As isolation bears down on the staff of the remote research facility, strange things are happening. 
 
Machines are taking on human traits and alien constructions have started to interfere with routine. The world around them is turning into a nightmare. 
 
The only way out is to do something unimaginable.

pegi.synopsis:
The content of this game is suitable for persons aged 16 years and over only.
It contains: Realistic looking violence - Strong language

reviews.review:
-Horror elements are not satisfied as Outlast or Dead Space series. It;s basically a first-person steathy game.

-solving myth without map directions can be both interesting and annoying. People who enjoyed Prey or Bioshock 1&2 would totally love the background theme.

-The concepts of the plots are really materpiece of work, like "Blade Runner" standard.

A profound psychological horror experience with Frictional Games' usual fantastic pacing that you could make an example out of, paired with top-tier voice acting and a mature story set in a transhumanist dystopia, that will grip you from start to end and leave you wanting for more. A landmark of its genre.

What a game! This was actually better than I expected. I really loved the story and it got me thinking at some points.

Also all the monsters and all were creepy as hell, and the way they appeared at some points really got me some goosebumps. The overall atmosphere of the game is so dark and creepy, and I loved that. It's kinda like scifi-horror version of BioShock. Just by the fact that you're under the sea got me anxious lol. But anxious in a good way.

SOMA has pretty much like Amnesia style of gameplay. I don't know is it just me, but there were parts where you were kinda left on your own to think what you should do. Kind of like where you should go and what you should be doing. Because there are no objective markers or anything. You just kinda have to figure everything out by yourself.

In general, I really like this game and I would recommend this to anyone who is into scifi-horror and post-apocalyptic stuff.

Wow.  Easily one of the best games I've played in the last five years. A seriously unsettling and unforgettable work of art.

Highs: Scary, and not in cheap ways either.  This is some serious multidimensional scary we're talking about.  Abyssal darkness, claustrophobia, pursuits by all manner of deranged faceless nightmares, f***-with-your-head psychological assaults, body horror, crushing loneliness and despair...  And between that, moments so beautifully poignant and serene. 
 This is an incredibly well written game, finely tuned and edited for maximum enjoyment.  Great script as well, and graphics and sound are well above average, especially for a small-budget title.

Lows: Not many.  It's a relatively short game and linear, so replay value is limited?  The lead character's voice acting is so-so?  Hard to come up with more than that.

Play it.  OMG play this game.

The gameplay is good, if not quite so scary as Amnesia. No complaints.

But the real standout is the story. The heavily philosophical elements made me think of the [i]Blade Runner[/i] films, but with an important difference. In [i]Blade Runner[/i] you are asked: is this new being a human also? How much do you have to add to a machine to make it human? In [i]SOMA[/i] the additive becomes subtractive: how much can be taken away from a human and leave them still human?

Also the sound design is great.

This game should be a sci fi movie! The plot is so amazing, that for a veteran on horror games like me i can say this is one the best games of the genre!

Frictional, this time you hit the fucking jackpot! 

I think the only negative think i can add, is that eventually you will reach the end of the game. =(

SOMA is polished and terrifying, but in order to properly enjoy your playthrough, you need to be aware of these things.

1. This is a very depressing game. The philosophical implications in the story are grim, but probably not beyond your grasp prior to playing. The REAL feeling of despair comes from the presentation of a hopeless fate for humanity and frequent allusions to a future where you are truly alone in the world. If you get this game expecting the typical formula of growth through triumph that most horror films and games have adopted, you will probably end up bored and upset. If this is the case, you may want to stick to your Outlast and Resident Evil.

2. If you "die," head back to your last save. This is essential if you desire challenge in your games. My first playthrough, I went through the first several chapters without getting touched by the monsters. They are loud, perceptive, and they disrupt your UI when near. When I finally learned through experience that they only stun you then fuck off, it took away some of the fear for me. So in this case, you will benefit from hancicapping yourself.

3. The main character of this game is an idiot. Not just a bonehead or a bumpkin blissfully unaware of his stupidity. He asks the same dumb shit over and over and keeps acting shocked when his iPod girlfriend gives him an answer he doesn't like. If you have no experience with the autistic, you will hate the MC. Please be patient with him.

I’m 29yrs old. I’ve been playing games since I was 9. I am a veteran at all sorts of games. I want to make this review short but I want it to capture this game and its essence. I would highly recommend this game if you like a meaningful experience. This game had it all, a good story, excitement, and fear all wrapped up in one ball of a game. The graphics 8/10. The story 8/10. The experience 10/10. I played this game during the day because I become very skittish at night while playing this game. All in all, I will give this game 9/10 and an absolute buy. Have fun, this game is worth it.
i hope every copy of me would play this

I own more than 100 games on Steam and completed good chunk of it, but this is the first time I'm writing a review. I don't like horror games, never play them, but I completed SOMA and recommend you do the same.

Is it scary? It's tolerable. There are no jumpscares and atmosphere darkens very smoothly. Also, game literally gives you visual and audio clues when scary part is coming. I found horror part very well made.

Story is amazing, one of the best I've seen in games. It has great pace, it works well with exploration part, and it really gets to you.

Stop reading this, buy this game, it's amazing, even if you don't like horror games.

An incredibly creepy, mysterious and intriguing in terms of aesthetics and storytelling sci-fi horror about the terrifying aspects of living in a virtual reality, emulating our consciousness and defining what really makes us human. 
Must have for technophobes, supporters of [b] the simulation hypothesis [/b] and metaphysicians

What I expected: another corridor-jumpscare-hide-from-monsters-horror-game.
What I got: brain blown up by the depth of the story; crying like a little girl watching ending.
Don't get me wrong, I'm not trying to sound pretentious but the idea of the game impressed me so much that I figured out I'm no longer afraid of death.

Absolute masterpiece. Nuff said.

[spoiler]Hint: game continues after credits end.[/spoiler]

A great way to not be able to sleep at night, just thinking about what life would be like if you were just an average dude and someone stuffed you into a robotic diving suit and you weren't sure if your next jump would send you someplace new or leave you stranded deep under the ocean forever while a mere copy of you went off into space to go have fun and live and do cool human things.
This is one of those games that makes you look up at the stars and question everything, including existence.

SOMA is a game which is kind of inspired by dead space. But this game is very true in its way and the story is very confusing until we reach a certain level. This is not exactly an horror game like amnesia or outlast. This is very thrilling and keeps your nerves up throughtout the game.
The sound mixing is one of the best pros of the game it gives you a sense of fear throughout the game.
The gameplay is simple as expected.
The concept of the game is good and the ending is also well done.
Those who love to play an game which keeps your nerves up, go for SOMA without any doubt. Don't expct it to be a regular horror game type, its not. The story is also crisp and short.
Enjoy the game!!!!!!

9/10

A way better horror game than outlast, well written story and great world building. one the best sci-fi horror games on steam.

Excellent game even though the traditional horror elements fell flat for me. The story is outstanding and presented in a way that respects the player's intelligence - the hooks it leaves in you stay long after the closing credits. Would recommend even if you dislike horror games. Best experienced going in blind.
Great story and a fun game, but I'd have to recommend that you get it while on sale because the price isn't worth just 8 hours of gameplay.

[REFER TO 2ND PARAGRAPH FOR ACTUAL REVIEW] Flashback to 2010, I found out about Amnesia the dark descent through a review from PC gamer and it got me intrigued to play the game. I was amazed with how they implemented the sanity meter and how the gameplay was focused on ways you can sneak through areas while having to avoid the monster that roams the area without a means of fighting. Thus, it was to my pleasant surprise when frictional games announced about their new and upcoming game that would involve psychological horror with robots possessing human consciences  which I found out through watching their teaser trailers prior to the release of their game and boy was I super excited for it to come out! Unfortunately, when soma came out in 2015, I was too preoccupied with real world problems and since I didn't hear too much about how well soma did, my excitement for the game died down. Now that I have more free time, I decided to browse through games from the recent steam sale and that was when soma was brought back to my attention. I bought the game, not expecting much out of it and to my surprise I fell in love with it! Upon taking breaks inbetween, I'd have the urge to continue playing the game out of curiosity to know more about how the story would progress and man was I glad to have made that purchase! So on to the review!

First, let's address the elephant in the room which would be the horror and gameplay. Let me say this first, horror is subjective, each and everyone has their own fears and something that 1 person deems scary might not seem scary to another. I personally felt that the monster designs were intriguing rather than scary. I was even in awe when I encountered the 1st monster and went up close to it but got killed instead XD Ways to evade monsters work very similarly to those you've encountered back in the previous Amnesia games; some are blind and are more sensitive to sound so making as little noise as possible is advised (i.e., avoid opening doors which makes a lot of noise, don't run, don't move when confronted) while some are more sensitive to how close you are so keeping your distance is advised. Information regarding advice on how to evade the monsters can be learnt through reading notes and listening to audio recordings. Although the monsters each have unique characteristics which can be used to your advantage when being confronted by them, most of the time you can just outrun the enemies and proceed to hiding unless you're in a particularly enclosed area where you'd encounter a lot of dead ends. The objective for each area would usually involve accessing security monitors to unlock certain locked doors or retrieving certain items required to proceed further while avoiding the monster that roams the area which work very much like amnesia and penumbra.

The sanity meter from amnesia also doesn't make an appearance which I thought was 1 of the main selling points for amnesia though this might be nitpicking since soma's focus is not exactly the horror that amnesia was going for. Surprisingly, I still had some heart-pounding moments while I crouched down, hiding and waiting for the monster to not notice my presence. The sound-design and beautifully rendered graphics also definitely helped bring a sense of eeriness and hopelessness with regards to the predicament that your character is in. A few people have mentioned that it would've been better if the monsters were removed from the game since they interfere with the player's ease of accessing various rooms to look up more information on the backstory of the game but considering that the monsters play a huge role in the narrative, I think it's more of a problem regarding how the areas are designed. Fortunately, for players who did find the need to hide from the monsters an issue, frictional games has added a "safe mode" which prevents the monsters from attacking you so that you can freely roam through the map. 
 
Next up would be story which is the game's main selling point. I kid you not, I think the premise and the story is one for the big screen but I won't spoil it to anticipating players, you'll have to play the game to find out;) I'll just say that the story involves a lot of philosophical issues regarding life and what it means to be human and frictional games made such a unique concept out of it, it's brilliant! Voice acting is sorta all over the place, the main protagonist sounds unnatural during the first few scenes but for some reason, it seems to get better as the story progresses to the point that some of the dialogue acted out during the serious moments caused me to empathize for the character a lot. He also goes on to meet another supporting character and I honestly can't get enough of their interactions together as they ponder about their existence and their ideologies. A few people have criticized the game for having a few plot holes and inconsistencies here and there but, unless you've finished the game and looked up all documents and audio logs in the game, I don't think one has the right to judge the game in such a way. I personally think they tied up the story's loose ends pretty well. 

To sum up, this game was such an amazing experience. Initially I was just excited about how the story would unravel with such an amazing premise but along the way, I started wondering about the philosophical issues brought up by the characters in the game and I came to love the characters a lot as well. I will never forget about this game and I think it's safe to say that it's now my favorite horror game of all time. That was such a roller coaster of feels:,) I highly encourage that you go play this game if you haven't and if you're a fan of sci-fi thrillers!
You've sobbed from existential dread in front of a disinterested woman before but now you can do it UNDERWATER

appDetails.name: SOMA
appDetails.detailed_description:
SOMA is a sci-fi horror game from Frictional Games, the creators of Amnesia: The Dark Descent. It is an unsettling story about identity, consciousness, and what it means to be human.

The radio is dead, food is running out, and the machines have started to think they are people. Underwater facility PATHOS-II has suffered an intolerable isolation and we’re going to have to make some tough decisions. What can be done? What makes sense? What is left to fight for?

Enter the world of SOMA and face horrors buried deep beneath the ocean waves. Delve through locked terminals and secret documents to uncover the truth behind the chaos. Seek out the last remaining inhabitants and take part in the events that will ultimately shape the fate of the station. But be careful, danger lurks in every corner: corrupted humans, twisted creatures, insane robots, and even an inscrutable omnipresent A.I.
You will need to figure out how to deal with each one of them. Just remember there’s no fighting back, either you outsmart your enemies or you get ready to run.

igdb.name: Kimmy
igdb.summary: Kimmy is a visual novel game about a young babysitter in 1968. Dana takes a lonely girl named Kimmy under her wing, worried that she's having trouble making friends. Let summer begin! Collect trinkets, play street games, and learn about Kimmy and her mysterious family as summer passes by.

reviews.review:
I really enjoyed this game. My only problem is that it was so short! 

This game is really enjoyable, and it really gets you in the mind of children around 4 or 10. It's really neat, and I think it's really accurate with how I felt back then, when I was that young. 

The music is also beautiful, and it slowly gets darker as more and more are revealed about Kimmy, the main character, and her family. 

Lastly, even though the animation is very simple it's very pleasant, and I really like all the artwork! 

It's really sad, but worth the money, especially if it's on sale!

It shouldn't come as a suprise but here is a truth Kimmy exposed me to: I do not know what Bloody Knuckles play like and it took me 2 attempts to get the right rules for Kick the Can.
Kimmy is very pretty and engaging to play, but more importantly, I found it displayed great sensitivity and restrain in its writing of kids dialogs: they are of the right complexity and they manage to be very evocative of unseen situations, in a way  that is neither sappy or overwritten. 
The pacing of the overall experience and the sense of closure were on point as well; givin the aftertaste of a game that found its perfect shape.

Despite having played Star Maid Games' previous work, Cibele, I still had no expectations that this particular game would somehow be relatable for me. And even though I felt put off by the game not allowing me to force my new friends into playing any of the weird, but infinitely more interesting, games I kept trying to present to them, that did not take away from the emotional impact this beautiful vignette offers. My heart strings shall surely be expectant and better prepared for you next time, Star Maid! Thank you for this lovely game!

Really, really good. Really heartfelt. Captured the Americana vibe well, and the story is a really strong coming-of-age piece that feels mature and very sincere. You will definitely believe in and probably relate to the relationship between Dana and Kimmy if you had kids on your block that you grew up with, and that aspect of it makes the writing hit home all the more.

It's no direct comparison, but if you like Stand By Me, My Girl, etc. I think you'll appreciate this. Definitely playable in one session, and I wouldn't break it up.

pros:

nice hand drawn art
good dialogue for the characters
captivating story

cons;

no replayability
linear story 
no dialogue choices only activity choices

i personally liked the game very much but not worth the price...it would be worth it if it had alternate endings...but because of the subject matter i guess there cannot be any alternate endings or real choices that efffect the game itself.
that is a shame though.

so wait for a good sale and enjoy a wonderfull yet heartbreaking game.

about 2 to 4 hours of game play so it is fairly short game especially for the price...

Kimmy was a short game but it has replay value to explore the different dialouges. I picked it up on a 15% sale and it was easily worth it. It does a really great job displaying childrens' emotions, dialouges, and thought processes. In my first playthrough alone the story dealt with themes of honesty, bullying, racism, childhood romance, growing up, and nostalgic summers. The story makes you feel like a kid again, especially reminiscent of adults purposefully keeping secrets in fear of you not being able to emotionally comprehend difficult situations. Pick it up if you're a fan of visual novels!
Get lost teaching street games to the neighborhood kids, never noticing that dark secrets are being kept.
Heartbreaking as much as it is heart warming. Grab some snacks and drinks and play through in one sitting for a great time.

The latest game from designer Nina Freeman (Cibele, Tacoma), Kimmy is a visual novel with a quirky style courtesy of artist Laura Knetzger (who had also worked with Nina on Freshman Year). The game is very simple to play, with the player primarily making a few choices through dialogue and who to interact with. You play as Dana, who becomes a babysitter to younger girl Kimmy. During the days that you babysit, you have a limited amount of time to play with other kids, buy toys and games, and learn more about the residents of your town. As with many of Nina Freeman’s games, what appears on the surface to be a normal 1960’s summer is in fact a dark, mature tale of the struggles that many families face. The game moves along at a good pace, taking you from interaction to interaction without much fuss and hardly a single wasted word throughout the entire game. It is very interesting to see the world through the eyes of a young girl at that time – I can’t think of any other game where the player takes the role of a middle-school-aged-girl. 
	Overall, it is a very interesting and impactful game that doesn’t take too long to tell its story. If you are a big fan of story in games, or just find this premise interesting, I’d definitely recommend picking Kimmy up! There is a demo on Steam, and the game is available on PC and Mac.

I got this game because I'm a fan of Nina's (she makes interesting games and she's a total fox!).  This game is short but it does a great job of making you feel like you're babysitting and responsible for this other person's happiness.  There are some really tragic conversations in here that will hit hard if you're an adult.  Anyway, long story short, support games like this and try it out.  It's short, sweet, and memorable.

Me ha gustado muchísimo por todos lados: el estilo de dibujo perfecto con la temática del juego, niños, verano, diversión... supura paz y tranquilidad por todos lados, y al jugarlo, te embarga la ternura y la dulzura de los protagonistas. 

Refleja y transmite un mensaje muy positivo, la amistad, la soledad, la sociedad, uno mismo... de verdad, es un juego que deja un muy buen sabor de boca y te saca más de una sonrisa, aparte de muchas capturas de pantalla por bromas inocentes o ingeniosas que querrás volver a leer o frases que querrás enseñar a tus amigos, porque son enseñazas directas, sinceras y cargadas de mucha realidad, pero expresado de una manera inocente, como lo ven los niños.

En este juego han trabajado el creador de la banda sonora, Louie Zong, que ha participado en muchos más proyectos reconocidos y una de las diseñadoras y escritoras del juego, Nina Freeman, quien tiene ya un juego conocido, Cibele (muy buen juego).

Lo recomiendo, y mucho. Os va a gustar si os gusta lo que veis en el trailer, si os gustan las historias bonitas y los personajes agradables, que te saquen una sonrisa y te enseñen valores positivos.
I really appriciate the exploration of a topic, setting, and age range we don't typically see represented in games.

Lovely little game about childhood innocence, and the looming issues that children can ultimately do nothing about. Definitely some awkward writing, and a game that doesnt really invite replaying despite the face that it is impossible to unlock all the conversations in one go, but still recommended for those who like realistic, story driven games.

appDetails.name: Kimmy
appDetails.detailed_description:
Kimmy is a visual novel style game about a summer spent babysitting in late 1960s Massachusetts. You play as Dana, who stumbles across Kimmy--a tiny girl wandering around alone in her neighborhood. Dana decides to take Kimmy under her wing, worried that she's having trouble making friends, and decides to be her babysitter. Let summer begin! Collect trinkets, play street games, and learn more and more about Kimmy and her mysterious family as summer passes by.

Features:

  • A dialogue rich story that takes place over the course of 5 acts.
  • Over 10 characters to chat with and get to know throughout the story.
  • A painterly art-style brings the characters to life, including multiple illustrated cut scenes.
  • An intimate story about childhood, honesty and growing up.

Recommendations and Notes

  • A single play through takes about 2 to 3 hours.
  • Play multiple times to see all of the conversations.
  • Headphones are recommended.

Content warning:

Kimmy is a game about childhood, but it does address some more serious issues and is primarily intended for adults. There are conversations between the characters about things like death, profanities and alcohol. Please consider this before playing this game with younger kids.

Credits:

Designed and written by: Nina Freeman
Illustrated and written by: Laura Knetzger
Programmed by: Aaron Freedman
OST Composed by: Louie Zong
Sound design by: Amos Roddy
Special thanks to Noel Clark for the Kimmy logo design.

Kimmy was originally commissioned by Humble Bundle as a part of the Humble Monthly Bundle, released to subscribers in January of 2017. Special thanks to Humble Bundle for their support in the development of Kimmy!

igdb.name: Penarium
igdb.summary: Poor Willy. Trapped in a sinister circus, his only hope of seeing his family is to run and jump his way past an array of deathtraps while being cheered on by a sadistically bloodthirsty crowd.

reviews.review:
Penarium is a pure platformer. No exploration, no shooting. Only moving and jumping. 

What else is there? A self-contained level whose borders you can cross to find yourself on the other side, and traps. Tons of traps that cycle during the duration of the level. Machine-guns, homing missiles, bubble-gum to make the platforms sticky while a see-saw journeys across… The goal of the game is to collect items that spawn in the level while avoiding different sets of traps. Simple, and yet effective.

This game is exactly what I was looking for. I am quite sick of the ‘muscle memory’ platformers where you have to learn by heart at which point of the level you jump, the perfect trajectory to land between spikes, and so on. Penarium focuses on the moment-to-moment frantic experience. Quick skills are required instead of a good finger memory, and it is rather telling that less than 20% of the players completed the 1st world. Penarium is very difficult, and as it sports a “sadistic circus” theme, you would have to be a masochist to like it. 

And yet I never found its difficulty to cross the “unfair” invisible line. The hitbox of the character is actually smaller than he looks. The movements are perfect, with double-jump and responsive controls without either the sliding momentum or the input delay that harm many platformers. The traps are more or less hard to avoid, but all can be predictable or give the player visual cues. But yeah, quick thinking and fast reflexes are mandatory. Oh, and I really appreciate that there is no timer adding an external pressure to the action. It is possible to either rush through the traps, or time them carefully. 

So despite the high difficulty, moving like a madman and surviving amongst the chaos is exhilarating. It is fun. It does not feel like the game is punishing the player, because the action is constant and the threats come from everywhere while still being manageable. And the variety/movement of traps help make the game not feel repetitive. It can be finished in a few hours, and this type of game is not enjoyable if it gets much longer than that. To extend the fun, there is an endless mode with permanent progression.

To conclude, I was surprised to love this simple game so much more than the other hardcore platformers. I think it’s due to the good maneuverability, the difficult yet manageable design, and most of all the dynamic traps that require quick skills and provide a lot of fun by getting rid of the ‘muscle memory’ level design that usually goes with that kind of platformers.  

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=712733656

Oh the joy and the lower back pains this game gave me..
Penarium is an addictive game. It is so simple and I had so much fun, a game you would expect from Team 17.
I hope Willy gets to do some other things except from jumping and running in the sequel (if there is one?).

10/10 would recommend!  \(^_^)/

This game is very addictive, fun, challenging and pretty. I'm normally not a fan of big pixels style but here it works somehow. Combine that with a simple, yet suprisingly effective story, and you've got something really worth its small price.   Also there' an endless arcade mode and co-op, thought for some reason my other controller refused to work. 
My score: solid 7.5/10
This is highly addictive. I don't remember being that much hooked up on something since Darkwing Duck on NES.

Really great little game, highly polished artstyle and tight controls, so tight, that I become sexually aroused when playing it.

Devilishly difficult with Meat Boy levels of frustration.

One disappointment is you can't play the campaign missions in co-op, but the other co-op modes (survival and versus) are satisfying. Though I initially bought this just for the co-op and was slightly miffed to find this isn't the next Towerfall, it then turned out the game has a meaty single player and excellent arcade mode so no worries a ding ding dong.

Penarium is a pleasant surprise. Bursting with personality, this arena-based arcade game is simple to look at, but a ton of fun to play. 

Seriously, you need to check this one out!

https://youtu.be/wX_AL6sV_kg
Fun game, nice art, great music and lots of fun playing the story line.

Great game. Frustrating, addicting and hard.
Definitly worth the money.
Penarium is ridiculous and chaotic, I love it!

This game is very challenging, and a LOT of fun. I got the 50 deaths achievement within 40 minutes of play, but never once felt frustrated or that the game was unfair. The gameplay is deceptively simple: all you do is jump between platforms. However, the different level goals, and the absurd amount of continuously changing trap combinations, force you to keep an eye on the entire screen and always keep you on your toes.

The campaign appears to be somewhat short, i seem to be over halfway through it within an hour of play, though your mileage may vary. Personally i feel that i got my money's worth, but you may want to keep that in mind. There is also an endless survival mode and a local multiplayer mode which further extend the game.

I love everything about the game so far, from the gameplay, to the art, to the music, to the setting, and definitely recommend it.

Penarium is an old school single screen wrap around skill based platformer in the spirit of games like bubble bobble. It's got a great graphic style and a good difficulty curve I often found myself finishing a level after thinking just one more try, which is exactly like it should be for skill based game like this. The music is fits nicely with the theme and the short span and the variety make it's tricky levels fun, replayable and well balanced. While certainly tough at times, the game always feels fair, the game has good weighty feel to it's physics and collision detection are great, when you die, which you will many many times, it's because you made a mistake. A charming little game more than worth it's price 4/5.
Fun game to pass time or to just have a 5 minute break.
love the game very simple but fun lol
Addicting & fun! Love to play in local coop mode!

What can I say about Penarium?

I was going to criticise it for being short. It is short, but it's exactly as long as it needs to be. There's something to be said for a game that can be completed in a single sitting, and never feel repetitive or like it's dragging its feet.

I was going to criticise it for being simple. It is simple, but its simplicity is elegant. The combinations of its approximately 15 traps make for some beautifully intense and varied gameplay.

I was going to criticise it for playing like a bonus challenge minigame at the end of a more fleshed-out game. It is reminiscent of a bonus challenge minigame, but unlike such games, it's well-designed, balanced, clever, and difficult to master.

So now, given the satisfying, challenging gameplay, beautifully realised pixel-art, and surprisingly engrossing setting and characters, I'm left with only one complaint:

Why is it that a rolling rock that could (and often will) crush me in an instant, does not crush the barrels I'm supposed to break!?

I had been playing this game for around half an hour every day for several months, trying to complete the campaign mode. I got all the way up to the last level and I couldn't beat it. Took a break for a few months and went back to try again. It took me a week but I finally completed campaign mode.

This game is insanely difficult, and so many times I died from either missing a jump or barely touching one of the many obstacles. I hate the birds, the dragons, the rockets and those icicles, and I have no idea how you can break more than 50 of those barrels.

So overall I enjoyed Penarium and felt so satisfied beating it.
Engraçado e difícil =D

appDetails.name: Penarium
appDetails.detailed_description:
Penarium is set in a sinister circus arena, where contestants, much like Gladiators of old, are forced to entertain a sadistic crowd. In this frantic 2D arena arcade game, you take on the role of our quirky antihero; Willy who, to survive, is forced to run, jump and avoid an array of killer death-traps. Succeed and Willy will become the Champion of Penarium. Fail and he will die in a most horrendous way, much to the delight of the baying crowd.

Guide poor Willy through this evil madness in single player and 2 player local COOP and Competitive modes. Every kid wants to go to circus but no kid wants to die in one.

Feature List


  • 3 Arenas
  • 4 Game Modes
  • Campaign mode featuring 30 challenges
  • Arcade mode featuring over a dozen of unlockable power-ups
  • COOP and VS local multiplayer
  • Online leaderboards
  • Dark comical dialogue and cutscenes

igdb.name: This War of Mine
igdb.summary:
In This War Of Mine you do not play as an elite soldier, rather a group of civilians trying to survive in a besieged city; struggling with lack of food, medicine and constant danger from snipers and hostile scavengers. The game provides an experience of war seen from an entirely new angle. 

The pace of This War of Mine is imposed by the day and night cycle. During the day snipers outside stop you from leaving your refuge, so you need to focus on maintaining your hideout: crafting, trading and taking care of your survivors. At night, take one of your civilians on a mission to scavenge through a set of unique locations for items that will help you stay alive. 

Make life-and-death decisions driven by your conscience. Try to protect everybody from your shelter or sacrifice some of them for longer-term survival. During war, there are no good or bad decisions; there is only survival. The sooner you realize that, the better.

alternative_names.name: This War of Mine: The Little Ones

Initially, I was a bit turned off by this game, as all of the reviews (even the good ones) called it depressing, and I just wasn’t in the mood to be bummed out.  When I finally picked it up, I just didn’t get that vibe.  The stories can be sad, and the lore you experience can be melancholy, but the game itself is still about overcoming challenges and hardship.  And I think that message is what made this game addicting for me.

The atmosphere and sound design are incredibly immersive.  There’s tension everywhere, and even a friendly knock on the door can be terrifying.  This is when you know a game has pulled you in and demonstrated just how helpless you are.  The art style portrays the hard times and difficult environment, but it is also so beautifully done.  It’s hard to not admire it sometimes, even when everyone is struggling.  The characters also have interesting back stories, and you even learn to care about some of them. Some.

One of my only complaints is that once I beat the game, I felt like I learned the “formula” needed to be successful in this game.  There were also only so many places to explore, and very little changed about them.  This meant you knew what to expect every play through.  This dropped the replayability a lot for me, and it also killed a bit of the magic I first had when I initially played.  

My other complaint is that I think ALL of the characters are too sensitive about the same things.  I can understand some not wanting to steal to survive, but it negatively affects almost EVERYONE.  For example, some replayability could come from treating situations differently.  Maybe I want to try stealing to survive, or defending myself with weapons while scavenging (meaning, I could potentially kill someone).  Well, I can’t, because every character will take each of those actions so negatively, they’ll most likely kill themselves if I play this way.  This sort of mechanic felt a bit shallow to me.  Maybe not shallow, but I felt like the devs definitely want you to play it their way.

Even though I have those complaints, I cannot overstate how much I recommend this game.  It’s beautifully done, and there’s nothing else out there quite like it.  Trust me, I’ve checked when I needed to scratch that itch.  Thanks to the devs for a great game!
good
An amazing, dark, and daring game.  Highly recommended.
Very good survival game!

[i]This war of mine. A very deep game that gets into a heart of not just one player.[/i]

I was searching for a game like this. A game where your choices matter and where one mistake can actually ruin the whole game. 
This war of mine is a game that shows the perspective of people, innocent people that sadly have to experience war. So you don't see the war through the eyes of a soldier, how many games show. You start in a shelter, destroyed shelter by shelling and looters. By time you try to make this shelter more comfortable for all the people that live in it. There are many different characters and each one of them has their own story. There are different sets of characters and everytime you play you unlock new stories basicaly, since you unlock more sets of characters that you need to take care of. Or you can even make your own set of characters. You need to scavenge, make difficult choices and survive. You can go through the war without killing a single person, or you can play agressively, it is just up to you. I really like how the game's atmosphere pulls you into the story and how it puts you into a role of a person that is responsible for lives of other people. When you let one of your characters die, you just feel so miserable. When one of your characters falls into depression or the character gets sick, you try to do as much as you can to keep them fine. It is often a big challange to keep everyone alive till the war ends.
But when you manage to, the feeling is amazing!

This game is worth its price, it is a great game, even though it may not be for everyone. Overall epic game with deep atmosphere and many possibilites. For this price, you get 15 hours of play time at the minimum which is obviously pretty great. 9/10

Let me start off saying this is a great game concept wise and does have some great features.  But thier are soooo many issues that it has turned me off to the point it is barely playable without mods. Great game as far as atmosphere and the overall idea behind it.  But the numerous bugs and the fact that the base game is so damn easy to survive.  If you do hiccup somewhere all you have to do is leave and restart the day and boom all is fine.  Cheesy but hard to avoid knowing you can get back the character that died simply by restarting the day.  Also Katia is still completely broken as you can unrealistically clear out the entire inventory of any trader be trading back and forth since she gets a HUGE discount and after a few minutes of back and forth you can basically empty out the trader.  Also the game crashes often and after 70 days in when a character or characters just freeze and you cannot interract and have to watch them starve to death since they cannot move is a joke since this problem has been for years now just as the Katia problem.  This happens often with the kids especially.  Also charcters glitch and will say things that makes no sense. 
 NPCs will talk as if other NPCs are there even when alone ("Hit Him", "Don't let him get away!", etc). I do actually still enjoy the game by using difficulty mods that make the game much harder.  Because it is just too easy once you understand you can take advantage of so many loopholes.  The garage has so much easy access suplies.  the Supermarket and Hospital will get you Rifles and Shotguns with many bullets right off the jump by simply stealth killing the baddies.  It is just too easy late game especially like once you are basically self suffficent with an alchohol and Tobacco empire as well as a garden and traps etc.  Just too many problems which is disappointing because the general concept is very cool. I wish the developers would address all of these issues I just don't get why they can't.   A shame because it is truly very close to being a great game despite the simply layout and controls due to decision making and environment.

even i played this game once, i really want play again over and over again. this game never bored me. and this game just reminds me that war is more scary than all game and film i saw. the music nice and saving money coz really wanted the tri DLC 10/10 this game awsome.

Such an amazing game, after several playthroughs and owning it for a couple years this game hasn't gotten old.  Stories for each character are amazing, and I actually gave a damn about them.  This game makes you pay attention to the things you do and the decisions you make, if you kill helpless people, your characters will be effected.

9.5/10

This game was extremely difficult. Untill about my 4th attempt when I finally realized you could use weapons to kill thugs and military. Despite barely being able to put my own pants on, and drinking out of a sippy cup, this game was thoroughly enjoyable.
toll
this was a very depressing, but meaningful and emotional ~game, unlike any other in my experience. You feel the moral choices. In the end, "winning" is mere survival.

Great Game!

Do or Die Simulator :D

After a year-long hiatus on this game and numerous others, I finally got around to resetting my computer entirely and now have reinstalled the game. Jesus Christ I couldn't have done it fast enough. Simply starting this game and being greeted by its hauntingly beautiful soundtrack is utterly spellbinding.  

Drawing inspiration from the Bosnian War and its numerous battles, The Siege of Sarajevo in particular, This War of Mine utilises real stories and events from survivors of the Bosnian War to paint a vivid picture. In This War of Mine you control a group of survivors that are thrust into an unknown warzone, the point of the anonymity aids the game in relaying the fact that a conflict like this can and will be happening somewhere in the world. This group must fight, scavenge and survive until the conflict is resolved, weapons and tools are rarity, food and water more so.  

Every decision you make, you make for the group, and if you wish for the pack to survive, you best make the right ones. Constantly hammering you with ACTUALLY impactful adaptions to the gameplay and ACTUALLY punishing you for stupid or "necessary" mistakes or judgements. Enter buildings at your own risk, steal from those less fortunate or outright kill others and become as mad as the world around you, the choice and freedom of your decisions will reverberate through the community and your other housemates however. 

The soundtrack is as I've previously said, hauntingly beautiful, taking inspiration from games like the Metro series, it's sweeping and yet at times so focused on minor details. Such as the winds providing an almost breeze-like effect, the lone guitar providing something that can hook the player in and can feel solidarity to. Other times the music shifts to a much darker tone, leaving open to anxious thoughts and allowing panic and fear to enter your once resolute mind. In short, Piotr Musial has done a gorgeous job and provided something that could hold a flame to composers such as Alexy Omelchukand, Keiichi Okabe and Austin Wintory 

The gameplay and UI are simplistic, taking away any unnecessary filler information that could distract you from completing your tasks. Your tasks for the day are easy; stay home, build and shore up whatever defences you can, maintain the wellbeing of your household and keep warm. Simple as. However, when night comes, so do the monsters who hide in plain sight. Opting to either keep all your occupants home and safe, or risking the night is a harsh but easy one, risking a bullet to the head certainly keeps the house fed after all. So, with whatever tools that can be found or made and hopefully some protection, the scavenger can get to work. This is where a majority of your thinking skills come in handy, figuring out who to hit. Do you go for the hospital where medicine and clean water are in surplus, but you're ultimately stealing from those far worse off than you, or do you steal from the elderly couple whose house has remained untouched, but your very presence strikes fear into their hearts. Especially when they catch you stealing from them.  Again, completely up to you, but for every ill deed there comes a reckoning. 

Scrolling past some of the other user reviews it's easy to be disheartened or even scoff at seeing the fifth review calling it "depressing" or seeing some diva whine about the how emotionally scarred they are after playing this game. But the funny thing is, they're true, at least partially. This game IS depressing, it's heart wrenching, punishing and judging. But that's exactly the point. No longer are you John Generic, US Marine and world champion crayon eater who saves the day by shooting anything dressed in red and has the words EVIL ductaped to its head. You are a human being, flawed, complicated and up a very large creek called shit. This War of Mine isn't meant to be another story about John Generic saving the world, it's about you, and the choices you make to save the house that is your world.  

This is a sobering game. These events have happened, will happen and will continue to happen. War is an unending cycle, it's something humanity is good at and let's face it, people don't like to stop when they've realised their potential. However, instead of picking up the controller or opening up GTA: V to have some 11-year-old tell you about his sexual conquests whilst he blasts you from three kilometres away. Buy this game and attempt to live as a stable house whilst the ever-present fear of failure, madness and death breathe down your neck. Suffer, and witness what it's like to be one of people caught in John Generic's crossfire.  

If you're still uncertain but can put up with my "essay" I urge you to watch a man called DasBoSchitt play this game, not only does he convey everything one hopes to feel with this game but he does it in such a tasteful manner I'm utterly shocked at his subscriber count. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=31R8lt-njtc&list=PLnXFQiKEVqUP9_tZAxlc9j0GKRdj3q7NU

TLDR: PLAY THIS GAME. WATCH THE LINK IF YOU'RE UNSURE OR BROKE AF
Good game, more "long"  DLC please, Story DLC is too short

The game is awsome heart wrenching and over all a real thinker and a lot of effort was put into the story.... but... the controls are absolutely the worst, even if you start out right you get killed so easy because your player just derps all over the freaking place, i just had to rage quit because while trying to do a steath takedown my charicter slamed open a door and sat there like there was zenomprph alien unable to move... i had a knife and a very very good game going but sadly, because of janky unusable controls i cant play a game i paid for... and is truely a well thought out one at that.
Cant fix an Alt+Tab glitch 3-4 years later WTF
Found it boring
Game is fun. But it keeps crashing all the time! Can someone help me please? I really want to play this game.

It's ok but I would barely call it a game. Very boring and repetitive near the end. Flakey controls, and just a huge time waste waiting for your character to craft and walk from one location to another.

appDetails.name: This War of Mine
appDetails.detailed_description:
The universe of This War of Mine has been expanded by two DLCs:

- The Little Ones - explores the hardships of wartime survival as seen from an entirely new perspective - that of a child.
- The Father's Promise - a heartbreaking tale of loss and hope in a war-torn city, opening a season of brand new independent Stories, with the second episode coming in 2018.



In This War Of Mine you do not play as an elite soldier, rather a group of civilians trying to survive in a besieged city; struggling with lack of food, medicine and constant danger from snipers and hostile scavengers. The game provides an experience of war seen from an entirely new angle.

The pace of This War of Mine is imposed by the day and night cycle. During the day snipers outside stop you from leaving your refuge, so you need to focus on maintaining your hideout: crafting, trading and taking care of your survivors. At night, take one of your civilians on a mission to scavenge through a set of unique locations for items that will help you stay alive.

Make life-and-death decisions driven by your conscience. Try to protect everybody from your shelter or sacrifice some of them for longer-term survival. During war, there are no good or bad decisions; there is only survival. The sooner you realize that, the better.

This War of Mine: Anniversary Edition

It's been two years since This War of Mine global release and we're still expanding the experience. This new free DLC, created especially for the Anniversary Edition, adds new characters, new locations to explore, and most importantly - a whole new ending, leading to a different outcome to the game. The dilemma though remains the same – how far will you go, to protect the ones you care about? 

This War of Mine:

  • Inspired by real-life events
  • Control your survivors and manage your shelter
  • Craft weapons, alcohol, beds or stoves – anything that helps you survive
  • Make decisions - an often unforgiving and emotionally difficult experience
  • Randomized world and characters every time you start a new game
  • Charcoal-stylized aesthetics to complement the game's theme

Babel:

Babel project is a community-based translation initiative that will allow us to bring This War of Mine experience to people all around the world.

Thanks to Babel these new languages are already available in game:
  • Finnish
  • Hungarian
  • Romanian
  • Vietnamese
  • Czech
You can be a part of the project. Register and start working on the translation right away at babel.thiswarofmine.com

Previews:

IGN

This War of Mine might be the war game we need.

Gamespot

I was intrigued by This War of Mine's attempts to portray the consequences of war in a way that games have largely ignored in the past. The fact that the psychological and emotional challenges of living under such horrifying conditions are something you have to consider as you struggle gives me added hope that it might treat its hefty and important subject matter with the gravity and complexity that it deserves.

Game Informer

11bit is blazing a new thematic trail amidst the currently popular survival genre, and so far the studio seems to have something special on its hand.

The game provides an experience of war seen from an entirely new angle.
appDetails.supported_languages:
English*, French, German, Polish, Russian, Italian, Portuguese-Brazil, Spanish, Japanese, Korean, Turkish, Simplified Chinese
*languages with full audio support
appDetails.reviews:
“This War of Mine is a gripping survival sim, and a great study of survival during wartime and civil collapse.”
8.4 – IGN UK

“This War of Mine shows the horrors of war in a way, that we rarely can experience in a game.”
9 – Giga Games

“Is this a game you want to play? No. Is it a game anyone with a beating heart should play? Yes. A million times yes. It's a longform exercise in empathy, a sobering piece of work that fills in the blanks left when all we see of war are the headshots. It's a much-needed course correct in the current shoot-first-ask-questions-never gaming landscape that supposes war is won because one supreme badguy caught a bullet through his brainstem. No: It's won when the people who lived under his boot get to go home.”
8 – Gamespot

appDetails.name: SPACECOM
appDetails.detailed_description:
Game Demo

Not sure if you'll like the game? Download our DEMO and try our Single Player campaign and our challenging Multiplayer mode!
Get the Steam DEMO now!


About the Game

SPACECOM – a strategic-to-the-bone, starfleet command game in which deception, smart movement, and choices to battle decide victory or defeat.

No coincidence, no luck. Spacecom pushes your ability to strategize with a focus on real-time tactics and planning. Use proven maneuvers learned from military legends or devise your own plans.

Test your wits in single player campaign, go head-to-head with up to 5 opponents in multiplayer or experiment with new strategies in AI skirmish mode. Most of all, you'll need a bright mind, cunning, and sound tactics.

When the war begins, leave the little things behind and dive into austere soundscapes as you immerse yourself in starfleet command. From now on, what matters is your grasp of tactics and strategy, not how fast you can click. Spacecom is about creativity in planning, not complexity of game mechanics.

Key Features


  • Single player campaign that will test your wit in diverse tactical puzzles
  • Tense multiplayer - dominate up to 5 players per map
  • No coincidence, no luck. What matters is good planning and successful execution
  • Sound designed specifically to trigger strategic thinking
  • Minimalistic visual design inspired by military technology
  • Created to exalt smart thinking over fast clicking

Previews


"In a market currently dominated by MOBAs, SPACECOM is set to offer a more nich perspective on strategy. Focused on concise combat roles and managing supply routes, it's all about using limited resources, to outwit your friends." - GameTrailers.com

"What really strikes me is that all of this is presented in an incredibly minimalistic style.(...) There is none of the distraction of flashy visual effects or incredibly renderedenvironments, this is pure strategy.(...) For me, an advocate of game mechanics above all else, this is as close to pure space strategy as I’ve seen and I’m really looking forward to the finished product." - gaminglives.com

"Spacecom is an interesting idea, as a quick-play strategy game. In a genre that tends to frighten off newcomers, Spacecom is poised to be the title that welcomes them in with open arms, avoiding complexity while still offering that classic 4X feeling. " - Criticallysane.com

appDetails.supported_languages: English, French, German, Spanish, Polish, Russian
appDetails.reviews:
“With Spacecom 11bit studios created perfectly working game mechanics which prove that you do not need elaborate animations to produce an immersive effect. I found Spacecom even more exciting and involving than most triple-A games recently. I would highly recommend it to all people who like good games.”
9/10 – IGN Deutschland

“Spacecom is simple, both graphically and mechanically—so simple it could almost be a board game. And yet despite—or rather, because of—this unassuming exterior, there's a lot of depth for you to explore within a limited space. That's the kind of strategy I like! It's like playing an actual game of chess where each piece has a very defined set of rules versus a weird game of pseudo-chess where each pawn functions slightly differently and you won't really understand the point of half of them until you're fifty hours in. We like to say "Graphics don't matter! Graphics don't matter!" Well, here's your proof. Just bring your imagination to the table, and there's a deeply satisfying strategy game waiting for you.”
4/5 – PC World

“Spacecom is exactly what I like. Challenging, smart, addictive, stimulating and yet not overloaded with unnecessary things. Flow Combine & 11 bit studios production represents the real meaning of strategy games and it’s essence. Every single fan of this genre, not only those with space theme, should check Spacecom.”
8,5/10 – http://gry.onet.pl/recenzje/spacecom-recenzja-male-jest-piekne-a-jakie-madre/pw3gd

igdb.name: A Fistful of Gun
igdb.summary:
When the evil railroad baron Clayton Boon decided to build a track to Hell, he didn’t reckon on a crazed shaman raising a posse of embittered psychopaths from the dead to stop him. Now they’ll pursue him across the whole Wild West, fighting their way through hordes of bandits, bears, braves and boogeymen just to find Boon and repay their debt with… A FISTFUL OF GUN!

Select one of eleven unique playable gunslingers and seek revenge as a lone wolf or with up to eight other bandits in local and online co-op. Master the specialized controls of each character, collect gold from fallen foes to purchase upgrades, and imbibe a bit of liquid courage and unleash a tornado of lead across the dusty plains.

reviews.review:
This game is fun and has a big learning curve but at time I die due to the controls not working well. I believe they need to rework the controls they can keep the reloading of some characters but they need to make the game twin stick with all characters because the rest don't work well they need to rework Pablo and a few other characters. I would not buy this game unless you can get it at a huge discount or they rework they controls
Tl:dr intresting concept classic feel but bad controls

appDetails.name: A Fistful of Gun
appDetails.detailed_description:
When the evil railroad baron Clayton Boon decided to build a track to Hell, he didn’t reckon on a crazed shaman raising a posse of embittered psychopaths from the dead to stop him. Now they’ll pursue him across the whole Wild West, fighting their way through hordes of bandits, bears, braves and boogeymen just to find Boon and repay their debt with… A FISTFUL OF GUN!

Select one of eleven unique playable gunslingers and seek revenge as a lone wolf or with your friends in local and online co-op. Master the specialized controls of each character, collect gold from fallen foes to purchase upgrades, and imbibe a bit of liquid courage and unleash a tornado of lead across the dusty plains.

Features


Misfits and Outlaws: Choose between eleven different gunslingers each with their own unique control scheme and methods of attack to master. Some characters require the finesse of a gamepad while others are strictly bound to mouse controls to mount their offensive.

Multiplayer and Co-Op Modes: Gather a posse of gunslingers for chaotic local multiplayer or connect online cooperative modes or square off with other gunslingers at the corral in the white-knuckled versus mode.

Story and Arcade Modes: Take up arms against those that stand opposed and blast your way through the colorful landscapes of the west against dozens of unique enemies. Grab a horse, forge a river, ride a train – there’s never a dull moment in the lawless lands of the Wild West!
appDetails.about_the_game:
When the evil railroad baron Clayton Boon decided to build a track to Hell, he didn’t reckon on a crazed shaman raising a posse of embittered psychopaths from the dead to stop him. Now they’ll pursue him across the whole Wild West, fighting their way through hordes of bandits, bears, braves and boogeymen just to find Boon and repay their debt with… A FISTFUL OF GUN!

Select one of eleven unique playable gunslingers and seek revenge as a lone wolf or with your friends in local and online co-op. Master the specialized controls of each character, collect gold from fallen foes to purchase upgrades, and imbibe a bit of liquid courage and unleash a tornado of lead across the dusty plains.

Story and Arcade Modes: Take up arms against those that stand opposed and blast your way through the colorful landscapes of the west against dozens of unique enemies. Grab a horse, forge a river, ride a train – there’s never a dull moment in the lawless lands of the Wild West!

igdb.name: Kero Blaster
igdb.summary:
Kero Blaster is a platform video game created by Daisuke "Pixel" Amaya. It was released in 2014 for PC and iOS and is the first major project of Pixel since Cave Story in 2004. The game lays a heavy emphasis on shooting and got positive reviews on both platforms. A short, free demo titled Pink Hour has been available since a month before the full game's release.
In Kero Blaster, the player controls a frog working for Cat & Frog, a teleporter company. Armed with a peashooter, he has to clean the teleporters of strange black monsters. The player has to work their way through a series of linear stages, by means of running, gunning and jumping. USGamer described the gameplay as "akin to ... Contra or old-school, pre-Symphony of the Night Castlevanias." Furthermore, the game is controlled by changing direction, jumping, firing your weapon and changing your weapon. Holding down the fire button continues to fire in the direction you were facing when you started shooting.

reviews.review: Really happy I bought this on sale and played through. Very cool game.lots of platformer fun. Definitely recommend if you like retro action platformer type games like I do.

better than cave story imho

igdb.name: The Masterplan
igdb.summary:
The Masterplan is a tactical team-based game where you plan and execute bank robberies and other heists. The 2D top-down view gives you a great overview of what's happening at any given moment, allowing you to be a real criminal mastermind.

Set in 1971, a story written by Tom Jubert (FTL, The Swapper), hand-drawn graphics, and the soundtrack recorded by real musicians with real instruments that evoke the unique mood of a 70s crime movie.

reviews.review: Great game, although I wish they made more levels as I got trough them pretty quickly. Not sure why people are complaining about controls, if you are not disabled you will be able to play this game just fine.

Initial impressions - 
1. The game COULD have been quite enjoyable
BUT 
2. it has been ruined by what must be the worst control system I have seen in 30 years of gaming. Truly horrible stuff. Non-intuitive, unresponsive and useless in a pinch.
Game crashes often getting to be frustrating when almost finished with a level.

The game itself is quite interesting but I cannot recommend it because of the amount of bugs and wonky behavior. If the devs want to patch the game to be well playable, I'd give it a big thumbs up.

Right now it's just not worth it, _especially_ considering it's 20€ which is absurd for this kind "polish".

This game is abandoned. The last update by the devs (2015) was adding a workshop whcih allowed users to upload maps they created but the map editor was third party software + it's hard to undrerstand (for me atleast). In my opinion is good at the start, the tutorial is very helpful and it made sense and it has a story that the game completely abandons after the tutorial is done. There is one mission called 'lonely alley' clearly it was a mission the devs put in to be mysterious and it had no uses, just a door that blocked off the 'alley' that you couldn't open. I opened it with some trusty C4 (unanticipated by the devs obviously) and of course, nothing. An incomplete mission. Suprisingly the stealth is pretty good if you're a micromanager. The proggresion is fairly balanced but you'll find yourself repeating missions to get money for new gear/ammo/crew which gets tiresome. Graphics for this game are nice, I like the art style and the shadows look really good. The final mission (SPOILERS if u even care which i wouldn't) is stealing form Fort Knox, if robbing Fort Knox was THIS easy I'd know where to start and end my criminal career. Some weapons you can only acquire from certain missions (they don't respawn if you do the mission again) aren't purchasable from the market, so say you drop some sweet knuckle dusters you found in the toture room of the police station to pick up some cash instead and escape. SAY BYE BYE TO THE KNUCKLE DUSTERS. Your crew also feel like empty mules to carry out your commands, no speech (excpet for the toutorial, they chat like birds in the morning). I would've reccomended this game if they actually put time into the map editor and allowed the players to express their creative potenial and show the world, it's saved so many games in the past and I don't understand if they were willing to stop making agame without the likelyhood of people playing beyond the base missions. It pains me that a game with such pontential has to get neglected by the devs. Another thing, some guns are only acquirable by hiring crew with said gun, for exaple I wanted a silenced pistol so I could make the guards not detect me killing their comrades, I'd have to hire a new crew member with a silenced pistol to get it.(another thing you can't purchase from the black market). But I must say the black market and the ordering system is pretty good, you go on a phone order it, they drop off a box, destroy the box and you get what you ordered. The safehouse also had SO much potenital but with about 10 of the rooms only 4 of them actually have things of intrest (yes, they have NOTHING in them, not even a chair or a window).
Crashes a lot, other than that, worth like 2 $ (get it on sale or dont get it at all, 100 copies isnt worth 20$)
VEEEEERRRRYYYY FUN GAME

appDetails.name: The Masterplan
appDetails.detailed_description:
The Masterplan is an award-winning tactical squad-based heist game set in 1970s. The 2D top-down view gives you a great overview of what's happening at any given moment, allowing you to be a real criminal mastermind. Features hand-drawn 2D graphics and fun group control, granting you total control - at least until someone calls the cops and everything goes haywire.

During the game you'll need to heist your way through 20 unique hand-crafted heists in a persisting career mode, manage your crew from heist to heist by hiring the right goons and by making sure they are properly equipped. A test of a true mastermind will be to execute the plan to perfection, keep the goons alive, and walk away with the maximum loot from each heist.

Depending on your preference, you can hit your targets loud, or in stealth, or a mix of both. Keep the civilians under control, knock them out, or leave no witnesses. It's all up to you, just make sure you won't be there when the cops arrive - or be ready for a brutal firefight.

If you are hungry for more content on top of the campaign, you can test your mettle in the 8 challenge maps, built by the development team, available through Steam Workshop. And with Steam Workshop support, players can also create their own heists!

Key Features


  • Heist your target silently or go guns blazing - your choice (and your consequences)
  • Switch the game into Slow-Motion on demand, to give you time to plan and to give your orders
  • Control civilians and guards at gunpoint with the unique threaten system
  • Employ a variety of weaponry and gear, from pistols and bombs to shotguns and tranquilizer guns
  • Carry and hide bodies to avoid detection
  • Use disguises to infiltrate forbidden areas
  • Disable electrical systems
  • Manage your crew
  • Unlock and rob 20 unique heist locations, each allowing you to choose your own approach and play in a sandbox environment
  • Discover, plan, and execute the greatest heist in the history of mankind!
  • Access and create more heists and content via Steam Workshop

igdb.name: Cat Girl Without Salad: Amuse~Bouche
igdb.summary: Cat Girl Without Salad: Amuse-Bouche is the first taste of an exciting new game franchise by acclaimed developer WayForward (Shantae and the Pirate's Curse, DuckTales: Remastered). Follow Kebako, a cat-eared intergalactic bounty hunter, as she patrols the galaxies with her faithful companion (Squiddie) in search of ridiculous space criminals. The game combines classic shmup shooting with additional genres like puzzle, sports, arcade, platformer, rhythm, and RPG. Take on the galaxy's worst in a hilarious action shooter unlike anything you've ever played before!

igdb.name: Epistory
igdb.summary:
Epistory is an atmospheric adventure typing game that tells the story of a writer lacking inspiration who asks her muse to help write her latest book. 
 
In Epistory you play the muse, a fictional character in a world where everything is untold. Your adventure begins on a blank page, but the world will soon become larger and livelier as you gather inspiration, solve its mysteries and defeat its enemies. From movement to opening chests and fighting in epic battles, every element in the game is controlled exclusively with the keyboard. 
 
As you progress and explore the fantasy origami world, the story literally unfolds in the writer’s mind and the mysteries of the magic power of the words are revealed.

reviews.review: Enjoyable story, beautiful paper art style, immersive sound and music and most importantly I get to type away. LOL. This game give me all reason to buy mechanical keyboard and be statisfied typing endlessly while setting enemies on fire. The fox is so cool (and cute too). Besides, you can improve your typing skills in a FUN way! Even though I just can't seem to break the barrier of 30WPM speed. Long hours ahead!! XD
This game is beautiful. Fun to play and easy to follow.

Epistory is a unquie game that uses your typing skills to fight off insects through out the game. Athogh I didn't fully understand the storyline at the end I did enjoy playing it, overall I thinks it's a great game I just with that it had more of a difficulty curve as you progress throught the game. As you have difrent powers to use I wish that during battles it made you switch spending presoice time that you could be attacking, as the lightnigh and wind seemed a little overpowered, as I found myself using thoughts power up majority of the game as enemies can't touch you during battle. The artstyle is beutiful and would recomend anyone that enjoy typing games or looking to imrove on you typing as I feel faster at typing after playthrough the game once.

I usually don't write reviews but because reviews was what made me buy and try this out I am going to write one.
I was thinking a typing game wouldn't be anything for me but I was apperently wrong. 
The art in this game and gameplay really captured me.
The art was drawing my eye to it at first but when I saw typing game I was a bit skeptic.I read some reviews about it and decided to try it out anyway.
It ease you into the difficulty and the art is beautiful I recomend this I had a blast playing it.

This is a fairly quick game (I played the full game through, achieving all collectibles and defeating all the nests in 7 hours), but the art and story are wonderful and emotive. The music is atmospheric, and this game is worth it on aesthetic alone. The gameplay itself isn't great: the waves of enemies and typing is monotonous but not very hard.

Overall, I'd recommend this game on virtue of its story, but I'd suggest buying it on sale.

Trust me, buy the version that includes the soundtrack. You won't regret it.

I'm really enjoying this game. Lots of neat puzzles that take a little bit of doing without being "this is a puzzle game" level, a lot of room for strategy in element choice in fights. Absolutely gorgeous art, a really compelling and slightly mysterious storyline. Definitely a solid purchase at full price, and an absolutely mandatory purchase on sale.

My only issue, which might be an issue for you as well, is that if you're the kind of person who sees a list of words to type, and queues them up in your brain 5 or 6 deep to type in sequence, it will really mess you up to use fire attacks (also slowly gets rid of the next word in their queue) or spark attacks (zaps around to other enemies and takes one of their words off). I actually lost a fight a few times because I was two or three words into words that weren't on the screen anymore because a spark pulled them off.

A lovely game, with original mechanics, good histori, and please, did you see the graphics? Enyway, I really recomend, it´s a great game, challenging, but not extremly hard, that test your tipeing skills, and have some minor puzzels. Play it, you´ll not desapointed.
Surprisingly engrossing and immersive. If you're already a touch typist it makes things easier, but I'd guess it would be good to make learning more fun. Really enjoying this game!
Beautiful and geogerous story. Really enjoy it!
it is a  6 hour astounding experience

Found this gem amidst the pages of specials during steam sale and what a great finding, it's a story unfonding while advancing in the game. With plenty of places to explore and with a fun gameplay. Just started playing and been loving it so far!

I absolutely love Epistory. While I knew from the start that I would like its gameplay - I used touch typing learning software as games when I was younger - I was not expecting to get sucked into the story. The atmosphere was positively haunting, and I loved the cryptic voice-over. My only 'complaint' is I thought it could have been just a tad more difficult.

Good visuals.
Engaging typing gameplay.
Good story.

A typing game that follows not only an interesting narrative, but story as well. I won't spoil it, but the main mechanics of this game are simply typing. There's no bullshit in between that seems like filler in order to make the game longer, it gets down to the brass tacks of home row and tests your skills. Even if it is a little short, it stays consistently fun throughout!
Very fun, love the story.

Great game.  Inventive and enjoyable.  Great mechanics, I especially like the switching of powers using typed command during battles, added a certain tension as you had to switch power for enemies.  Storyline felt a bit contrived, but found myself getting into it as I went further.  Ending is possibly a slight letdown, but journey there is great.  Good atmosperic sound track also.

appDetails.name: Epistory - Typing Chronicles
appDetails.detailed_description:
Epistory is an atmospheric adventure typing game that tells the story of a writer lacking inspiration who asks her muse to help write her latest book.

In Epistory you play the muse, a fictional character in a world where everything is untold. Your adventure begins on a blank page, but the world will soon become larger and livelier as you gather inspiration, solve its mysteries and defeat its enemies. From movement to opening chests and fighting in epic battles, every element in the game is controlled exclusively with the keyboard.

As you progress and explore the fantasy origami world, the story literally unfolds in the writer’s mind and the mysteries of the magic power of the words are revealed.

Features


  • Explore a beautiful paper craft world: play as the muse riding a giant three tailed fox, lost in a fantasy 3D world
  • More than just typing: solve mysterious puzzles, unlock magic powers and defeat enemies in adrenaline pumping epic combats
  • A writer’s block? Collect fragments and inspirations points to unfold the story as you explore the origami world in the writer’s head. But there is more to the story than meets the eye…
  • All in keyboard: from movements, combats to even menus, control everything with a keyboard
  • Adaptive difficulty: if your hands fly around the keyboard or if you are a slow typist, the game features a dynamic difficulty system that evolves to fit each players’ skill set
  • Competitive Arena Mode: challenge other players for the top spot in the arena leaderboards
  • Play in your own language: game texts are localized in English, French, German, Spanish, Portuguese (Brazil), Russian, Polish with voice overs in English. The game supports several keyboard layouts (QWERTY, QWERTZ, AZERTY, BEPO, Dvorak, Workman and Colemak)

As you progress and explore this world, the story literally unfolds and the mysteries of the magic power of the words are revealed. It's an immersive, unique and exciting combination of both roleplaying and typing.

igdb.name: Tesla Effect: A Tex Murphy Adventure
igdb.summary: Tesla Effect: A Tex Murphy Adventure (developed under the working title Project Fedora) is the upcoming sixth game in the Tex Murphy series of detective adventure games, developed by Big Finish Games and published by Atlus. Like the previous three games, it will tell much of its story through live-action full-motion video sequences, and feature freely explorable 3D environments during gameplay.
igdb.storyline: Tex Murphy wakes up - disoriented and head pounding - on the fire escape outside his office atop the Ritz Hotel. Another typical morning for the last of the old-school detectives. Except it isn't. What starts out as the worst hangover in history becomes a baffling nightmare: something - or someone - has erased Tex's memory of the past seven years. Motivated by lost love, revenge and the world's strongest coffee blend, Tex must retrace his own steps into a maze of unsolved murders, hidden agendas and lost technologies of Nikola Tesla. Only by solving the mysteries of his past can Tex hope to regain his memory in time to restore what's been lost and stop a terrifying future.
