appDetails.name: Tesla Effect: A Tex Murphy Adventure
appDetails.detailed_description:
-Winner of Best Character from Adventuregamers.com as well as 10 of their Readers Choice awards including Best Story and Best Adventure of 2014.

Tex Murphy wakes up – disoriented and head pounding – on the fire escape outside his office atop the Ritz Hotel. Another typical morning for the last of the old-school detectives. Except it isn’t. What starts out as the worst hangover in history becomes a baffling nightmare: something – or someone – has erased Tex’s memory of the past seven years. Motivated by lost love, revenge and the world’s strongest coffee blend, Tex must retrace his own steps into a maze of unsolved murders, hidden agendas and lost technologies of Nikola Tesla. Only by solving the mysteries of his past can Tex hope to regain his memory in time to restore what’s been lost…and stop a terrifying future.

Tex Murphy will finally be back in 2014 after leaving loyal fans on a cliffhanger for almost 16 years, so come get acquainted in a world filled with dangerous dames, morally ambiguous characters, and lots of mysteries to be solved.

Tesla Effect upgrades the classic Tex Murphy experience with HD live-action -- that's right, for those of you not old enough to have played adventure games in the 90s, Tex Murphy embraces the lost art of green screen full-motion video as it interacts with fully modeled 3D environments. Players will be challenged with logic puzzles, interactive dialogue, branching storylines, and alternate endings.

Tesla Effect shines with an eclectic cast of actors, including:
• Todd Bridges (Willis from Diff'rent Strokes...ask someone older if you don't know what that is)
• June "TV's Greatest Mom" Lockhart (ask someone even older if you don't know who that is)
• Larry "Soup Nazi" Thomas (you all have seen Seinfeld, right?)
• Kevin "Tom Servo" Murphy (Mystery Science Theater 3000)
• The original Tex himself, Chris Jones
appDetails.about_the_game:
-Winner of Best Character from Adventuregamers.com as well as 10 of their Readers Choice awards including Best Story and Best Adventure of 2014.

Tex Murphy wakes up – disoriented and head pounding – on the fire escape outside his office atop the Ritz Hotel. Another typical morning for the last of the old-school detectives. Except it isn’t. What starts out as the worst hangover in history becomes a baffling nightmare: something – or someone – has erased Tex’s memory of the past seven years. Motivated by lost love, revenge and the world’s strongest coffee blend, Tex must retrace his own steps into a maze of unsolved murders, hidden agendas and lost technologies of Nikola Tesla. Only by solving the mysteries of his past can Tex hope to regain his memory in time to restore what’s been lost…and stop a terrifying future.

Tex Murphy will finally be back in 2014 after leaving loyal fans on a cliffhanger for almost 16 years, so come get acquainted in a world filled with dangerous dames, morally ambiguous characters, and lots of mysteries to be solved.

igdb.name: Mushroom 11
igdb.summary: An award-winning anti-platformer where destruction is the only way to move. Mold yourself into any form by destroying your cells, and traverse a devastated landscape filled with brain-twisting puzzles and bizarre mutations. Are you ready to break the mold?

reviews.review:
This is an incredible physics-based action puzzler. It's what I imagine you'd get if you crossed the Ecco the Dolphin game, with the World of Goo game with the Bladerunner movie, in terms of its combination of gameplay and atmosphere.

I was going to write a review earlier when I was at level 4, but I was reading some negative reviews saying it got too hard at later points, so I decided to finish all 7 levels to be thorough. I can honestly say the challenge level was not excessive at any point. Yes there were a handful of points that I was stuck on for a while, but isn't challenge part of the reason you play games? It is for me anyway. To be honest, I feel ripped off if nothing stumps me in a whole game. And I would say all of those moments were followed by an "Ohhh" revelation, usually me approaching the problem in a fundamentally wrong way, or not paying close enough attention to the mechanics of the movement.

It's a joy to "learn to walk" in this game. The resolution between figuring out the puzzle and making your organism carry your solution out is very satisfying -- SO many "Ohhh" moments! The visuals are flawless as is the soundtrack, the perfect ether to immerse you in the practical aspect of the mechanics and puzzles. I also feel like a 2nd play-through to 100% all the level collectibles/achievements would be just as fun (now I just need life to give me unlimited free time kthx... *cry*).

I don't get the time to play games often, but picking this game for the holidays was a great decision!

If you do play it, don't give up! Stay to experience the AMAZING CLIMAX :)

If you'd like a copy, I'll be giving away 5 free copies to the first 5 people who reply to this review!  Simply reply with "Mushrooms are delicious!" (or something expressing that you'd like to play the game), and I will friend you and gift it to you. (Please only people who didn't receive one of my previous giveaways.).

 Oh, check out DYE too, it rocks :)

I feel bad, but I am giving this game a mild "Not recommended" rating.  I feel bad because it is such an original concept and really is a good puzzle game... but it is so hard and very, very frustrating especially on the last 2-3 chapters.

In the game, you control an amobea / blob like creature.  You move by erasing part of yourself, which causes the remaining leftovers to grow in a somewhat random fashion.  Your creature can take on almost any shape, but getting how you want is not always so easy.  The goal of the game is to just reach the end of each chapter, of which there are 7.  Each level also ends with a boss, he being just another puzzle but where you need to somehow destroy him.  Things start out simple with you just needing to reach up to grab things and cross empty spaces.  By the end you will be pushing buttons, riding rockets, pushing balls and racing to make a bridge for them and many other complicated things.

This is all great but the levels are simply too long and many of the puzzles are too fiddly.  Since you grow in a somewhat random fashion, you can know what you want to do and still fail miserably at making your creature do it.  A few of the puzzles in particular will take the average player 10 to 20 attempts to complete them (you riding a rocket across a pool of acid for example).  If these difficult puzzles would have been reduced and the chapters been reduced in length, the game would have been fun and I would have recommended this.  Most players simply won't have the patience to get through to the end of the game, I almost gave up on it myself.  Those with lots of patience might want to try it out though if the concept looks intriguing, others should pass.

appDetails.name: Mushroom 11
appDetails.detailed_description:
Delete it and it will grow.
Mold an amorphous organism into any shape by pruning its cells. New cells will immediately grow, allowing you to traverse a mysterious world across brain-twisting obstacles, overcome swarms of bizarre mutated creatures, and understand the true nature of the devastation from which you emerged. The eerily beautiful visuals are complemented by the exquisite, ethereal soundtrack of British electronica legend The Future Sound of London, also available as DLC.

* Rock, Paper, Shotgun's Best Platformer of 2015
* IGN's List of Best Platformers and Most Innovative Games of 2015
* The Guardian's Top 25 Games of 2015

igdb.name: Dungeon Siege III
igdb.summary: Dungeon Siege III (DSIII or DS3) is an action role-playing game developed by Obsidian Entertainment and published by Square Enix for the PlayStation 3, Xbox 360 and Microsoft Windows.[5] Chris Taylor, the original creator of Dungeon Siege, served as an advisor during the development of the game. It is the third game in the series not to be developed by Gas Powered Games, (after Dungeon Siege: Legends of Aranna by Mad Doc Software and Dungeon Siege: Throne of Agony by SuperVillain Studios) and the first to be published by Square Enix after it acquired the complete ownership of the Dungeon Siege franchise. It was released on June 17, 2011. (wiki, 2014)
igdb.storyline: The game returns to the Kingdom of Ehb, which already featured as the setting of the first (but not second) game. Roughly 150 years after the events of Dungeon Siege, the 10th Legion, who provided stability and protection for the kingdom for 400 years, has almost completely been wiped out. 30 years before the game's setting, Jeyne Kassynder rallied the people of eastern Ehb and the Azunite Church against the Legion who she blamed for the death of the king (her father). Following a long and brutal campaign, she managed to kill the entire remnant of the Legion in a battle in the Rukkenvahl Forest and the royalist army of young Queen Roslyn has been driven deep into the mines of Glitterdelve, losing almost all of their power. (wiki, 2014)

alternative_names.name: ダンジョン シージ ３

esrb.synopsis: This is an action role-playing game in which players assume the role of a warrior battling to rebuild the royal army of a fallen empire. Players complete quests and use swords, ranged weapons, and magic spells to kill both human and supernatural enemies (e.g., skeletons, goblins, demons, giant wolves). Battles include hack-and-slash combat, highlighted by cries of pain and brief puffs of blood. During the course of the game, players can elect to spare or kill certain boss characters; if players choose the latter, the boss is depicted in a small pool of blood. Some female characters are depicted in the game wearing low-cut outfits that reveal moderate amounts of cleavage; the dialogue also contains some suggestive references (e.g., 'Your mother seduced Montbarron?' and 'We will seduce a foreign man, but only if he is strong . . . clever . . . handsome.'). The words 'whore,' 'damn,' and 'bastard' can be heard in dialogue.

pegi.synopsis:
The content of this game is suitable for persons aged 16 years and over only.
It contains: Realistic looking violence
This game allows the player to interact with other players ONLINE.

reviews.review:
If you are thinking of buying this hoping it would be a modern version of Dungeon Siege 1 or 2, please do not.  It is virtually NOTHING like the first 2 in the series and almost every aspect of the game is miserable.  The camera angles(2) are both absolutely terrible.  The controls feel like you are trying to use a console controller on a game that was designed for mouse and keyboard... even when using a mouse and keyboard.  The "stats" have little to know clear meaning or explaination... that being said it's impossible to know what gear is better.  The maps are VERY linear, magnified by the minimap which is basically a straight line that you follow.  Little to no customization of your characater relative to the previous versions of the game.

Long story short, do NOT buy this game, or the 3-game package.
So much promise of a great game, yet so much ruined.

Wow!  What a gem, I purchased this game a few years ago and had wanted to get to it, but hadn't made the time.  Having played the first and second one this one blew it out of the water.  It's not open world, but very flexible in terms of moral and action choices - think Mass Effect + early Fable, at the end you get a great montage of how your actions impacted the future of the game.  It was hard to believe how good the graphics are for a 7 year old game.  Look forward to next edition.

Only gripes are that they need a better inventory system (selling and identfying what is on whom is rough) and improve on the key mapping descriptions - Key 1 equals power 1 should become Key 1 equals what ever the contextual power you have set the slot too.

I don't really know what's up with all the bad reviews, but again I never played Dungeon Siege 1 or 2.
I like this game. It's like Diablo III, but way cheaper and you can use a gamepad.
Edit: I really don't know what all the fuss is about. This game is great.

appDetails.name: Dungeon Siege III
appDetails.detailed_description:
For centuries legionnaires have protected the nation of Ehb until they were betrayed and all but driven to the brink of extinction. Now that evil has returned to Ehb the people turn to the few remaining Legionnaires for the protection of the past. As an heir to the legion will you accept this plea for help? How it will all be resolved is up to you!
Dungeon Siege III is an Action RPG that seamlessly blends intuitive fast-paced gameplay, a robust RPG system featuring a large selection of abilities, loot galore and the depth of story Square-Enix and Obsidian Entertainment are known for creating. Players will be able to adventure by themselves, on the couch with friends, or online in a fully multiplayer experience.

igdb.name: Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas
igdb.summary:
A remasterd version of Oceanhorn from iOS. 
 
"You wake up and find a letter from your father. He is gone… The only lead is his old notebook and a mysterious necklace. What happened? 
 
Oceanhorn: Monster of Uncharted Seas combines captivating storytelling, breathtaking 3D visuals and exciting gameplay into one epic action-adventure experience. In the game you explore the islands of Uncharted Seas, a world filled with many dangers, puzzles and secrets. You must fight monsters, learn to use magic and discover ancient treasures, which will help you on your quest. Use all of your wits and skill to unravel the mysteries of the ancient kingdom of Arcadia and the sea monster, Oceanhorn."

pegi.synopsis:
The content of this game is suitable for persons aged 7 years and over only.

It contains: Non realistic looking violence towards fantasy characters - - Pictures or sounds likely to be scary to young children

reviews.review: The game freezes every few minutes. This problem persists since launch in 2015 and the developers don't seem to be interested in fixing it. I searched the steam forum for a solution but nobody knows why it happens for some people with different setups.
Closest thing I have found to that traditional Zelda feel that I love so much.

I can finally write a review for this game, now that I have unlocked all the achievements. The game is literally magnificent. I was one of the unlucky people who although was born in 90s, didn't have the chance to play a single Legend of Zelda game. This game looks and feels like one Zelda games but in with its own theme and world. I highly recommend this game to kids and adults as well. Really relaxing and good gameplay with joyful musics. I own it both on mobile and PC now but finished it on PC. I'm so happy to hear that there is a sequel coming up and hopefully a third one will also be made. 
However I have one tiny complaint. The fishing mechanics are really stale and not fun in my opinion. I had really hard time catching some of the fishes but finding them was even harder. Nonetheless, I went through the trouble and 100% this game. Don't miss this game out. Even the full price is worth for this game, you have my word.

igdb.name: Broforce
igdb.summary:
Broforce is an action platformer for PC about 80’s & 90’s action heroes making up the Broforce team, an under-funded vigilante paramilitary organization. The game features ridiculous violence, pixel art graphics and a fully destructible Vietnam setting. While masquerading as a run ‘n gun in the vein of Metal Slug, Broforce’s reactive environment encourages tactical play. Each bro out of the 13 the game currently features has distinctive overpowered attacks and special abilities, and mastering them all is one of Broforce’s core pleasures. Death is instant and can be surprising, but this is balanced by the incompetence of the enemy. Explosions are plentiful and very often result in chaotic chain reactions, but this shouldn’t discourage you from permanently holding down your trigger finger. Yelling “‘Murica!” while you do so is optional. 
Broforce is best played co-operatively, two to four players (though single player is an option). It can be played both on keyboard and on XBox controllers. 
Vehicular action sequences, dinosaurs, aliens and epic Contra-inspired boss fights, deathmatch arenas with leaderboards and rankings, a level editor, the ability to challenge friends and share custom levels, a customizable Brofort with unlockable rooms and much more to come in the full game. The only thing left to say is: brace your loins.

reviews.review: Can I get one uhhh... Broforce 2 please?

This game kicks butt on ubuntu linux, with fun gameplay, unlockables, and funny action movie parodies.
I imagine the couch co-op for this game is a lot of fun, but I have been playing the single player campaign for weeks. It's a blast. For me, it is a good challenge, but trying different approaches always pays off. Sometimes sneaky, sometimes rushing, and sometimes super careful. And, each retry uses totally random BROS, so you have to play with what you are dealt. It's such a good idea, because each BROS has totally different weapons and playstyles. It constantly keeps you on your toes.
The level designs are very clever, too. It is never boring, with deformable terrain, and dynamic map elements. Based on how I approach the level, I might find myself trying to dig up through a mountain, or making flying jumps into the air praying to see the ground when I land. Just like the movie Team America, this game delivers lots of laughs and lots of action, but just like that movie, you are only going to enjoy this in small doses. Thankfully, it's easy to pick up and come back to later.

appDetails.name: Broforce
appDetails.detailed_description:
When evil threatens the world, the world calls on Broforce - an under-funded, over-powered paramilitary organization dealing exclusively in excessive force. Brace your loins with up to four players to run ‘n’ gun as dozens of different bros and eliminate the opposing terrorist forces that threaten our way of life. Unleash scores of unique weapons and set off incredible chain reactions of fire, napalm, and limbs in the name of freedom.



  • The Broforce: Deliver your own brand of shock and awe with dozens of bros each with their own unique weaponry and special attacks designed to dispatch freedom across the world.
  • Bro-Op & Deathmatch: Battle terrorism with up to four players in cooperative mode or sever ties with your bros and face each other in several bombastic competitive modes.
  • Explosion Run: Join up with other bros to tackle these unique time attack levels under the pressure of exploding terrains and mass chaos.
  • Fully Destructible Everything: Destructible terrain opens up a slew of strategic options while the abundance of Exploding Red Barrels of Justice™ can literally level the playing field with one shot.
  • Level Editor: Design your own playground of destruction with a robust level editor and become the envy of all the other bros by sharing them online. Browse through scores of custom user created levels and complete them to rate their Bro-ness.

igdb.name: Campfire Cooking
igdb.summary: Campfire Cooking is a puzzle game about relaxing moments in nature, as you prepare meals over a warm fire. Follow a family's vacation to beautiful and exotic hiking trails. Listen to stories, toast marshmallows, simmer fondue or play with magnets until each meal is ready to eat.

reviews.review:
One of the best puzzle games you can get. The game looks gorgeous, and the sound mimics the camping experience. The controls are easy to learn, The puzzles have a nice complexity to them, ranging from easy to tricky, but once you figure out a puzzle you've been stuck on, it's incredibly satisfying. 

+ Having the option to play levels in any order you want is also nice.
+ Wonderful Graphics and atmosphere as well as simple concept.
+ Smart innovative ideas, and rich with +100 Levels.

appDetails.name: Campfire Cooking
appDetails.detailed_description:
Campfire Cooking is a puzzle game about relaxing moments in nature, as you prepare meals over a warm fire. Discover the joy of cooking on a stick and test your problem-solving skills with some challenging campfire puzzles! The latest creation from Layton Hawkes is guaranteed to make you feel clever, hungry and eager to book your next woodland escape.


Solve tricky puzzles with one simple goal; prepare the all the food, cooked to perfection and with a hint of smoke. When each meal is ready it's time to trek to the next campsite. But don't be fooled: these puzzles are no walk in the park, and some of them are a hike up the mountain!



A year long trip and a lot of marshmallows to toast. Follow a vacation like no other and listen to the campers as they tell stories, laugh at each other’s jokes or moan about the lack of cell phone reception. Enjoy the simple moments they share around the fire while waiting for their food to be cooked.



Twist, rotate and jostle skewers around the fire until each meal is ready to eat. Push fondue pots, play with magnets or maybe just use a camping stove if the fire won't light. Discover clever ways to solve puzzles at each new locale.



Once you've visited all the campsites on one trail, why not hike to another? Each trail brings you new vistas brimming with color, different foods to cook and fresh fireside stories to hear. Take a journey from the deep woodlands to snow-capped peaks, and everywhere in between.

appDetails.name: SPACECOM
appDetails.detailed_description:
Game Demo

Not sure if you'll like the game? Download our DEMO and try our Single Player campaign and our challenging Multiplayer mode!
Get the Steam DEMO now!


About the Game

SPACECOM – a strategic-to-the-bone, starfleet command game in which deception, smart movement, and choices to battle decide victory or defeat.

No coincidence, no luck. Spacecom pushes your ability to strategize with a focus on real-time tactics and planning. Use proven maneuvers learned from military legends or devise your own plans.

Test your wits in single player campaign, go head-to-head with up to 5 opponents in multiplayer or experiment with new strategies in AI skirmish mode. Most of all, you'll need a bright mind, cunning, and sound tactics.

When the war begins, leave the little things behind and dive into austere soundscapes as you immerse yourself in starfleet command. From now on, what matters is your grasp of tactics and strategy, not how fast you can click. Spacecom is about creativity in planning, not complexity of game mechanics.

Key Features


  • Single player campaign that will test your wit in diverse tactical puzzles
  • Tense multiplayer - dominate up to 5 players per map
  • No coincidence, no luck. What matters is good planning and successful execution
  • Sound designed specifically to trigger strategic thinking
  • Minimalistic visual design inspired by military technology
  • Created to exalt smart thinking over fast clicking

Previews


"In a market currently dominated by MOBAs, SPACECOM is set to offer a more nich perspective on strategy. Focused on concise combat roles and managing supply routes, it's all about using limited resources, to outwit your friends." - GameTrailers.com

"What really strikes me is that all of this is presented in an incredibly minimalistic style.(...) There is none of the distraction of flashy visual effects or incredibly renderedenvironments, this is pure strategy.(...) For me, an advocate of game mechanics above all else, this is as close to pure space strategy as I’ve seen and I’m really looking forward to the finished product." - gaminglives.com

"Spacecom is an interesting idea, as a quick-play strategy game. In a genre that tends to frighten off newcomers, Spacecom is poised to be the title that welcomes them in with open arms, avoiding complexity while still offering that classic 4X feeling. " - Criticallysane.com

appDetails.reviews:
“With Spacecom 11bit studios created perfectly working game mechanics which prove that you do not need elaborate animations to produce an immersive effect. I found Spacecom even more exciting and involving than most triple-A games recently. I would highly recommend it to all people who like good games.”
9/10 – IGN Deutschland

“Spacecom is simple, both graphically and mechanically—so simple it could almost be a board game. And yet despite—or rather, because of—this unassuming exterior, there's a lot of depth for you to explore within a limited space. That's the kind of strategy I like! It's like playing an actual game of chess where each piece has a very defined set of rules versus a weird game of pseudo-chess where each pawn functions slightly differently and you won't really understand the point of half of them until you're fifty hours in. We like to say "Graphics don't matter! Graphics don't matter!" Well, here's your proof. Just bring your imagination to the table, and there's a deeply satisfying strategy game waiting for you.”
4/5 – PC World

“Spacecom is exactly what I like. Challenging, smart, addictive, stimulating and yet not overloaded with unnecessary things. Flow Combine & 11 bit studios production represents the real meaning of strategy games and it’s essence. Every single fan of this genre, not only those with space theme, should check Spacecom.”
8,5/10 – http://gry.onet.pl/recenzje/spacecom-recenzja-male-jest-piekne-a-jakie-madre/pw3gd

igdb.name: Planetoid Pioneers
igdb.summary: Bring your game ideas and feedback to life with the Planetoid Pioneers Contributor Edition! With its powerful engine and integrated tools, join us in evolving the concept of Early Access. Don’t just tell us what you would like to see in this 2D physics-based action exploration game - SHOW us!

reviews.review:
Sorry but I've made up my mind. 

I will start by saying how I was a huge fan of Cortex Command (Data Realms' game prior). Just like Cortex Command, Planetoid Pioneers has the same key issues. Both games have a really awesome take on physics and pixel by pixel destruction. The core of both games is amazing... but that's just it. The games are just good core concepts. They're like the best building foundations you've ever seen, but they have shacks made of rotting wood on top. Both games are just empty sandboxes. Sandboxes which don't even run particularly well on any computer. You notice I keep using comparisons between both games because they're nearly the same. 

This game took great steps in its art style, music and physics but took 10 steps back everywhere else. There is NOTHING after the main "game". You spend a few hours playing through what was marketed as the game's story. You're a really old guy who crashes on a planet and has to get enough tech to build a new ship. This isn't like Terraria where the world is random and massive, no. It's all preset and static every time you play; It's just one world. There is literally nothing else in terms of story or progression, it just ends there. After completing "Primeoid" (the "main game"), you gain access to more worlds. Great! More story right!? WRONG. They're practically mini-games or tech demos showing what CAN be done with the engine and editor.

These planetoids take merely minutes to complete each. They include...

-A gamemode about "catching" flying aliens with a grappling hook and pulling them back to the mission start.

-An easier variant of that exact same gamemode mentioned above.

-A racing mode which isn't much of a race when you can't pass the AI. You can win just by letting the AI kill you so you spawn in front of them on each checkpoint, almost ensuring 1st place.

-An "arena" where you just watch workshop created creatures fight.

-A deathmatch mode which plays like a sad and broken Duck Game.

-Another tiny planet to complete like the main Primeoid.

-A small planet with seemingly no objective or way to complete it.

-A blank world for you to make your own scenario with the editor.

-A wave defense planet

-Lastly who knows, it's a miracle I remembered 9/10.

This game is another Cortex Command but even more limited and boring. You can't destroy the map, only entities. You can't customize anything, you're just told to make more stuff in the creator yourself by the devs. The final insult is that there's no fun here. Cortex Command you could have mindless fun watching the giant meat grinder of a war, people dying from outside elements, and it had some tactics if you tried. Planetoid Pioneers is just a straight static line. Every time you play the main game you just get bored and sad thinking of what the game COULD have been. With no online multiplayer there really is no reason to play. I'm not the tech-savvy person who wants to spend an hour drawing and LUA scripting my own stuff to enjoy a sandbox. They should have had this ready...

If that's not enough, I'll go on about the development cycle for this game and what I think is wrong here.

Data Realms wanted to do something new with Early Access games by letting players have access to the same editors to help make content before the games release. Now bluntly you think, "Wow! That's kind of cool and nice of them." Then you realise that they just wanted to have people do their work for them. They have no clue what their niche fan base wants. Ultimately the game's current setup reflects that, with the short "story" and the 10 minigames. 

They not only changed their Early Access in this sense, but they voided the purpose of Early Access entirely. They went dead silent for a good year + before the game's release. During this time, they were selling build 4 which is ancient. They had been updating the game left and right for a year without letting the player base see and help them improve. They come out of nowhere telling us, "Tah-dah! Here's a fully finished game!" Clearly, it's not. If people didn't notice, half the gamemodes have place holder descriptions marked- "TO DO" as a reminder among the devs.

Cortex command also did this; not with the whole Early Access issue, but falling off a cliff with it's development. They made the game 64bit in 2016 and doubled the FPS for a game that existed before "Early Access" was a thing on Steam. Even for that game they did the whole mini-game thing but it kind of worked because of the raw gameplay. The raw gameplay of Planetoid Pioneers DOES NOT carry it enough to be fun.

Keep in mind, this is the same team that has massive trust issues with the Steam community because of Cortex Command. They have Data himself defend the game in awkward videos on both store pages. They respond to every negative review and try to plead and scrap over each point with the author to make it positive. They just have bad PR overall. All advertising and events for this game are from years ago and honestly not a lot has changed comparing gameplay and entities then to now. It even looked empty and boring back then. To promote the game Data just streamed auto-fight bot matches on twitch with 0-2 people watching for days leading up to release. There is no charisma or passion here.

The final point, what they can do to fix it... Honestly, I'm not sure. I think it is a bad idea to let Data run everything 100% the way he wants. I mean no disrespect what so ever, and I think he's done well for a small team. I even love his work deep down, there's nothing like it. The big elephant in the room is management ultimately. He can't take the top 10 jobs in each project like he does. There's no one telling him what he should or shouldn't do like a producer or someone from a marketing team. They clearly don't plan ahead, tons of game changing updates were just added the last 3 days before launch according to their discord "updates" channel. If Data Realms wants to be successful, which I belive they can... They need to take a step back and develop concepts into full games from a gamer's perspective, not the lead designer, producer, marketing agent, and parent of their own game.

Unfortunately, this was a miss. Cortex Command is a better game despite being from a totally different era in gaming.
reviews.developer_response:
I've had several versions of responses up here, and after reconsidering (again), I've decided to replace all that and focus on the facts [i]only[/i]:

[h1]"Both Cortex Command and Planetoid Pioneers are nearly the same"[/h1]
The entire game designs, engines, and teams behind them are almost totally different. This is not Cortex Command.

[h1]"They went dead silent for a good year + before the game's release"[/h1]
See our [url=http://steamcommunity.com/games/300260/announcements/]update announcements from last year[/url] and prompt replies to every forum thread.

[h1]"There isn't enough content"[/h1] (paraphrased)
Here is [url=https://www.twitch.tv/videos/226966296]12 hours showing the amount of gameplay[/url] available on launch day. We were aiming for ten hours, as it's what seemed about right for an indie game at this price point - let alone one that comes with a full suite of editors and an endlessly expandable game design.

[h1]"I am generally not satisfied with this game at launch"[/h1] (paraphrased)
Our team worked hard for over eight years to bring this game to launch, and we are of course really bummed to see when someone isn't happy with the results of our efforts. We are eagerly listening to all constructive feedback and watching people play so we can improve the game and expand its content. Three days after launch we pushed out [b][url=http://steamcommunity.com/games/300260/announcements/detail/1658884035778198101]an update[/url][/b] with a long list of these improvements. It is the first update of many going forward.

To be clear, [b]I am not asking the author to change their review[/b] (although we would ofc be delighted if they eventually did). I am just asking everyone else to review this review with all the facts on the table.

Thank you,
- D

reviews.review:
Instead of wasting your time reading negative personal opinions do yourself a favor and google
"lets play planetoid pioneers" watch the videos of actual gameplay and then decide for yourself.

As for my own "personal views"?...

I spent 10$ for game only edition early access 
and honestly feel well worth the money invested price vs product
(as you can see this is simillar though obviously *NOT* cortex command.. apples/oranges..)
the bgm fits the atmosphere well and I personally enjoy the wonky ragdoll physics
I find it interesting in how with more blueprints fully discovered you find more intricate/complex solutions to puzzles/situations given
I see alot of player created content in workshop..though I myself am admittedly more player then creator (some rather talented individuals out there) as the same with cortex
I was quite suprized how quickly they addressed the bugs in early launch as the game runs smoothly on both my  laptop and desktop

I have spent 3 or even 4x the amount puchased and not enjoyed a game nearly as much
as Im quite anxious to see what its future brings...

Long time since I have had so much fun playing a game. It's a joy.
More and more content and planetoids coming all the time from the community.
And if you have contributor edition you can have much fun with the game editors.

Played now for almost 11 hours on steam version. Still have lots to discover on the first
planetoid.

There are multiple ways to solve things, since it's physics based, it's very dynamic.
Scan things- everything for blueprints. Make a backup body in case you die.
Believe me, you will multiple times. This is the only game that have made me laugh of my silly ways to die.

If you're on the fence on buying this. Watch some gameplays, to see if it's your type of game.

I will absolutely recommend this game.

This is one of those games that you start and just lose track of time because it's so pleasant to play. The soundtrack and art style are great, the enemies are strange and interesting, there are humor elements... and you actually feel that you are exploring an unknown planet. The way you have to craft your weapons as they wear out and how you can cut enemies and rip some limbs. Its really the core of the game, this amazing gameplay and crafting your way out of places. With the workshop tools released I'am hoping there will be even more planetoids to explore in the future.

Really fun game and the physics is spot on.

Basic crafting and resource collecting, but nothing hardcore so no real grind.

Just a lot of exploration and a lot of dying.

TL;DR worth it?: for fans of cortex command and anyone who wants to make levels/guns yeah sure! but for more casual gamers who just want a game experince im not sure, you may wish to hold off for more content(or get it now, and enjoy the content as it comes)


i have extremely mixed feelings on this game, but in the end i think its a good game and absolutly worth a look if the idea of creating levels, guns, and actors appeals to you.

theres not much i can really say that reviews like nameless's havent said (i partialy agree with his criticism of the game, not so much of the dev stuff) , but i beleive in the potential for this game. as of right now, you only get about an 8 hour main game and a handful of minigames, thats not very much i will agree. but the fact that the tools people would need to make any of these levels are available to everyone means that once content creators get into it there will be many more levels to play. but of course, the potential for content down the line does not excuse how little is in the base game because what if, gaben forbid, it fails to take off or get a solid group of creators? not to mention people like me who cant code/draw and can only make the most rudimentary use of the editor getting to the end of the current content and going "thats all?" and suddenly the wind is taken from my sails. 

but, like i said, i believe in the potential here as the base itself is very solid and super fun, as the time i had on primoid can attest to. once the devs finish up the "todo" planets in the system and add some more big planets(as they have mentioned they plan to) and the community gains steam the game will be in a much better state.
Fun Game. Very clever engine. Pixel destruction is fun.

This is first and foremost a sandbox game. The actual "game" content of this product will take you 4-5 hours to beat, at which point you're basically done with all the core content.

If it had good controls and was a good platformer, this would be fine. But it's really not. It's a wobbly-man shuffle down a hallway firing blindly into the darkness simulator.

Frankly dissapointing, but what can you expect from the Cortex Command people? I blame myself more than them. I was 100% aware of their previous work and didn't look for an indepth review before purchasing.

I can't envision this project going anywhere,

Brand new physics engine appears to be recycled and modified behaviour from CC objects.

In it's current state, gameplay is virtually non existent. The gameplay that does exist is not overly entertaining.

Imagine the physics puzzles in half life 2, kinda neat for the first playthrough or two.
Now imagine if half life 2 was primarily physics puzzles, one would get sick of them quickly. 

Couple that with extremely linear level design where one has to cover significant distances using a movement system equivalent to that in CC and you have a really uninteresting, dead end prototype.

Speculation at this point, but considering that we already have workshop support before any kind of fleshed out gameplay one might suggest that the developers are banking on the community to produce majority of the content. 


Would not recommend purchasing at this point. Wait and see if it's going to end up being a game, and then wait a bit more just in case they device to slap a "finished" sticker on it.

Cortex Command-y enough to love it.

+rep

ggwp, Data Realms. I love you xoxo

It seemed like it had some potential, but it needs some serious TLC.

The physics system is robust, but your character is intimately tied to it. Simply walking forward is a frustrating experience. You get caught up on minute bumps in the soil. God help you if there's actually a rock in the way.

Also, lots of random hitching and frame loss. Given the simple nature of the graphics in the game, my assumption is this is caused by the physics engine. You don't even have to be doing anything very interesting (in fact, I experienced this while trying to perform the arduous task of walking forward over flat-ish ground). I think maybe it was caught up trying to simulate stuff in the planet I can't see? Who knows.

I might give this another look in a year to see if it's improved at all. If they could deal with the framerate issues and make the basic character controls more responsive and predictable, I feel like there'd be something fun here.

After purchasing the Game Only version of this game I was a little confused about the whole thing. I wasn't sure if what I purchased was the full game and it didn't feel to me like the game was polished enough. So I got a refund. The very next day I seen the contributor edition was on sale. I figured after some more looking at gameplay videos that I would give it one more try. Man I am glad I felt better about getting the whole game and giving it one more chance. I have to say Planetoid is that fun funny goofy clumsy shooting flying breaking things game I thought it was. The fact that there is FREE mods that are pretty interesting already out now. I emphasis free because I don't feel like mods should be lock behind a pay wall but I do like the idea of donating. It seems to me like the perfect game for steam workshop. I have to say give the game a chance to grow on you and I believe you wont be disappointed. This is one of those game in which the more people who play the more people there are creating mods for it. I absolutely recommend this game.

I played this game and honestly could not continue. First of all the player willconstantly move and every command is delayed. I love the concept of the game but the gameplay is honestly unbearable. After at least 4 hours of playing and it saving a checkpoint I come back to it and the data is no longer there. Hopefully I can get my money back because in its current state, I am very disapointed.

The fact that they took this out of early access to a version called "Release Version 0" and the loading screen (which is where about 7 of my 9 minutes playtime were spent) includes the note "Work in Progress" is a joke. This game is not anywhere near finished and no one should be buying it expecting an complete game.

Once it loaded my character got stuck within 2 minutes of me fumbling around with no tutorial - and then the game crashed when I tried to bring up the menu to figure out what I was supposed to be doing. I bought this expecting them to have cleaned up what they started with Cortex Command and what I found instead was another unstable, half finished game with clunky controls.

I have refunded the game.

Pretty bare bones with the developer depending on the community to make up for the lack of content and then charging extra for the community to buy the "contributor edition" to make that content.  Even worse is that the terrain is indestructible which is a downgrade from cortex command.
reviews.developer_response:
Hey,

So the "Contributor Edition" is actually more of a Deluxe version. Anyone who purchases any version of the game will get Access to the in-game Editors. Tons of people have spent hours creating their own content for the game, not for us but just for their own enjoyment.We get creating your own items doesn't interest everyone, I would suggest you give it a try. 

We're continuing to work on Content for the game, as well as fix feedback that the community is giving.

reviews.review:
I haven't had such a riveting experience in a game for a long time. I bought the game on a whim after seeing a demonstration and I played 11 hours straight!

Planetoid Pioneers is a deliberately clunky action platformer with crafting elements and a detailed physics engine.
The awkward movements of your character are part of the challenge you have to overcome, although it's nowhere near as frustrating as e.g. QWOP. Even though the planetoid you are on seems small, there is tons of stuff hidden throughout and you can explore whichever path you feel like, provided you find a way there.
There are lots of different types of equipment to find and scan, which you can replicate on the fly with your matter printer if you have the necessary resources. Those range from lots of different weapons and explosives to grappling hooks, jet packs, vehicles, building constructs and other sort of equipment which have to be used to face the challenge of going from A to B.

And the whole experience is just a ballpit of fun!

I know of the other game they made - Cortex Command - which features a similiar strange style of movement and physic simulation ... but whate made CC frustrating (I only played a very early version many years ago) is fun in PP.

Also, there is a mighty editor for community content inside, in case the numerous planetoids are not enough - which present not only different levels but also wildly different game modes like PvP, horde mode, Racing and solo adventures.

However, it is also quite obvious that the game is not quite ready for a full release - placeholder text, the level editor is directly usuable in the main game, no graphic settings, tanking framerates, long loading times (especially the very first start), wonky full screen mode ... I expect this from early access titles and not from release versions.

Nevertheless, I had an absolute blast in my first 11 hours despite all this and that's saying something.

Recommended!
reviews.developer_response:
Aroddo, thank you so much for letting us know we are on the right track, and what we have to focus on right now - we just put live a nice update with lots of fixes from the first wave of feedback and observed problems. The editor crash bug is gone, and you can use it on the biggest Planetoids!

We're also making a resolution setting and addressing the load times and perf dips here and there.. I hope you'll see some massive improvements going forward!

Thanks again for letting us know how much you liked the gameplay - it gives a huge boost in morale!

reviews.review: I love physics simulation in games, and this game has the best physics around. A huge improvement has been made since the developers previous game. Simply watching your character walk on uneven terrain is impressive here, as nothing is a straight animation, and everything is simulated. Fans of games like Terraria should check this out.

I loved Cortex Command, I have around 40 hours in it at least just doing one man army, I love this game too. Alot of people try to draw lines of comparison between the two games, and there are certainly some to be drawn, but not nearly as many as people do. Both this game and cortex command weigh heavily on community modding to provide content, while the developer provides the engine and tools for that content to made easily and enjoyed. This worked great for cortex command despite its many flaws, it works well for this game too. Core gameplay content made by the developers is an enjoyable 7-8 hour survival mission on a large planetoid, which is honestly enough on its own for a 15$ game. But the game has more content beyond that, not much right now, just a few minigames and a small touch of community content, but I am certain that with time it will grow just like cortex command.

The auto-injected workshop feature is actually very cool, and the versus mode is really fun because of it. Who knows what weapon my friends and I will have to learn on the fly how to use in order to win. Just like cortex command the game draws its fun from the pure hectic nature of its gameplay, and its amazing.

TL:DR The game is very fun as is and offers a campaign which is worth the money in my opinion, and also shows great promise for more content created by the community and the developers both.

A really fun game. It has interesting physics and its an origanal idea which is hard to come by these days in gaming. I like how you can drag PNG files into the game and it creates stuff. Only downsides is the physics need some work so people do not get stuck as often and maybe more saving progress with blueprints sicne it is tedious to get them every time I am on a new plantoid. Online multiplayer would make this game ALOT more fun because there could be online pvp, story coop, sandbox, etc.
constantly crashes when in coop
reviews.developer_response: Really sorry about that - we are rolling out an update this weekend that we believe fixes the coop crash issue! Stay tuned to the announcement page ~

appDetails.name: Planetoid Pioneers
appDetails.detailed_description:
Welcome to Planetoid Pioneers, a cooperative sci-fi Physicsvania where kooky old astronauts fall over themselves with QWOP-like action to explore the Asteroid Belt beyond Mars. It’s been built on the unique Crush2D physics engine and can be played on your couch with or against your friends in seamless pick-up-and-play Co-Op and PvP action.

You’ll trip over rocks, lose limbs and get your stuff stolen while fleeing from terrifying enemies that make you forget you’re walking right into the next trap. Come up with alternate creative solutions to the challenges thrown at you, or get your hands dirty and build some of your own Planetoids in the editors that are now all included in the standard edition, too. Laugh while others attempt to survive your carefully constructed carnage!


If you choose to purchase the Contributor Edition today, you will also get access to the official Contributor Community Discord server, where you can collaborate and share content with creatively-minded people, and also chat directly with the developers.

appDetails.short_description: Explore deep circular worlds in this Physicsvania with couch Co-Op combat, crafting, and ridiculous physics fails! Also bring your own game ideas to life with the powerful engine and integrated game development tools. Each Planetoid is a whole separate game mode that you can fully edit and easily share!

igdb.name: Titan Souls
igdb.summary: Between our world and the world beyond lie the Titan Souls, the spiritual source and sum of all living things. Now scattered amongst the ruins and guarded by the idle titans charged with their care, a solitary hero armed with but a single arrow is once again assembling shards of the Titan Soul in a quest for truth and power.
igdb.storyline: Titan Souls tells the story of a nameless warrior’s quest to bring down the ancient titans with nothing but a single, indestructible arrow. There are no lesser classes of enemies, no crafting, no grinding and no side quests -- just you and the two dozen titans scattered throughout the land awaiting your challenge.

reviews.review:
do you like to die

over and over again




perfect

Shadow Of The Colossus in 2D! This is a very excellent and extremely hard bossrush action-adventure game. Gameplay is very simple, you just walk/roll around to the bosslairs, there are no powerups or skills or any other game mechanics that you would expect in a pseudo-RPG. Each boss has a unique pattern and way to kill. Basically you have to hit the boss at its weak spot (sometimes after disabling some of its moves) with your only weapon, the bow and arrow. I HIGHLY recommend this game!

PREPARE TO DIE A LOT!!! :D

Played this a long time ago when it first released. Never payed.
Paying now that I see it on Steam and have funds, you deserve it. Fantastic game.

I love this game.

At least, I love the first section of the game.

Titan Souls is a boss rush style game that seems to take some inspiriation from the Souls series of games as well as Shado Of Colosus. The problem is the latter inspiration. The first four bosses you fight are nice and close together so if you get tired of trying to fight one you can just run over to the next and give that one a shot and eventually when you beat those four the next section opens up. This is where we run into problems. The second part of the game is a large expansive map more akin to a LoZ game where there is a substantial amount of distance between the boss locations, and no means of quickly traveling between them. 

So now if you get tired of one boss and want to give another a shot, you have to travel back to where you were and then roam around looking for a new boss to fight in a large area with NO map to guide you along.

This got very tiring very quickly.

So, this is the game people were saying difficult, 
19 bosses 4 hrs 45 mins 255 death, in other word i hate [b]Titan Souls[/b], but it's a good suggestion for people who want to experience something close to Dark Souls, good luck

Game play - Fun,Like dark soul.
Graphic - Hey if you like pixel you like this just saying.
Price - Better buy it on sale.

This game is very fun if you are skillful, for you only have one arrow and "1 shot".Smart concept almost if its shadow of the colossus but instead its on a budget cut.Hey for the price in which i got it its worth it.However, I did not proclaim i ever finish the game - Cause I SUCCCCCCK.I would like to see this game combine with the survival aspect of DST then i think we'll see some pretty sick game which i still gonna be sh** at.

Amazing game. Nice pixel art. Thrilling bosses.

However having to walk to the boss area every time you die is just unbearable. I liked the game a lot, but because of that I can't stand playing it for more than 30 min straight. Why can't the player just respawn where he just died ? It's not like there's something to be done to get there other than simply walking and seeing the same scenario over and over. Sometimes a boss can kill me in less than 10 sec and I too can one shot bosses sometimes in few seconds, so I definitely spend more time walking than really fighting against the bosses in this game.

It's not like I'm complaing about the essence of the game or something that would change it entirely. Why wouldn't the devs make such a simple and obvious change to the respawn system ?

appDetails.name: Titan Souls
appDetails.detailed_description:
Between our world and the world beyond lie the Titan Souls, the spiritual source and sum of all living things. Now scattered amongst the ruins and guarded by the idle titans charged with their care, a solitary hero armed with but a single arrow is once again assembling shards of the Titan Soul in a quest for truth and power.

Colossal Titans: Explore the ancient ruins of your forefathers and uncover extraordinary and unique titans, each with their own savage attacks and hidden weakness. Find and exploit their faults to slay the beasts and consume the primeval power that lies within them.

Simple Combat: Loose your solitary arrow at the monstrous titans and summon it back to your hand to unleash another forceful strike. Dash and run from the titan’s attacks but do not fear death, as it is both inevitable and plentiful in Titan Souls.

Arcane Secrets: This realm is not without its secrets. Long forgotten titans are hidden in the shadows and prowling through the furthest corners of the land – find them, destroy them, and take their souls for your own to discover the true extent of the power that resides here.

Titan Souls | Digital Special Edition

The Titan Souls Digital Special Edition includes a digital artbook, world map, full original soundtrack and desktop backgrounds. All files can be found in the game's folder on your hard drive.

igdb.name: Grim Fandango Remastered
igdb.summary:
Something's rotten in the land of the dead, and you're being played for a sucker. Meet Manny Calavera, travel agent at the Department of Death. He sells luxury packages to souls on their four-year journey to eternal rest. But there's trouble in paradise. Help Manny untangle himself from a conspiracy that threatens his very salvation. 
 
One of the most acclaimed adventure games of all time is now back, better than ever. Grim Fandango's epic story of four years in the life (or death) of Manny Calavera, travel agent to the dead, has been remastered to look, sound, and control even better than when it won GameSpot's Game of the Year award upon its original launch. Grim Fandango still stands as a classic of the genre, with unforgettable characters and unique combination of film noir and Mexican folklore.

reviews.review: "You can't hide from the Grim Reaper. Especially when he's got a gun." ~Manuel Calavera
This is my favorite point and click games, if you haven't played it yet... I don't know what you're waiting for!

Grim Fandango is a game that, at the peak of the era of classic adventure games, stood as a high mark of the genre. It is one of the best and most beloved Lucasarts titles, as well as one of the last adventure games the company developed. Grim Fandango's film noir story, reminiscent in tone to noire classics such as The Maltese Falcon, is peppered with dark humor and superbly written. Combined with the game's aztec and art deco inspired visual design, and latin and jazz influenced musical score, it created a truly unique and exceptional atmosphere compared to other adventure titles of the 90's.

PROS
+ Wonderful and unique atmosphere and visual design
+ Dark, film noir narrative, often heartfelt, with plenty of witty and charming humor
+ Good length for an adventure game, and satisfying to play to its conclusion
+ Superb writing, dialogue and narrative still hold up for the most part, marred by a couple cringy lines
+ Excellent voice acting
+ Soundtrack is one of the best in the adventure genre. Evocative and beautiful, it perfectly fits the atmosphere and has been totally remastered using a live orchestra
+ Improved controls - use a mouse, controller, or the original keyboard only tank controls (there is even an achievement for playing through it the way it was originally designed)
+ Runs well on PC, as it should, did not encounter any bugs
+ Improved aspect ratio, now able to choose 16:9 stretched, or the original 4:3
+ Higher resolution character and 3d models
+ Improved real-time lighting and shadows
+ Enhanced cutscenes, movies look good considering the age of this game
+ Developer commentary added, can be funny at times
+ Achievements added

CONS:
- Prerendered backgrounds are unfortunately not remastered, look no different to the original
- Dialogue has not been enhanced or improved, and some static can be heard in a few lines
- Ability to switch between original and remastered mode is nothing but a curiosity, redundant, and not worth playing the game that way
- Outdated and often illogical puzzle design
- The archaic gameplay may be frustrating to some

Grim Fandango Remastered can not, if we are being honest with ourselves, be called a complete remaster. Had the backgrounds been completely redone, or the dialogue cleaned up in a few places, this would be a different story. As it is, the remaster feels more like a touch-up of a beloved classic, albeit a damn good one. It stays faithful to the original - the humor still works, the strength of the original voice acting still shines, the game is still steeped in that lovely film noir atmosphere and is a blast to replay for someone who grew up in that golden age, the 90's. Despite the few flaws this remaster has, it is still the best way to experience the high point of a gaming era which has, sadly, long gone by. Get it on sale, or for full price if you're an old school fan, worth it for the nostalgia alone.

FINAL VERDICT: 8/10

Highly  reccomended, as stated it's a point & click classic that was made by the gaming comedy legend Double Fine.
You're a skeleton agent in the corrupt purgatory in a buisness that sells transportation tickets to get to other layers of the underworld. Your character got jealous that only his partner gets premium users (practically saints) so he steals a job from him and goes off to harvest the newly dead, and this little jealousy leads you down to the ends of the world through fire beavers to gigant pure gold statues of cats with plenty of jokes along the way.

Grim Fandango was my first point-and-click adventure game, and it certainly won't be my last. This is a great introduction to the genre, as it can easily be played without a walkthrough and isn't . The characters aren't dried-out and saturated, even the antagonists, and have interesting interactions with one another. The story is great, as you are a salesman trying to save a women, solving puzzles and overcoming obstacles to find her. I would highly recommend this game to those that want to start playing point-and-click adventure games or those that already enjoy the genre.
Great game. Classic
Was extremely happy to find this on steam, I never got a chance to finish it "back in the day"

Seriously, the most original game I've ever played. The art-style, the "film-noir" setting, the dialogue, the story, the puzzles, everything about this game is on fucking point. The only downside is that some of the puzzles are fucking hard.

If you want to chill out, but still have a small challenge, a good game with with humor and a story, Grim Fandango is the perfect match, such a fucking good game.

This game crashes on the second level, and you cannot get past it, so I cannot play the vast majority of this game. I asked Steam for a refund and they refused my request, despite finding many others online with the same issue, and no resolution to the issue available.

On the other hand, I really did enjoy the part of the game that was playable, and if the whole game worked (and was as fun as the start), this would be a great value!

But as it stands, you're pretty much making a donation to Steam by buying this, and I'm pretty sure you can't deduct that donation on your taxes.

igdb.name: Tharsis
igdb.summary:
Tharsis is a turn-based space strategy game. With dice. And cannibalism. It puts you in control of humanity’s first manned mission to Mars, just as it’s struck by a micrometeoroid storm. You must guide your crew through disasters, food shortages, and the unforgiving nature of space — all while maintaining your sanity amidst cryptic signals and warnings from Mars.

Defy the odds, make the difficult decisions, and embark on the most important mission in human history.
igdb.storyline:
A mysterious signal originating from the Tharsis region of Mars set us on a frantic mission. Who sent it? And why? Impossible questions, but in them lie the key to humanity’s survival.

Now, millions of miles away from home, a micrometeoroid storm has left us with a severely damaged ship, two deceased crew, and the sneaking suspicion this trip was doomed from the start.

pegi.synopsis:
The content of this game is suitable for persons aged 12 years and over only.
It contains: Mild bad language

reviews.review: The dice rolling algorithm is not random; it is clearly devised to roll select dice corresponding to difficulty level.  By implementing it this way you are basically forcing players to watch an interactive movie; lacking any 'real' choices.  This is what makes this game extremely boring.  All of a sudden rolling 4 1's when you get ahead in the game; when 1's are the exact roll needed to screw you over.  This type of thing happens over and over again. It is clear that the programming was devised to force constant replays of the game.  Fire that person please, as this 'idea' made this game less optional than a 'choose you own adventure' book and boring AS ****.  This is the first game I've ever purchased that I asked for a refund.
This game is quite an original concept which is why I am recommending it. It is what it says on the box though and it isn't a AAA title. But for $15 it's a reasonable price. Try it out.

Yet another wonderful indie gem. If you like survival games, this is for you... if you like to struggle A LOT!
It took me 4 playthroughs to actually beat the Easy difficulty. The crew needs to survive for a set amount of 'turns' to finish. Besides the plethora of crises that will try to kill you, you also have to keep your crew's health and mental state in good condition. Just from the few playthroughs I can see several different ways to play this game which gives it some kind of replayability. I can recommend this one; it is definitely going on my favourites list.

From the 'only' mostly positive reviews and people complaining about randomness and difficulty,Iexpected this to be a rather nice game for people seeking challenge in tactical strategy or something. Deemed the bad reviews to be from people not that ambitioned, strategicaly only average and frustrated by difficulty only.

In hindsight, the game does no provide enough content to justify the price. Unlocked nearly everything after a few hours of gameplay, managed to finish the game after just maybe 4 tries. It is too easy, player keeps repeating mostly the same basic combinatorical calculations before commencing his turn. Only reason for loosing is the considerable randomness, which can result in prolonged piling up dice-deficit or sustained damage received to vessel, crew or dice.

Keeping available dice for all crewmembers at max is key to victory. This can be hardened or postponed by bad luck (imminent vessel destruction or crewdeaths), which will force you postponing dice reaquisition. Having accidents or large fires in not-so-relevant-modules will worsen your situation futher, while having an accident at medical bay, food-reporoduction or maintaneance bay will give you the chance to invest unspent dicerolls into healing, foodaquisition or shiprepairs after you have solved whatever catastrophe there was (each crew can move somewhere once each turn and try solving/repairing the accident in that module).
Procedure (simplified):
1. Move to module
2. Roll dice and use for repairs
3. Spend leftover dice on module special function(foodgain/healing/shiprepairs/...) or crewmans special ability
(4.) Do above steps with the best suited crewmember (if someone needs health, he should put out the fire in medbay, so he can heal himself after the problem is solved). Also consider the order of acting crewmembers.

Basically thats the gist of the game. There are a few more things there, like Challenges and stuff, but not really worth mentioning.
The game is really nicely made with a great concept and well executed programming. I never expected using dice mechanisms on such a kind of game would result in such a good game. It probably gave me the best 4 hours of gameplay in months, but thats it. Dont really see much worth in investing more time to play the game, just to repeat over and over what I had been doing for the last 5-7 hours.
Too bad, the game looked really promising.

For 6€ (if that is pocket change for you), I would really recommend it - just because it is a rare concept and well made non-average experience. But 15€ is really overpriced for the first game that Im willing to deinstall after just a few hours of easy gameplay. The game is something worth having seen or played once, but doesnt offer much long-term motivation.

I dont want to be misunderstood here:
Playing the game is really easy. Determining the optimum and best course and orders of actons to take is easy to moderate. Sometimes you make mistakes because you get lazy thinking it through, but other than those its not that hard to determine what the optimum next steps are each turn. You only loose because of randomness, not because it was too hard to find what to best click next.
I hoped the game was hard and brutal, requiring a lot from the player to compensate against the odds in dire situations - but its just the opposite... determining the optimum course of actions is way too easy and sadly even trying to think 10 times harder wouldnt give you any other or better course of action. Noone can improve the easily found optimum course of action, no matter what he did.

Best compare the gamepaly to a button game:
You may press one of three buttons: 1.button triggers certain death, 2.button has very bad 10% chance of surviving, 3.button obviously has a 25% chance to win.
Determining which button to press is easy to moderatly difficult. Pressing the button is ultraeasy. Having any influence of wether button 3 wins or looses the game is nearly impossible.

Tharsis is similar to above described game. Very interesting to find out how the game works. Easy to determine how to best play it. Game too easy, outcome mainly only depends on accidental randomness. Would be good if more depended on the player or the game was a bit more complex (probably even harder to balance then).
Aiming to unlock the additional characters keeps you going for a while, which in combination with its uniqueness is probably the motivation why I enjoyed the game so much during the first few hours. Now Ive seen everything and there is not much more to see or enjoy.
Deinstalling it probably later this evening (maybe Ill play it once or twice more).

Even though it was fun, 15€ is way too much for just a few fun hours.

not very much content, about 20 mins real gameplay for a playthrough
there is no story or 'flavor'
it's a super easy puzzle based on dice

igdb.name: Battlesloths
igdb.summary:
Battlesloths is the fast-paced local multiplayer competitive twin-stick shooter of your slothy dreams. Compete with up to 4 human players or play against AI sloths should you be short of friends. Use a myriad of weaponry, each with their own strategies, to destroy your enemies in a quest to collect the most pizza.

With 12 unique weapons, 7 game modes, customizable battle settings, team vs. options, free for all, a nuke and more hats than you can fit on 50 sloths heads; you’ll have plenty to do as you train to become the ultimate gun-toting, hoverboarding, pizza eating sloth on the block! Revel in the silliness of the slothpacalypse, shoot everything that moves and start hoarding pizza!

igdb.name: Infinifactory
igdb.summary:
Infinifactory is a sandbox puzzle game by Zachtronics, the creators of SpaceChem and Infiniminer. Build factories that assemble products for your alien overlords, and try not to die in the process. 
 
LIKE SPACECHEM… IN 3D! Design and run factories in a first-person, fully 3D environment. 
HISTOGRAMS ARE BACK! Optimize your solutions, and then optimize them more when you see how much better your friends did. 
VISIT EXOTIC ALIEN LOCALES! Explore a story-driven campaign with 30+ puzzles, audio logs, and more. 
BLOCKS THAT MOVE! Go beyond the campaign and push the limits of Infinifactory’s next-generation block engine in the sandbox. 
STEAM WORKSHOP INTEGRATION! Create, share, and play custom puzzles on Steam Workshop.

pegi.synopsis:
The content of this game is suitable for persons aged 12 years and over only.
It contains: Mild bad language

reviews.review:
ladies and gentlemen. presenting the successor to the game that inspired minecraft. T.H.E. voxel-game codifier. this game will make you feel so smart one moment, incredibly stupid the next, make you ragequit in frustration, only to come back and FINALLY finish that stupid thing you wanted to fix!... and then ragequit again when something stupid goes wrong for seemingly no reason whatsoever...

this is a great way to get into Zachtronics puzzle games without needing an electronics or programming background.
Only people with a very high IQ can play this game. I suggest you watch Rick and Morty first.

Zachtronics creates games that ask the player to build a solution to solve a problem. I like these types of games and have written good reviews on a few Zachtronic games. I really want to write a good review of Infinifactory but I can't. 

My problem with this game is while it is okay to make something have to think to come up with a solution, there is such a thing as making it too hard to figure out. Right from the first training puzzle, the thing I felt was missing that was not the case in other Zachtronic games was the needed components to construct the solution. Shenzhen IO, TIS/100 and SpaceChem always had enough of the basic elements -- motion, a grabber, and a switch -- to complete the problem. With infinifactory, the grabber -- which in this case would be a clamp -- was missing and it was sorely needed on the third training puzzle where I had to weld a vertical two-block stack, then move the union to the transporter. There was simply no way to join two falling objects at different altitudes into a union and then at command move the union to the transporter. I spent a total of 2 and a half hours on that one puzzle before finally giving up and uninstalling.

When something becomes too hard to do, it stops being enjoyable. Infinifactory made the learning curve much too steep at the beginning and I truly feel it should have followed a more shallow incline demonstrated in the other games.
Please let me skip the intro and the tutorial and anything else I'm going to be forced to endure mindlessly...

igdb.name: Screencheat
igdb.summary:
Screencheat is a chaotic split-screen multiplayer shooter that forces players to rethink the way they approach conventional multiplayer games. In the Screencheat arena, fast reaction times aren’t enough to keep you alive. When everyone is invisible, players will have to master the art of taking a not-so sneaky look at their opponent’s screens and working out where they are based on uniquely coloured areas of the map and distinctive landmarks.

Screencheat pays homage to iconic competitive first-person shooters such as Goldeneye, Perfect Dark and Halo, by blending the elements everyone loves about those games and shaking it up with its own unique take on the genre. When everyone’s used to playing by the rules, can you adapt to unconventional gaming quick enough to get the upper hand?

reviews.review: Piece of shit game lol

appDetails.name: Screencheat
appDetails.detailed_description:
Full Controller Support

Screencheat has full Steam Controller support including supporting multiple controllers to use touchpad mouse aiming.

Other controllers supported include Xbox 360, Xbox One, PS3 and PS4 controllers.


About the Game

Screencheat is the ridiculous split-screen shooter where everyone is invisible so you have to “screencheat” (Screencheat - verb: to look at your opponent’s screens. “Stop screencheating you cheater!”). Master a wide variety of one-hit kill weapons including a blunderbuss, a car engine that shoots bouncing plasma balls and a teddy bear loaded with explosives. Train your skills in the solo time trials then engage in fast and frantic combat with up to eight players locally on the couch or online. With colourful maps, unique modes and a huge number of customisation options including wacky mutators, Screencheat is the ultimate party FPS.


Ranging from the dependable Blunderbuss to the heroic Hobby Horse to the completely crazy Chefolet; a car engine that fires ricocheting energy balls, all are designed to deliver deadly satisfaction. Each weapon comes with its own unique advantages and disadvantages, encouraging wildly different play styles. These include not only the way a weapon shoots but also the 'tells' the weapon leaves such as the smoke from the blunderbuss or the trail of fire behind the Hobby Horse.


From traditional favourites such as Deathmatch to the completely unique Murder Mystery that challenges you to find and frag your specific target with a specific weapon. Play in teams or all against all. Challenge up to seven of your mates on the couch or online or a combination of both, the game is always split screen whether you are on or offline. When your friends aren't around, train your skills and learn the maps in the solo time trials or play against AI bots.


In the spirit of the best arena shooters you’ll spend time traversing 11 maps via air vents and trampolines until you’ve acquired your target and fragged them accordingly. Each map is designed with colour-coded areas as well as plentiful landmarks such as statues, paintings and furniture that allow you to quickly locate other players without being able to actually see them.


Inspired by games like Towerfall we've provided players with a highly granular level of customisation to play the game the way they want to. Choose which weapons you'll allow, how and when they can be swapped or reloaded, apply time limits, adjust the victory conditions, penalties and more. To really mix it up stack on some Mutators such as slow mode, low gravity or flappy jump.

Train your skills in the solo time trials then engage in fast and frantic combat with up to eight players locally on the couch or online. With colourful maps, unique modes and a huge number of customisation options including wacky mutators, Screencheat is the ultimate party FPS.


Ranging from the dependable Blunderbuss to the heroic Hobby Horse to the completely crazy Chefolet; a car engine that fires ricocheting energy balls, all are designed to deliver deadly satisfaction. Each weapon comes with its own unique advantages and disadvantages, encouraging wildly different play styles. These include not only the way a weapon shoots but also the 'tells' the weapon leaves such as the smoke from the blunderbuss or the trail of fire behind the Hobby Horse.


From traditional favourites such as Deathmatch to the completely unique Murder Mystery that challenges you to find and frag your specific target with a specific weapon. Play in teams or all against all. Challenge up to seven of your mates on the couch or online or a combination of both, the game is always split screen whether you are on or offline. When your friends aren't around, train your skills and learn the maps in the solo time trials or play against AI bots.


In the spirit of the best arena shooters you’ll spend time traversing 11 maps via air vents and trampolines until you’ve acquired your target and fragged them accordingly. Each map is designed with colour-coded areas as well as plentiful landmarks such as statues, paintings and furniture that allow you to quickly locate other players without being able to actually see them.


Inspired by games like Towerfall we've provided players with a highly granular level of customisation to play the game the way they want to. Choose which weapons you'll allow, how and when they can be swapped or reloaded, apply time limits, adjust the victory conditions, penalties and more. To really mix it up stack on some Mutators such as slow mode, low gravity or flappy jump.
appDetails.short_description: Screencheat is a ridiculous competitive split-screen first-person shooter where everyone is invisible, so players are forced to look at each other’s screens in order to win. Supporting both local and online multiplayer, combat in Screencheat is fast and furious with a wide variety of one-hit kill weapons.
