reviews.review: Incredible. One of those games that just sucks you into its beautiful, calm, peaceful world and makes you wish y ou were a bird. Buy it!

appDetails.name: Copoka
appDetails.detailed_description:
Copoka is an open-world exploratory indie game about a bird building its nest in a totalitarian city state. As a player, you are soaring free, high above the city of Copoka, as a contrast to the citizens below. Your goal is to find and collect twigs for your nest, and as you construct your home piece by piece a story of intrigue and politics beneath around you.

Key Features

  • Take wing and enjoy the freedom of flight
  • Experience a city boiling with strife and political turmoil
  • Eavesdrop on conversations to get the full story of the city

Story

The city of Copoka is in distress. Speakers all around the city proclaim the glory of the Great Leader and how she will bring salvation to a country in need, while people lament in the streets about starvation and dissatisfaction. Something is brewing in the back alleys of the slums. Whispers in the wind tell about a coming uprising, about an end to the suffering and new hope for the citizens of Copoka. Being a bird you can undertake the role of silent observer. By listening to people around the city a more nuanced picture of the brewing conflict is revealed - a conflict concerning clashing ideologies regardless of social standing or allegiance.

Of course, it’s up to you if you wish to stop and listen. After all, what are human concerns to a bird anyway?

Experience the mysterious vibe of each of carefully explored locations, solve diverse puzzles, make fateful decisions and discuss intriguing matters to find out the whole truth being kept from you.

igdb.name: JumpJet Rex
igdb.summary:
JumpJet Rex is a punishing, old school 2-D platformer where players take control of a Tyrannosaurus Rex with extraterrestrial jump boots to save dino-kind from extinction by a giant asteroid.

As Rex, players will jump, drop and dash through more than 40 challenging levels and race against the clock to not only preserve life during the Mesozoic era, but also prove their platforming prowess against other dino enthusiasts.

Players can explore the galaxy and unlock new worlds alone or team up with a friend in co-op mode, where players will need to coordinate movements to get past challenges.

reviews.review: u can play with freind!!

appDetails.name: JumpJet Rex
appDetails.detailed_description:
Retro Platformer Flare
JumpJet Rex features beautiful hand-drawn 16-bit graphics and classic chiptune music that transfers dino lovers back to the 2-D glory days of the early 90’s.

Secrets and Collectibles
With dozens of items stashed across the Galaxy, and many secret areas to discover, JumpJet Rex offers plenty to do for the treasure hunters in the house!

Replayability
With a time challenge twist, players can replay every level multiple times to prove their platforming prowess. Download ghosts to race against the best players in the world, or compete directly with your friends to see who can post the best times!

Killer Old School Gameplay
Remember when platformers were so tough that people would hurt their hands playing, but feel amazing after getting past a level? Relive those moments with JumpJet Rex’s strenuous platforming challenges and retro boss battles.

Co-op Mode
Saving all of dinokind from a giant asteroid barreling down on Earth is a pretty tall task for a T-Rex with tiny arms, so players can team up with a friend to take on challenges. Teammates must coordinate efforts in order to avoid mass obliteration.

Customization and Upgrades
No two T-Rex’s are alike and fans will be able to customize their character and upgrade their appearance with the loot they collect on their travels.

Simply put, you're a t-rex with rocket boots trying to save earth from an incoming asteroid.  Do you have what it takes to stop it?  Jump, drop and dash your way through over 40+ levels via story, multiplayer arena & party, co-op and speedrun modes.  Be the dinonaut you always knew you were.

igdb.name: Tailwind: Prologue
igdb.summary: You are the last survivor of an alien invasion that has all but destroyed your homeworld. Barely escaping the atmosphere in your ship, the Keravnós, you realize you don’t have enough fuel to survive. You are going to die. Well, if this is your time, you might as well spend it doing what you do best: aerial ballet! Rain from the heavens as a bolt of lightning in one final blaze of glory.

igdb.name: Limbo
igdb.summary: Limbo is a black and white puzzle-platforming adventure. Play the role of a young boy traveling through an eerie and treacherous world in an attempt to discover the fate of his sister. Limbo's design is an example of gaming as an art form. Short and sweet, doesn't overstay its welcome. Puzzles are challenging and fun, not illogical and frustrating.

pegi.synopsis: The content of this game is suitable for persons aged 18 years and over only. It contains: Extreme violence.

reviews.review:
[b][u]-OVERALL:[/u][/b]                            5.5/10
  

Limbo is not that great... If the art concept doesnt grab your attention there is basically nothing going for limbo, forget about any satisfying gameplay sensation or pleasing of the ears with a sweet soundtrack... It's all simple concept puzzles yet it's quite easy to get confused and to never see the solution even though once you get it, it seems so basic. Again if the art style doesnt fascinate you, limbo is a cold , dark and empty game.

[b][u]-GAMEPLAY:[/u][/b]                           4/10

This the worst aspect of limbo, the game is slow, unresponsive and reduced to bare bones controls: move, jump, activate. Puzzles are simple and hard at the same time, most of the time you'll get the right solution straight away but unless you get the perfect timing you'll start to search for solutions the game doesnt provide. It's die and retry 101, and there's no two way to go about solving a puzzle.

[b][u]-LEVEL DESIGN:[/u][/b]                        5/10
 
Go right, sometimes walkback to the left, then go right and jump over a pit. 90% of the game is basic washed up 2D platformer level design mechanics, it start to get good when the games ends sadly, when the gravity comes into play in order to solve the last few puzzles.

[b][u]-VISUAL & ART:[/u][/b]                        7/10
   
This is Limbo's best effort, a dark and coldly portrayed nightmare world. This is the real "50 shades of grey", the visual concept brings some good, some bad. This the anti Mario game, no colors , no fun but it's intentional. It's a lonely and painful journey for the game's character but it can turn the same for the player. Yeah it's an artistic choice but this doesn't make for a particularly enjoyable game.

[b][u]-SOUND & MUSIC:[/u][/b]                       5/10

Again it's a design choice to make the world feel cold and the character lonely but this ends ups being so bare bones that there's barely anything to rate in this domain ! It's a coherent atmosphere but as most of anything in this game it surely can leave you indifferent.

[b][u]-REPLAYABILITY:[/u][/b]                       3/10

3/10 because I doubt you'll ever play through this game more than 3 times.
It's a special kind of a game... Scared the shit out of me multiple times...

Limbo will always be the base of reminder for any new games with similar style as this. Just like when INSIDE came out, I was immediately reminded of LIMBO. And any other games that look like this, I always bring up LIMBO and am reminded of LIMBO. The aesthetics of this game was so unique to me when I first saw it, and that was years ago when I didn't even have steam yet. I watched so many different gameplays of this when it first came out because it was just that exciting and intriguing and unique. It definitely opened up a path for a new genre of games and I'm very happy it did. I already know how the game goes but I still bought it anyways because I wanted to support the company because they deserve it.
Very short (about 3 hours), didn't enjoy the atmosphere at all.

The experience of this game really sticks with you. I remember playing this game back when it came out, and I never really got around to finishing it. However, when I picked it back up again, I was able to vividly recall many of the impactful moments and devilish puzzles this game contains. Its bleak and lonely aesthetic really makes an impression.

The puzzles in this game definitely have a bit of a difficulty curve. I would also argue that a lot of the puzzle-related elements that are introduced later in the game are a detriment to its immersion. I started to feel a little bit disconnected from the world and found myself playing a run-of-the-mill puzzle game. Another issue is in the controls. The boy doesn't handle nearly as smoothly as he ought to for a game containing puzzles that require some level of precision. Many times did I have to repeat a simple puzzle because the boy grabbed onto something or jumped errantly to his own death.

I can forgive the shortcomings of this game mostly because of its length. If you're focused and are able to figure out puzzles easily, it's a 2-3 hour game. It's really short, moderately sweet, and immensely impactful for a 2D puzzle-platformer.

Meh. It wasn't bad. But it is far, FAR inferior to its successor, Inside, which I can't say enough good things about. I was able to solve all the puzzles without cheating, but many of them were counter-intuitive and required split second timing. There were times when I died like 50 times trying to hit a key at just the right moment and my twitch skills are pretty good. If you enjoy Film Noir lighting and repetitive death, then you might like it. If your into interesting concept games with minimalist artwork, I would recommend Kentucky Route Zero instead.

Do completely disregard all the negative reviews that are attatched to this masterpiece, as they've all been crafted by close-minded and dull individuals.

With glossy eyes and bones as breakable as glass, you'll travel through the haunting atmosphere and across the hellish landscape that makes LIMBO. Armed with nothing but your own wit, you'll be faced with daring puzzles and heart-thrashing encounters. 

Those intelligent enough to find and smash the secret "eggs" scattered throughout the game shall be rewarded greatly.
A masterpiece

igdb.name: Crawl
igdb.summary: Crawl is the local multiplayer dungeon crawler where your friends control the monsters! It’s bullet-hell beat-em-up meets old-school RPG, in an arcadey party-game for up to 4 players. One player is the hero, exploring a randomly generated dungeon full of traps and monsters - all controlled by the other players. If you slay the hero you take their place and it’s your turn to crawl! Then it's a race to gain enough XP and loot to reach the final battle, where it's all on one as the other players collectively control the hulking final boss!

I bought this on sale. What a mistake: these devs deserve every dollar of the full price! This is an exeedingly unique, well-crafted, and replayable game. Of course it does require some local playmates, but you knew that. I love how it acts as a 'one-stick' game, so a player can play with just a keyboard, and another with just a mouse! The only problem I can think of is that the game seems to be balanced for three players. If there are two players, the living human will have a moderate advantage. igdb.name: Kentucky Route Zero
igdb.summary:
Kentucky Route Zero is a magical realist adventure game about a secret highway in the caves beneath Kentucky, and the mysterious folks who travel it. Gameplay is inspired by point-and-click adventure games (like the classic Monkey Island or King's Quest series, or more recently Telltale's Walking Dead series), but focused on characterization, atmosphere and storytelling rather than clever puzzles or challenges of skill. 
 
The game is developed by Cardboard Computer (Jake Elliott and Tamas Kemenczy). The game's soundtrack features an original electronic score by Ben Babbitt along with a suite of old hymns & bluegrass standards recorded by The Bedquilt Ramblers.

reviews.review:
Great art, sound and atmosphere, but not much else other then a colossal waste of your time.  

Like many bad plays written by fourth rate playwrights put on in small production houses, this falls flat for the same reasons.  The writing is non-sensical and just bad with no point.  And the game is just writing.  It tries to take a page from other 'remote surrealist' type settings without really capturing any of the magic, wonder, enjoyment, or anything positive.  The games it gets compared to are amazing (Dear Esther, Gone Home, Stanley Parable, etc).  This is not.  The writing spirals and spirals never amounting to anything worth reading except for random disjointed meaningless facts.  If there was an interesting narrative, something worth exploring.  Even something funny.  Hell, then maybe this could have been saved.  But there is just nothing.  This is an exploration of nothing.  It is an exploration of how much can you waste someones time and have them still think there was anything of substance because they don't want to admit there was absolutely nothing in front of them.  
This is the type of thing that gives indie art a bad name because a vacuous empty headed moron headed a project and no one had the right mindset to tell them they were terrible.  Then the worst part is people put in good reviews, comparing it to actual games that are art, that have concept, that have life only because they didn't get it, maybe they were just too stoned to have noticed what was in front of them.  Either way, do not waste your time on this garbage.  It is not art.  It is a really, really bad script with some nice visuals.

Worst game I've ever played--by a significant margin. I saw lots of recommendations for this game and while playing it I just kept waiting for some 'Aha!' moment. It never came. I wish I could get back the time I wasted on this trash. Go to your nearest bus stop and listen to a homeless man ramble about nonsense. That would be a better use of your time and money compared to playing this game.

appDetails.name: Kentucky Route Zero
appDetails.detailed_description:
Kentucky Route Zero is a magical realist adventure game about a secret highway in the caves beneath Kentucky, and the mysterious folks who travel it.

The game is developed by Cardboard Computer (Jake Elliott, Tamas Kemenczy, and Ben Babbitt), and features an original electronic score by Ben Babbitt along with a suite of old hymns & bluegrass standards recorded by The Bedquilt Ramblers.

The game is split into five acts. Acts I, II, III, and IV are available now. The remaining act will be released when it's completed. Taken as a whole, Kentucky Route Zero is roughly the length of a summer night.

Key Features

  • A focus on characterization, atmosphere and storytelling rather than clever puzzles or challenges of skill.
  • A unique art treatment inspired by theatrical set design.
  • A haunting score accompanies the ambient sounds of the bluegrass state.
  • Wander the highways of Kentucky.
  • Make some friends before morning.

appDetails.reviews:
"Smart, thoughtful, sweet and incredibly well crafted – it’s the perfect game to play in the small hours of a lonely night. Be warned though; it’ll leave you hungry for unknown roads and longing for an invitation to the blues."
Rock, Paper, Shotgun

"Evokes the feeling of old ghost stories told around a campfire. There's the familiarity of friends and family around a warm, man-made fire, but with it comes the unnerving tale of the strange and unusual. Kentucky Route Zero is beautifully bizarre and perfectly poignant, and most of all, deserves your attention."

9.5 - Destructoid

"However you respond to its ethereal imagery, this is a game which makes a rare suggestion: who a player is may be more important than what they do."

84/100 - PC Gamer

igdb.name: Satellite Reign
igdb.summary:
Satellite Reign is a real-time, class-based strategy game. You control a team of four agents, each with distinct and unique abilities, collectively battling for control of a simulated, living cyberpunk city. 
 
Customise your team with the strength to destroy your enemies head-on, or hack into their facilities to manipulate their infrastructure without them ever knowing you were even there. 
 
Will you take down your enemies with brute-force? Covert espionage and infiltration? Or will you use propaganda to influence the citizens of the city and overthrow the controlling powers? 
 
The world's governments are controlled by mega-corporations, democracy to the highest bidder. Society is structured for the benefit of those in power. The poor exist in the dark squalid underbelly of the city, while the wealthy swim in opulence and luxury on the upper tiers, and the vast middle-class are too comfortable with their lives of convenience to see the world for what it really is. Corporate police patrol the streets, brutally maintaining the status quo, all under the guise of keeping the people safe. The time for change is now, as a mysterious organisation rises from the slums of the city. They'll have to bribe, steal, hack, kill and augment their way through the barriers between them and their ultimate goal...but what are they trying to achieve? To free the masses from the corporate stranglehold, or to take control for themselves? That, is up to you.
igdb.storyline: Satellite Reign takes place in an unnamed fictional city referred as "The City" where a corporation named Dracogenics rises after releasing a prototype for Immortality named Resurrection-Tech however Dracogenics turns to Corporate crime and bribes politicians with Immortality for control and influence eventually leading to the privatisation of The City's services and full corporate control over The City's Police Force. Civil unrest arises and is suppressed by Dracogenics but a rival corporation soon comes to light and launches anti Dracogenics attacks. The Player controls this Rival Corporation and must overthrow Dracogenics from The City.

reviews.review:
Great concept.  I recommend if you can get past the following.  Nice successor to the Syndicate series.

The game designer forgot that many of us already have a job and get to be frustrated there.  I don't want to be frustrated by a game.  It should be fun.  You can't save mid mission.  1 simple bad click will cause a massive firefight which will kill all of your men.  Then you can start all over again, turning off all the security cameras, sneaking all over the place, then make 1 bad click (for example, you accidentally use the move function on a security camera resulting in your men opening fire on it) and your cover is blown 20 minutes into the mission.  Start over and over and over.  That kind of gameplay went out in the 90's.

Some of us just want entertainment, not a job.

Good game if you like this genre. My biggest gripe is that it is built on a poorly optimized unity engine though i will admit 7/10 unity engine games run like crap and this one is no exception. Other then that I've enjoyed my time with this game. Currently beat it once back 2016 and reinstalled it recently, time to beat it again in ironman mode.

The game play itself and feel is like an RTS shadowrun, same cyberpunkish theme neon bling and futuristic feel to weapons and skills. Had a story that i honestly don't remeber lol. That was 2 years ago when last played it though, so forgive me for that. Getting old memory isn't like it used to be. 

Personally, i think the game itself not counting unity engine (i really dislike unity engine games). Despite the engine it's a fun & good game. I remeber passing out while playing it a few times, because I liked playing it. Any game I pass out in while playing not related to bordum is a pretty good in my opinion.

So bottomline if you like RTS games and like smaller squad size (4 here normally 12 if you count hackers drones and 5 hijacked enemies). With cyberpunk theme and rpg elements then give it a go. Pick it up on sale and sink a few 50 or so hrs in. Remeber i passed out a few times, im pretty sure i didn't sink 100 hrs my 1st play through maybe 50-60 actually playing it I could be wrong i don't remeber precisly.

This could have been a really good, possibly great game. But there are significant bugs in the UI and game sync. Playing coop with a friend could have been a fantastic, strategic experience but with characters wandering randomly around and disappearing, only to appear to actually have run right in to the camera, turret, guard makes for a very frustrating experience.

Giving actions to your characters has no feedback, which combined with the sync issues, means that a lot of the time you're just hoping your squad is doing what you want.

I was very very dissapointed. Especially because I really liked the game at the begining. What stared as a very interesting and promissing game turned out to be a huge waste of time mixed with frustration and anger. 

There are 2 games I bumped into in the recent time and both looked very promising - RUINER and Satellite Reign. RUINER costs 19,99€ and SR 27,99€. So, since I played RUINER and loved it I expected a fun worh almost 50% more than RUINER. Well... not this time I guess, but let's not haste.

Why to compare these two games? 
1) They are both cyberpunk genre
2) They both have same isometric graphcs gameplay (Satellite Reign allows small rotation, but it's not enough)
3) They both promised a great fun in their promo videos/picture with similar gameplay
4) They both are "low cost" and came from relatively unkown publishers (in contrast to giants such as CD Projekt Red,  Bethesda or EA or any other market leading game studios)
5) Similary complex game control during the play
6) Although SR is presented as open-world, the city and levels are actully locked - same as in RUINER.

Ok, so what is my opinion on Satellite Reign:

PROS:
+ amazing graphics. Really (with exception of that stupid camera movemet which I had to turn off from the very start), the level of details is simply incredible and although  sometimes the environment looks similar there is always something more. I loved it. It was better than RUINER imho. Although I think they played a little bit more with shaders in RUINER, some effects look better there.

CONS:
- unable to save during missions. Without checkpoints or anything. You have to simply get through it and succeed or waste another 2 - 4 hours going through the same area (level) again. Time waste per level rises as you progress more in to the game where the levels become bigger and enemies tougher. (I call "level" any area where they start to shoot at you on sight).

After some frustration I read the forum, hoped to find some quick save feature. None. The only "excuse" (presumably from developers/marketing) I found was , that it would be hard to implement... 

Really? come on people! At least let the killed enemies be killed and don't respawn more, or divide levels into certain areas based on patrol patterns and once the area is clear, allow people to save game or stop respawning more patrols, or create special designated points inside the level where it would be possible to save progress. I doubt it is hard to save the state of hacked terminals, destroyed/disabled cameras and power supplies, state of doors (closed/open),... - unless, of course you developed a terrible game/engine architecture. Sorry, but "too hard to implement" is not an excuse here. Especially for a game which costed me about 50% more than epic RUINER. What about your beta testers? Didn't they complained? Did they actually get through the game? What I saw in forum is that many people are frustrated due to this. 

- glitches.  I almost finished a level in industrial section and when I ordered my crew to hide near a fence one of them remained stuck behind it and I could not get him out. After 3 hours of play where I cannot save anything, because it is "hard to implement" I had to load the starting position. The more I progressed in the game, the more frequent they become.

- Repetitive music. It seems to me that music is always same, especially when I am inside a level. I did not noticed its' change in different sections (downtown/industrial/...) either. Really ? (50% more than RUINER for this? really?)

- Repetitive level solution. It's hard to be creative with so many enemies around, especially in the begining of the game where your team is weak. You had to find a place where you can destory your enemies one by one to survive (unless you have 12 hours time to waste to keep respawning with your team and do the level over and over again). Once you find this pattern, you tend to stick with it, because it works and it is a small substitute for lack of save (especially when you get the skill to heal your team and research armor wich repairs itself). Only one time I used intruder (number 4) and its' cloak ability to get through the whole level without anybody else, but again - If I should do this all the time (because certainly I could)  why bother to develop other members? Result is that it started to be boring soon. (50% more than RUINER for this? really?)

Overall result is:
Do not buy this game. It's not worth 27.99. If RUINER is for 19,99 I would rate this to max 14 Euro. Not more. Even that is too much given all the problems the game has. And I'm especially sad because it looked so cool at first sight.
Ugh I really wanted to like this game. But my hacker glitched during the freaking tutorial and could no longer move.

The devs certainly put a lot of work on this game but I think it was not enough to make it worth that work. It's not a complete waste of time but it's not a good game. A lot of UI glitches and flaws make the game very frustrating to play if you  ever try a more tactical approach. Unfortunely, the only way I could have fun with this game was by blasting my way in to every objective. Like I said, not a waste of time, lots of fun to have there, but it could have been so much better. It's pretty decent visually. Explosions, laser guns, the environment. Everything looks as it should with a lot of attention to detail. Nothing to complain about this. Story is pretty cool too. The way the story is told is pretty clever. Although you almost never interact with NPCs the game characters are very well developed. This is one of those games that could have been a classic but seems like it was released too soon. A shame.

Character stuck in wall in the first 4 minutes of the tutorial.

Tried many times to get into it, but meh, shitty controls (the alt button let you "force" orders (like USING SLIDING ROPES) AND to change weapons (if you know their number in an arbitrary and non visible list). The tutorial teach you to click all over the menus (an absolute mess with nice colors). The story seems really cliche but the atmosphere is good.
The game is so slow (not in terms of FPS).

Just fucking hate it, and I don't know why I keep coming back once a year to try it out again and again. Just love the setting. Hate the gameplay.

appDetails.name: Satellite Reign
appDetails.detailed_description:
Deluxe Edition


Contains the game, original soundtrack, 'Satellite Reign: Reboot' e-book and 'The Art of Satellite Reign' e-book.

Co-Op Multiplayer

Play the entirety of Satellite Reign with your friends in co-op multiplayer. Up to four players can each control their own agent, opening up a whole new level of strategic and co-ordinated play.

With full drop-in/drop-out support, LAN and Internet play, and customisable agent assignment, get ready to experience Satellite Reign like never before.

Strategic Cyberpunk Action


Satellite Reign is a real-time, class-based strategy game, set in an open-world cyberpunk city. You command a group of 4 agents through rain-soaked, neon-lit streets, where the law is the will of mega-corporations. Use your agents to sneak, shoot, steal, and sabotage your way up the corporate ladder, and take control of the most powerful monopoly of all time.

Each of your agents can be tailored toward your favoured play-style, while still maintaining their own unique specialisations. Shape your team into an offensive war machine, or an elite covert spec-ops outfit, and take the open-world city as your own.

Open World

The city of Satellite Reign is one big, open playground. No individual levels to pick between, the whole world can be explored seamlessly. Uncover new missions while you explore, and pick and choose which objectives you want to tackle.

Customise your Team

Each of your four agents can be tailored to suit your play style. Choose their skills, weapons, gear, augmentations, and even their genetic base by cloning exceptional individuals from the general population.

Multiple Strategies

There's no 'right-way' to complete your objectives. The world has been designed to facilitate emergent gameplay, allowing you to choose from and combine a wide range of strategic options. Sneak in through ventilation shafts, hack doors, take out power generators, hijack the minds of guards, or just blow the front door down. Countless opportunities await.

igdb.name: Steredenn
igdb.summary:
Steredenn is a frenetic and chaotic space shooter, carved in big beautiful pixels, with insane boss battles. Embark in your ship and engage the fight against dreadful space pirates in a never-ending combat for your survival.

Steredenn is at the crossroads between a shmup and a rogue-like. Enjoy the infinite replayability of the game with its unforgiving gameplay, intense boss fights, (almost) randomly generated environments, twisted space events and a surprisingly large arsenal of weapons. Enhance your ship during your flight with many upgrades and forge your own path across the universe!

reviews.review:
This is a great rouge-like shmup, with [b]beautiful, BIG pixels.[/b] You can't go wrong with this one!

[b] I appreciate the Linux support[/b], game runs great on my 'buntu machine, and recognizes my logitech controller flawlessly.

Steredenn is at the crossroads between a shmup and a rogue-like.   • Beautiful art and spaceships.
  • Awesome boss fights.
  • Addictive, ruthless.
  • Endless arcade gameplay.
  • Quick and intense sessions.
  • INFINITE REPLAYABILITY: levels are (practically) randomly-generated.
  • ARSENAL: 35 weapons and 25 upgrades with many interactions and combos.

  • DAILY RUN: everyday, try to be the first in a special leaderboard where all players share the same run, guns and bosses. Beware, you only get one chance per day!
  • ARENA: Unlock a boss by defeating it in the normal mode. Then, train against it in a 1 to 1 duel. Your guns, your laws, your fight.

Devblog: http://steredenn-game.tumblr.com

igdb.name: Hand of Fate
igdb.summary: Inspired by tarot and fantasy, all bets are off as you create your own journey by building a collection of cards used to deal out a boardgame-like dungeon teeming with enemies, treasure, and adventure. Upon entering combat, the cards come to life as the player is propelled into a beautiful 3D environment to brawl it out with foes. Draw your cards, play your hand, and discover your fate.

pegi.synopsis:
The content of this game is suitable for persons aged 16 years and over only.
It contains: Realistic looking violence

reviews.review: Bought this game because it was on sale and WOW what a gem. Not only is the combat system very well employed but the mechanics of the card system work really well. I'd give this game a solid 8.5/10 great job devs i look forward to more content in the future!
This game made me enjoy playing games again. A++ 12/10 would buy again.

More action/combat game than a card/roguelike game. I've expected a bit different game but still I liked it (playthrough of story mode took 10 hours for me). I've still didn't unlock all of cards but I'm looking for to do it in next couple days exploring Endless Mode.

For now, if you can get this game at discount, I can recommend it but you really need to know that it's more combat game than a card game (I mentioned it in the beginning).

Graphics/audio are on fine level, don't really expect much from a game of that type. Encounters are interesting, story (well if you can call it a story) is developed quite good.

In conclusion I can recommend this game, I think every person who like cards/action game would be pleased.

I give this game solid [b]7/10[/b] for now. Maybe I'll update this review after I play some Endless Mode.
I recommend this game.

Man, this game is a dream of a lazy table-topper. There's an automatic dungeon master right in front of you, and you are set for new adventure in a matter of seconds! Great game for table-top rpg wanna-players

I thought I would get bored quickly since the goal is to play several "matches" to beat each boss. However, it was not the case since the new cards that are continuously earned keeps the game interesting and not really repetitive.

Actually, the only issue I had with the game was the final boss who is ridiculously overpowered. The game gets more and more difficult but is manageable, however this final boss... it's just a lot of frustration especially since there is no "ending".

In any case, I still had a lot of fun and really recommend this game.
Hard but nice game!

A game that doesn't understand gameplay, chance or when a schtick has worn dry.

Firstly, the most substantial critique is levelled at the gameplay itself. It consists of two parts, really, overworld "exploration" and small combat arenas. In the overworld, you follow a path of unrevealed cards, which are revealed when stepped upon, giving you a random encounter, sometimes with a choice, sometimes just with an effect, and sometimes what you do further has a random chance of succeeding or failing. There's a pretense at it being a draw of a card that you can effect, but it's really just a random dice roll. Sometimes these events will result in a combat arena, where you're locked in with some enemies until they're all dead or, very rarely, a "puzzle arena" where your camera is locked at a terrible angle and you do your best to dodge-roll past traps you can hardly see before you're on top of them.

The issue with the overworld exploration is the hidden cards, really. If you knew which encounters were coming up, and had multiple routes(you very rarely do), you could plan how to approach them based on your food supplies(each card moved takes up 1 food, if you have food, you're healed, if you have none, you're harmed), what gear you have, how risky you want to play it, etc. But as it is, you're just... rolling a die every time you do ANYTHING. Because any given step you take might as well blow you up as help you. So the game never really challenges your planning, just your luck. A second issue is that as you play, your deck of available cards is increased, which means that everything just becomes MORE random. So for instance, on the first level or two, you only fight bandits, so you could go: "Ah-hah! This item boosts my abilities against bandits! I should prioritize this!" but soon you've got bandits, lizards, skeletons and rats with more-or-less equal spawn chances so you may as well not even bother to try. You also can't re-equip once you KNOW what you're fighting, so. Yeah.

The second issue is that the game is extremely enchanted with its presentation. I mean, sure, it's a neat schtick, and sure, the narrator's voice is pretty alright. But by the tenth unskippable card setup scene or repeat of the same voice clip or animation that just drags out a thing I've already seen A HUNDRED TIMES... yeah, my patience starts running out.

I really can't recommend this game, and since the second game looks exactly like the first but with slightly updated graphics? I'd suggest skipping that one as well.

Too much to lose, too little to gain.

I really like the premise of the game, but the execution is just too harsh on the player. Skill has very little influence, much less even than in RNG-heavy stuff like Darkest Dungeon (which I did enjoy btw).  I get that a Roguelike is supposed to have a great deal of chance involved, but the cards are, quite literally, stacked way too heavily against you in this game. 

And even if you do manage to have a bit of luck, it never feels satisfying. Magic items you find only do something in combat, but the majority of events are out-of-combat, where succes is based on drawing the correct card, odds which are usually 50/50 at best, usually worse. Items don't help you there. As a result, you never feel like you're actually getting stronger or getting better at the game. 

The only thing this game does is make you feel helpless because you're running out of food again after 12 cards with no rewards or shops. Buy this only if stuff like Darkest Dungeon wasn't sadistic enough for you.
Very fun game but god damn, the combat really holds it back.

You get sold features seperately as a DLC that should be in the basegame. So you get asked for money twice if you like the game. Content of the basegame is slim. No way they should ask you a second time for your money.

The game itself is mediocre. "Mostly positive reviews" is not warranted in my opinion. It should be "mixed".

I bought it for a 75% discount and that's ok. No way this is worth the full price of 20 bucks. 5 bucks on a sale is ok because remember: you'll have to pay twice anyways because they only sell you half a game and the other half as a seperate DLC.

Their full price is definately much too high. Only buy on a deep discount if at all.

Get Hand of Fate 2. It's much more fun, has more content overall, and is significantly more refined overall. This game has too many kinks to recommend it over the 2nd. 

What is this game?

         Hand of Fate is a Card Game/Beat-Em up hybrid. Most of the game you're dealing with cards as your scenarios and you battle it out in a Batman Style "Aimless Combat". What I mean by Aimless combat is that combat is supposed to be fluid enough for you to just let the attacks chain together and not have to individually look at each person to attack. You assume the role of an Adventurer (Or whatever you chose if you have the Wildcard DLC) and you try to wipe out the entire deck of the Dealer, starting at the Jacks and ending with the Kings. 

 Card Mechanics:

      The Base Mechanics are that you have Health, Food, and Gold. Your health is basic, you need health to survive. Food ticks down every time you move to another part of the map. If you have no food when you move, you start to starve and take damage every next card you move with 0 food. Gold is used for purchasing things or in encounters.
      There are 2 kinds of buffs and debuffs: Blessings and Curses. Blessings are nothing but good, while Curses can end up changing mechanics or being for the worst. (i.e. Midas Appetite, which causes all your food to turn into gold, and you consume 5 Gold instead of 1 Food.) Curses can be removed at certain shops, while Blessings can only be removed by items, encounters, or curses. 
       Shops will come up on the occasion, with 5 Available Shops: Standard Shops, Travelling Mages, Travelling Jewellers, Travelling Healers, and Travelling Preists. Shops can sell anything and has the most food, Mages have Magical Items and little of anything else, Jewellers only Carry Rings, Healers can remove curses, heal, and add blessings, and Preists can do the same as Healers but for cheaper. All shops will sell food no matter what, so don't worry about starving if you have coin. 
       Encounters can go in certain ways. They can just be passed by most of the time, but sometimes they require either  an action, an offering, or a card pull. Card Pulls you are given 4 Cards in front of you, with 4 different cards available (depending on the difficulty and the encounter): Failure, Success, Huge Failure, and Huge Success. Card Pulls are shuffled in front of you, so you really just need to track which card you want to pull. Sometimes, however, it's shuffled so fast it's almost impossible. 
       You do have gear available to you. You start with an Axe and a Shield and some other gear depending on the difficulty you chose. Your slots are Helmet, Shield, Armor, Gauntlets, Weapon, Rings, Blessings/Curses, and Artifacts. You can only have one of each equipped minus Blessings/Curses and Rings, and their effects stack. 

Combat Mechanics:
        
      The Combat mechanics are going to be the thing you're fighting most of the time. You use WASD to move, and you have pivital movement (standing still and turning won't turn your body left and right, it moves you forward and turns you). You use M1 to attack and M2 to do a Kick or a Shield Bash, knocking an enemy back slightly and also breaking whatever block they have. Pressing 1 will use a weapon's ability if it has one, and pressing 2 will use an Artefact if you have one. Pressing Q while you have a shield will allow you to reflect certain projectiles and parry certain attacks. Pressing Space will allow you to roll. 
       This game has Arkham Asylum-like beat-em-up combat. You click in the direction of the bad guys and press Q to counter enemies with a green squiggle crown on them. Enemies with Green Squiggles on their head can be parried, and if they're red they can't be parried or blocked. Enemies with Green Spikes on their head is about to shoot a reflectable projectile. It sounds all and good, but all Green Indicators do NOT show up unless you have a shield. No shield, and you have to go off visual cues. 


With the basics out of the way, I'm going to talk about most of the issues with the game.

Blessings being next to useless while curses can be crippling or game-ruining. i.e. "Holy Touch" makes it so undead that hit you have a chance of recieving damage, while one of the curses called "Cowardice" forces you to choose a non-combat encounter choice if available. Both of these have little techincal use, but Blessings are much less common and are outnumbered by Curses (17 Blessings total and 29 total Curses). One of the most problematic curses is Starvation, Consume 2 food instead of 1, or Haunted, which makes it so after every purchase (excluding the purchase to get rid of it) gives you a random curse. 

Bad Difficulty Curve. Difficulty has 2 or 3 noticible spikes, and the game is trivial most of the time afterwards. I played on Warlord most of my playthrough, and I noticed the main problems was 3 Bosses: The Jack of Plague, the King of Plague, and the Final Boss (which I will reveal under the spoilers section). Rest of it was extremely easy, and I even went for most of the tokens on new cards during this time. 

Reliance on the Pick a card system. The game relies heavily on the pick one for randomization, and it feels bland and repetitive due to it. Rather than adding more cards or doing a different form, the only times it gets harder is adding more Huge Failures and speeding up the card shuffling. 

Re-Using cards. A lot of the token cards are re-used a lot. Blood Auction happens 6 times and are the exact same minus the rewards. Iron Hunger happens 7 times. Shadow Agent happens 8 times. This happens a LOT. 
       
Poor Telegraphs and Visual Range. Sometimes during combat sections, unblockable attacks are just not going to work out as intented. Sometimes you get hit despite you rolled far enough away, sometimes you don't know it's coming until it's too late. Hellhounds are a big example of this, their unblockable attack seems like a parryable attack until right before you get hit. 

Clunky Movement. As mentioned before, movement seems more pivotal. You can't stand still and turn a direction, you move while turning that direction. Especially with the trap encounters like Devil's Trap or Trapped Labrynth, it's very easy to get hit or even killed due to this issue. 

Too high of a emphasis on combat. This game doesn't do combat well, but it's around 40% of the game. The other 60% being waiting, doing RNG Card pulls, or waiting for dialogue to end. 

No kind of build diversity outside the DLC. You can't really change up a build if you don't have the Wildcard DLC. Wildcard DLC allows you to do different builds, while the base game difficulty cards just give you Easy, Normal, and Hard. 

Overall, I think this game is 4/10. It was a good concept and it was GREATLY improved in Hand of Fate 2. I recommend getting Hand of Fate 2 over this by a long shot. However, if you're poor or want to get to know the low-down on the story, get this then. Otherwise, get Hand of Fate 2. 

!!! SPOILERS BELOW. THIS PART OF THE REVIEW HAS SPOILERS !!!

The Final boss fight - The Dealer boss fight is not only boring but also bullshit. The bosses he summons are very easy, but the Dealer's attacks are badly done. They deal too much damage for what they're worth, and how hard the later ones are to dodge. Especially since a RED telegraph on a RED TABLECLOTH is extremely hard to see. On top of that, the Final Phase, the one where he summons the Jack, Queen, and King of Scales, gets drawn out due to the King of Scale's friendly immunity. 

The Dealer's Curses are also really hard to deal with. If you don't get the Travelling Healer or Priest, you're screwed if they're bad. Especially since doing this on Warlord gives you a 40 ENCOUNTER DECK, you will go through much more than you need to. I managed to accrue 10 curses and died to starvation because of starvation curse. It gets very tedious and if you don't get lucky with curses it's over.

appDetails.name: Hand of Fate
appDetails.detailed_description:
Add Hand of Fate 2 to your wishlist in order to keep up to date on announcements and release details!

"Words fail me at describing just how seamlessly Defiant Development managed to blend the tailored experience aspect of deck building games with the hack-and-slash excitement of action-RPGs." - The Escapist

"If you are a fan of either old school adventure books, Gauntlet from its glory days, collectible card games, Rogue or just general fantasy, this game is for you" - Gamestyle 9/10

"Whether you are a CCG veteran or not, you need to play this game…right now!" - Godisageek 9/10

"Defiant Development’s newest project feels like playing a customizable card game, Dungeons & Dragons, and Batman: Arkham Asylum all at the same time; if that idea doesn’t excite you, then I have no idea what will." Gaming Union 9/10

Deckbuilding Comes to Life In hand Of Fate!


An infinitely replayable series of quests - earn new cards, build your deck, then try to defeat it!

Beyond the thirteen gates at the end of the world, the game of life and death is played. Draw your cards, play your hand, and discover your fate. Hand of Fate is a hybrid roguelike/action-RPG/deck builder, in which the player builds a set of cards into a deck, which is then used to deal out the dungeon floors through which they adventure. Upon entering a combat, all of the cards the player has collected fly into their hands as fully modeled 3D assets, and combat begins.

Build your deck, enter the world of Hand of Fate, and prepare to face the Ace of Skulls.

Key Features

  • Tabletop card game brought to vivid life.
  • A unique take on roguelike gameplay.
  • Visceral action-RPG combat.
  • Game changing gear and items make every play through unique.
  • Hundreds of encounters, items, armor, weapons, artifacts, and mysteries to unlock.
  • Unique deck building mechanics let you customise your own adventure, as you seek to defeat the Jack, Queen and King of each suit.

Microsoft Xbox 360® Controller (or equivalent) is recommended.

appDetails.name: HoPiKo
appDetails.detailed_description:
Download the HoPiKo Demo

http://store.steampowered.com/app/520570


About the Game


A virus, known as the Nanobyte has infected hardware around the globe rendering all systems useless - gaming is dead. The HoPiKo, who ran the games, have been enslaved... It’s time to hook up your power gloves and save your HoPiKo brothers!


HoPiKo is an intense speed run platformer where you get to save gaming. Jump from platform to platform avoiding death, exploiting shortcuts and ripping through 100s of hand-crafted levels, each one dropped into a 5-stage mini run designed to break your mind!

Compete to be the fastest in the world with time based scores, level pars and collectable retro consoles opening unique bonus runs.

  • Fast and brutal twitch-based gameplay.
  • Awesome chiptune soundtrack written and composed on authentic hardware.
  • Uses every ounce of your muscle memory.
  • Unique minimal controls, you’ve never played a platformer like this!

igdb.name: Jazzpunk
igdb.summary: Jazzpunk is a single-player, first-person adventure game, focusing on exploration and comedy over puzzle-solving. Each mission has one central objective, but the player is free to explore the game world at their own pace, which is populated with a large number of interactive NPCs, each with their own action or gag. Mini-games, including mini-golf, a Frogger clone, and a version of Duck Hunt in which the player pelts cardboard ducks with slices of bread from a toaster, also feature prominently in the game's storyline.
igdb.storyline:
The game is centered around a top-secret espionage agency operating out of an abandoned subway station in late 1950's Japan. The player takes the role of Polyblank, a silent protagonist. The game begins when Polyblank is mailed to the espionage agency in a human-shaped suitcase. He is then given several missions by the head of the organization, all of which begin by ingesting a dose of prescription medicine and which end with the protagonist sitting on a bench in a Zen garden, feeding breadcrumbs to Koi fish. The missions assigned to Polyblank are almost always bizarre and nonsensical, relying heavily on free association and references to older movies and video games. Tasks include degaussing and smuggling pigeons, assassinating cowboys, cross-dressing, killing a pig with a six-string guitar, and photocopying Polyblank's bottom to fool a security scanner.
The first mission begins with Polyblank having to infiltrate a Soviet consulate to recover a data cartridge, the second to go to a sushi restaurant to steal a cowboy's artificial kidney. On the way back from the sushi restaurant, Polyblank is intercepted by agents telling him to 'hand over the wetware', but he escapes. The Director then states that Polyblank should take a holiday while they wait for things to die down. When Polyblank gets to Kai Tak Resort for his holiday, he receives a phone call telling him he has to find the syndicate man (The Editor) on site and switch briefcases with him. Polyblank succeeds, but then passes out after drinking a cocktail. Polyblank wakes up in a hotel room at night with a message telling him to come to the rear pool. In the empty rear pool, Polyblank talks to a man who tells him the resort is a simulation, and to get out he must find, kill and cook the mechanical pig. After doing this, and navigating an electric maze, Polyblank finds himself back in the subway station, only to find the Director and his secretary are cardboard cutouts. He then finds an audio message from the Editor telling him if he wants to see them again he should come to his house. Polyblank goes there, and he is told he must beat the Editor in a game of sport for the Director to be freed. Polyblank loses, and so must find prizes for the Editor. Polyblank does this, inflating the Editor's ego, then he pops the Editor with a needle. Polyblank then finds the Director, where to free him he must either press a button. No matter which Polyblank presses, the Director turns into a crocodile and eats Polyblank. The credits take place in the Director's intestines, and then Polyblank is giving special tablets to help him get out. The game ends after Polyblank takes the pills.

reviews.review:
This game is a treasure to behold, I love everything about it.
Every single joke, every single reference, the games design.
I wish more people checked it out

Can you name one game more creative than this one ?
This is a must play on Steam.
This game is what I imagine drugs are like.
This was silly.
Not very often does a game sadden me for not having more content. I had fun from the very first to the very last moment. What a marvellous game!

I ended up playing through the entire game aside a friend and It was a blast; its so stupid and at the same time so smart.

Gameplay is inspired by spoof comedy films and cartoons of yesteryear, with a focus on weird gadgets, exotic locales, and open-world style. 

Honestly all I can really say is that you will leave this game smiling at your monitor like a huge doofus.

This game is pure comedy, you should definitely buy it, although I recommend to buy it only when discounted, since it´s a short game. Also, if you have zero understanding about pop culture references, don´t bother buying it.
What's amazing about this is how it does comedy in a way that could only be done by a video game. It's very medium-specific comedy, & I wish more games played with that the way this one does.

There is no real gameplay, and I played 2.5 hours and not laughed once. The entire game is clicking random things and hoping something funny happens. Even for 4 bucks, I wouldn't recommend this. A waste of time, and money.

appDetails.name: Jazzpunk: Director's Cut
appDetails.detailed_description:
Jazzpunk is a comedy adventure set in an alternate reality Cold War World, plagued with corporate espionage, CyberCrime, and sentient martinis. Gameplay is inspired by spoof comedy films and cartoons of yesteryear, with a focus on weird gadgets, exotic locales, and open-world style exploration.

Key Features:

  • Stereographic Polygony Soundeo™, NOW IN COLOURVISON.
  • A cast of over 360,000 polygons, working in concert.
  • For the first time ever, the human voice captured and preserved in CryoSonic Stasis™, thawed before your very ears during NPC exchanges (voice acting).
  • Windows/Mac/Linux/Suppository
  • Half a dozen jokes.
  • Contains 5% of recommended daily intake of vitamin C++
  • Original soundtrack featuring exotic percussion and homemade analog electronic instruments.

Find out why PC Gamer says Jazzpunk is "easily one of the funniest games in years."

igdb.name: 10 Second Ninja
igdb.summary:
Ninja's are awesome, this is an established fact of the universe. Nazi Robots from space however are not. They are trying to take over the Earth and their leader Robot Hitler is out to get you, the world's first ninja. You have 10 seconds to destroy all Nazi Robots in your vicinity and face the ultimate challenge: Hitler Robot himself. THE GAME IS ON. 
 
10 Second Ninja is a blisteringly fast platformery, actiony, sort of puzzley gamey thing. The player (that's you) is given the task of eliminating all of the enemies in each stage in 10 seconds or less. How hard could that be?

reviews.review:
Hate to have to give this game a bad review, because it seems fun in the beginning and has some funny (albeit juvenile) cutscenes. The problem is the title is extremely deceptive. In order to even progress to later levels, nevermind replaying them for achievements, you have to complete levels in less than a few seconds. If this were optional and not mandatory to progress, then I might recommend this game to people who are good at speedrunning.

Everyone else should be prepared to spend hours repeating the same levels to get ridiculously perfect timing while making their fingers go numb.

appDetails.name: 10 Second Ninja
appDetails.detailed_description:
Ninjas are cool, this is an established fact of the universe. Nazi Robots from space are not cool, they are the complete opposite of cool, and Robot Hitler is out to get you, the world's first ninja.

You have 10 seconds to destroy all Nazi Robots in your vicinity. IT. IS. ON.

Become the ultimate Ninja and take down Robot Hitler’s automated autocracy in this blisteringly fast platformer.

Ready, Steady, Ninja!

Features


  • Blitz through 40 challenging levels!
  • Fight again and again to get the best time possible and a glorious three star rating!
  • Break your controller or keyboard out of anger!
  • Battle your friends down to the millisecond on the leaderboards
  • Prove you know how to play games and collect all 30 achievements

Warning: This game contains flashing images. It is advised that you do not play if you suffer from photosensitive epilepsy.

igdb.name: Broken Sword 5: The Serpent's Curse
igdb.summary: Paris in the spring. Shots ring out from a gallery. A robbery -- a murder -- and the beginning of another epic, original Broken Sword adventure! Broken Sword 5: The Serpent’s Curse builds on the rich heritage of the classic Broken Sword adventure gaming saga. Intrepid lawyer George Stobbart and sassy journalist Nico Collard are hurled onto the trail of a murderous conspiracy forged in the cauldron of war-torn Europe. A conspiracy whose roots lie in mysteries older than the written word. Armed only with logic, integrity and a wry sense of humor, can George and Nico outwit evil forces both ancient and modern and save mankind from disaster? From a Curse forged by the Devil himself?

pegi.synopsis:
The content of this game is suitable for persons aged 16 years and over only.
It contains: Realistic looking violence

reviews.review: Very good

I have been fan of first two games. Unfortunately III & IV didn't reach the heights of them. So I had little doubt about this one too. But 5th installment is great. This isn't masterpiece like first two but this is better than last two games.  
  
Pros:  
1. The art style
2. Voice acting
3. The story
4. The humour.

Cons:
1. My game crashes in windows 10 a lot. It hindered my enjoyment slightly. But eventually I could able to finish my game. Crashes were not game breaking but high in numbers.

If you have older Windows machine, then this is a great game to enjoy. If you can overlook the crash in Win10, then grab this one.  

I give this [b]recommended[/b] stamp.

appDetails.name: Broken Sword 5 - the Serpent's Curse
appDetails.detailed_description:
Paris in the spring. Shots ring out from a gallery…

A robbery… a murder… and the beginning of another epic, original Broken Sword adventure.

From multi-award winning Revolution Software comes the latest explosive episode in this classic series. Playing as intrepid American George Stobbart and sassy French journalist Nico Collard, you find yourself on the trail of a stolen painting – and a murderous conspiracy. A conspiracy whose roots lie in mysteries older than the written word...

Armed only with logic, integrity and a wry sense of humour - can George and Nico save mankind from disaster?

Can you solve the secret of the Serpent’s Curse? A curse forged by the Devil himself...

Key Features:
  • The latest game in the global smash Broken Sword series
  • Solve riddles, defeat conspiracies, and survive chilling threats
  • A wonderful cast of characters - all fully voiced
  • Classic point-and-click gameplay
  • Stunning music from world-acclaimed composer, Barrington Pheloung

This Definitive Edition also includes:
  • Unlockable Character Gallery
  • Full controller support
  • Additional animations and sound effects
  • Enhanced UI
  • Tap-to-continue speech option

reviews.review: Fun building and testing my own planes.
After playing it for a while, it is pretty fun. All you need is creativity, and if you dont have, just try out some creations made of the community.
Creative

If you're looking for a game review than you came to the wrong place, now if you wanted a delicious pancake recipe...



Ingredients + Equipment

You’ll need a mixing bowl, a wire whisk, a spatula and a non-stick griddle or skillet. An electric griddle works wonders too, if you make a lot of pancakes at your house. The ingredients you’ll need are:

1 ¼ cup milk 
2 eggs 
2 tablespoons vegetable oil 
2 cups all-purpose flour 
2 tablespoons sugar 
3 teaspoons baking powder 
¼ teaspoon salt

The Batter
Pancakes aren’t complicated, so the batter is everything! For best results, mix that bowl of batter up right before it’s going to hit the griddle.

The wet ingredients come together first. Beat the milk, eggs and vegetable oil in a mixing bowl with a wire whisk.

The dry ingredients—flour, baking powder, sugar and salt—are then stirred into the wet mixture. Baking powder is what makes the pancakes fluffy, while the sugar helps the exterior caramelize just enough. And a dash of our friend salt enhances the flavor.

Gently mix everything together until it’s combined, but still lumpy. It’ll only take about 10-15 seconds to get to that liquidy-lumpy state. If you over-mix the batter, you’re going to be chowing down on a very tough, rubbery pancake because the gluten molecules start having a party. If you under-mix, you might end up with a mouthful of flour.


The Cooking
Brush a non-stick griddle or skillet with vegetable oil, clarified butter or cooking spray before heating. You don’t need too much with a nonstick pan. (You may be tempted to use regular butter, but it tends to burn easily. Save the butter for the breakfast table.)

Heat the griddle over medium-high heat. To determine when the griddle is ready for pancake action, run your hand under the faucet and carefully flick just a tiny bit of water onto the surface of the pan. The water droplets will bead up and sizzle when it’s ready.

Pour ¼ cup of batter onto the hot griddle and cook 1-2 minutes or until the bubbles on the surface have finished popping and the pancake is dry around the edges.

Now it’s time to flip. Using a spatula, gently turn the pancake over and cook on the other side until golden brown.


Serve warm
Fluffy Pancakes
Print Recipe
(0) 0 View Full Recipe
Ingredients
Steps
How to Keep Pancakes Hot
If you’re cooking for a crowd, turn the oven to 325°F and put your finished pancakes on a baking sheet as they come off the griddle. That way they all stay hot until you are ready to eat.

How to Store Leftover Pancakes in the Freezer
Stack cooled pancakes between a sheet of waxed paper or parchment. Wrap the stack in foil and freeze. To reheat, preheat the oven to 400°F. Unwrap frozen pancakes and remove from waxed paper. Heat pancakes in a single layer on an ungreased cookie sheet for 5 to 7 minutes or until heated through.

How to Store Leftover Batter
Storing leftover batter is one of those things one could technically do, but should one? Nah, one really shouldn’t.

The baking powder loses its oomph very quickly and the gluten molecules have a field day of chewiness when they are allowed to sit around. Rather than storing leftover batter, we recommend making just the right amount of batter for your breakfast or cooking up the whole batch and storing leftover pancakes in the freezer as directed above.

Back To Top
Twists on Pancakes
Pancakes are meant to be twisted! There are so many ways you can upgrade your pancakes, from batter mix-ins to mid-griddle additions to final toppings.

Batter mix-ins might include pureed pumpkin with pumpkin pie spice, lemon zest and ricotta cheese or even mashed bananas. Our Gingerbread Pancakes are perfect for the holidays. Buttermilk is a common substitute for milk in pancakes too, as the acidity provides extra volume, browning and flavor. Adding additional (or different) wet ingredients may mean you need to adjust your dry ingredients accordingly, so unless you’re simply shaking a bit of cinnamon into your batter, you’ll want to follow a recipe to make sure your flavored pancakes turn out perfectly.

Mid-griddle additions would include those tasty bits that you’ll want to place on your hot cakes before you flip them—things like whole berries, chocolate chips, crunchy granola or little pieces of bacon. Adding these types of things to the individual pancakes rather than the batter helps them stay evenly distributed and keeps them from burning. You can use the same Fluffy Pancake recipe outlined above and easily personalize it with whatever you like without changing the batter.

Topping options are pretty much unlimited when it comes to pancakes, and also don’t require any new recipe. Obviously butter and maple syrup are classic pancake pairings for a reason—there is no substitute for a hefty drizzle of real maple syrup. But it’s also wonderful to think outside the syrup container and try topping your pancakes with jam, caramel, nuts, fruit, whipped cream, sprinkles and more!

8 Easy Twists on Pancakes

Gingerbread Pancakes

appDetails.name: SimplePlanes
appDetails.detailed_description:
BUILD AIRPLANES


You have the tools you'll need to bring any airplane to life. Snap parts together to build your airplane's body. Place engines to add thrust. Design and attach wings and then strap yourself into the cockpit and see how it flies.

DOWNLOAD AIRPLANES


Over 100,000 airplanes are available to download for free from SimplePlanes.com Find anything from old WW2 bombers to next generation fighters to sci-fi spacecrafts. You can upload your own airplanes and rise through the ranks from a bronze builder to a gold level builder.

DYNAMIC FLIGHT MODEL


Flight simulation at its finest. Every little change you make in the designer impacts how the airplane flies. Weight distribution, thrust, lift, and drag are all calculated continuously while flying. Parts can break off in spectacular fashion while flying due to over-stress or by hitting something. The fun won't stop there though. You can keep on flying even with a missing wing if you've got the skills.

CHALLENGES


Climb into the cockpit of one of your custom aircraft and see how it does in the challenges. The challenges will keep you entertained for hours. Land on aircraft carriers, escort bombers, dodge surface-to-air missiles, race through courses, and so much more.

SANDBOX


Use all available parts to build airplanes with no restrictions. The sky is the limit. Literally.

MODDING


Modding is fully supported so you can build your own parts and environments. Download our Unity package which includes specially designed tools to aid in designing and building mods which you can then share with your friends and the community.

igdb.name: Dropsy
igdb.summary:
After a deadly circus fire shatters his world and tarnishes his name, Dropsy the Clown finds himself on a journey of self-discovery through a story that harnesses powerful themes of love and kindness. With his father gravely ill and the world turning its back on a once happy-go-lucky clown, Dropsy will need to help those in need, hug total strangers, and unravel dark and shameful secrets from his past on the way to redemption. Oh, and Dropsy can also talk to animals.

Dropsy is a non-traditional take on the classic point and click adventure formula starring the game’s perpetually carefree namesake clown as he explores a richly detailed world full of colorful characters and sinister secrets, doling out hugs along the way. Rather than lead players on a singular narrative path, players are free to choose which avenues of adventure they want to explore in an open world setting and can piece the puzzles and story together however they choose.

reviews.review: Nice adventure game with a very creative gameplay, memorable characters and somewhat both cheerful AND dark athmosphere. I'd absolutely recommend this game to fans of Point & Click, puzzles, clowns and to Juggalos. <3
What a strange, wild, and ultimately comfy ride it's been. I feel so good having played it start to finish.

Dropsy too pure.

A must if you are a fan of hugs.

i hate point and click games, i never liked them. 
i got this game because i realy like the pixel art style used and the character is funny. the world is dark and light at the same time. both sick and twisted and loving and peacful. giving hugs is the best game objective ever.  i got this game knowing id never play it through, i just got it becouse i realy like its style. idk how to put it into words.

if u like point and click games u would be foolish to pass this 1 up

appDetails.name: Dropsy
appDetails.detailed_description:
Dropsy: Warm Damp Hug Edition

The Dropsy Warm Damp Hug Edition includes the official Dropsy digital soundtrack by Chris Schlarb, the Eternal Hug music EP by Jay Tholen, and Dropsy's Book of Secrets - a collection of over 100 pages of tips, sketches, concepts and ramblings from designer Jay Tholen.


About the Game

After a deadly circus fire shatters his world and tarnishes his name, Dropsy the Clown finds himself on a journey of self-discovery through a story that harnesses themes of love and unmerited kindness. With his father gravely ill and the world turning its back on the once celebrated clown, Dropsy will need to help those in need, hug total strangers, and unearth dark secrets on the winding road to redemption. Oh, and Dropsy can also talk to animals.

Dropsy is a non-traditional take on the classic point and click adventure formula starring the game's perpetually carefree namesake clown as he explores a richly detailed world full of colorful characters and sinister secrets, doling out hugs along the way. Rather than lead players on a singular narrative path, players are free to determine which avenues of adventure they want to explore in an open world setting and can piece the puzzles together at their own pace.

  • Open World Adventure – Players are free to choose which avenues of adventure they want to explore in an open world setting and can piece many of the puzzles and story bits together however they choose.

  • Text Free Experience – Communicate with a bizarre and colorful cast of characters through an innovative use of visual icons rather than traditional text-based dialog trees.

  • Puzzles and Hugs – Challenging puzzles and complex conundrums stand between Dropsy and the secrets behind his shrouded past. With clever thinking, tender hugs, and the help of his animal friends, Dropsy can overcome evil and win the hearts of the people around him.

  • Evocative Soundtrack – From gentle electric piano and saxophone melodies of the starting area, to the space echo drenched dub reggae tracks of a vampire-hunting swamp village, to the bombastic fuzzed out quasi-prog-rock of the endgame sequences, Chris Schlarb and his band of minstrels give every area in the game a distinct sense of place.
