igdb.name: Broken Age
igdb.summary:
Broken Age is a point-and-click adventure telling the stories of a young boy and girl leading parallel lives. The girl has been chosen by her village to be sacrificed to a terrible monster--but she decides to fight back. Meanwhile, a boy on a spaceship is living a solitary life under the care of a motherly computer, but he wants to break free to lead adventures and do good in the world. Adventures ensue.

Broken Age development began when we asked our community if they would help us create a classic-style adventure game without needing to rely on traditional publishers. It turns out they did.

And ever since day one, 2 Player Productions has been recording the whole process in an ongoing series of in-depth episodes documenting the creation of a game. Stay tuned for details on how to get your hands on it.

esrb.synopsis: This is a point-and-click adventure game in which players assume the role of two teenagers trying to stop creatures from destroying their world. Players explore fantastical environments, interact with different characters, and search for items to progress the story. A handful of sequences depict various acts of violence: a character firing lasers at a giant monster; characters engaging in hand-to-hand combat; a ship hit with exploding projectiles. One sequence depicts a large chum bucket filled with red blood-like liquid. During the course of the game, a character coerces a tree creature into vomiting tree sap into a bucket. The word “damn” is heard in the dialogue.

pegi.synopsis:
The content of this game is suitable for persons aged 12 years and over only.
It contains: Non realistic looking violence towards human characters

reviews.review: The voice acting and art design was fantastic. But the plot itself was not very exciting and I just got bored and stopped playing... :/ In addition, choice-based dialogue is awesome, but there wasn't any branching dialogue unfortunately that altered anything. Lastly, the puzzles can be pretty tedious and illogical at times.

While a beautiful and engaging game at the start, Act II didn't deliver on any of the promises built up in the first section of the game.  Characterization is swept aside, the puzzles are tedious, and no satisfying resolution is presented to the story presented.  It feels like there should've been an Act III to really complete the game.  I don't regret playing it, necessarily, but neither would I necessarily recommend it to someone else.
I am impressed by the story, the art, and the voice acting!
From all the Double Fine games I've played, this is by far the best one.
Its a fantastic game!

Disclaimer: I played through the end of Act 1. I have not completed (or started) Act 2.

I have a love/hate relationship with adventure games. I like the creativity and story-telling involved, but hate that most devolve into random "guess what bizarre thing the designer was thinking" puzzles.

Broken Age (at least Act 1) was like that for me. The larger crime, however, is that I didn't find the story interesting or engaging. The end of Act 1 teases, I suppose, some coherence but really, for the most part you play as two different characters in two different worlds solving two entirely different sets of puzzles. I get that Act 2 may somehow tie these together, but after nearly 5 hours of Act 1, I just don't care.

If you love adventure games and don't mind a potentially dull story, give it a shot. Otherwise, move on as I have done.

Not recommended: 2.5 out of 5.

I love this game, I platinumed it on my PS4 but I'm really a PC gamer at heart so I bought it on Steam too lol.  The game has a really neat storyline that grabs you in.  The puzzles are fun, and the game is challenging.  Some of the puzzles border insane but with enough time you can figure them out.  I love the art style of the game, it's whimsical, and fun.

What a great game.  The story is amazing.  The puzzles are challenging.  The humor is funny.  The characters are well thoughtout.  I was a little underwhelmed with the ending but it was still a good ending.  I would highly recomend it if you play P&C Adventures.

only in Gaming Can you have CEO like Tim Schaffuer relentlessly denegrate and lie about the audience that not only purchases the product, but funds the entire thing (kickstarter). i could give this game a bad review and it would be justified because Tim openly lies about gamers, but truth is, i have integrity, so here we go:


GAMEPLAY: as a point and click Adventure - this GAME is solid, no game breaking glitches, or unwinnable scenarios. This game has no deaths, and limited inventory items (which means fewer useless objects being hauled around). Where the game-play diverts from a traditional point and click, is there are no ' True timing based ' problems, meaning everything is sequential, so if a character watching something ' just gets back' that means you've missed a step or you're not doing the correct solution. Talking to characters, is also essential in solving problems, and the way the game is there are certain characters you need to talk with, talk to other characters, and THEN return to the character to open new dialouge. Most puzzles cannot be 'brute forced' or even 'logically/systematically' solved, so you may be wasting time taking excessive notes during gameplay. although to be fair during the 2nd act there are more logic/mind puzzles which are satisfying to finally solve. There are also a particular puzzle that is really Rigid, its a "timing" based sequence, but its very unforgiving, and its not clear what you are exactly trying to do, also there are elements that arent obvious to make it even more convelouted. you just have to repetatively perform the same task over and over until you see what exactly you're missing, then once you 'see it' you will have to suffer more frustration as you realize the timing aspect doesn't set you up to complete the sequence, with out some back and forth...

the length of the game feels about right for a $8 game. but $20 is outrageous, Thimbleweed park is a much better buy at that pricepoint.


GRAPHICS/DESIGN: there is no real nostalgia factor here for the point-and-click genre, instead you have a 'storybook' motiff through out, that has animation like it came out of flash, now its much more sophisticated and polished, and it looks great. The characters are Cute, HOWEVER they did go cheap in that there are 2 missing Characters in the Game! they are referenced multiple times, you're even told they are in a room with other characters, but you never see them, even at the END of the game where everyone is reunited these two characters are not present, it totally breaks continuity and just is such a huge oversight.



 SOUND: The music is SIMPLY AMAZING, and the VOICE ACTING IS SPOT on!, The best character (NPC) in the game BY FAR is Curtis the Wood-Cutter, he deserves his own point-and-click adventure title. i am Dead serious, he is so charismatic and likable, and absolutely hilarious, its a shame that he doesn't have a bigger role in the game, but then sometimes less is more.



STORY: a lot of people bag on the story... i actually thought that the story was REALLY creative! its unlike any other point-and-click title out there, its Fun, engaging, but slow to start. I do have to say the ENDING was REALLY Poorly handled, it felt like a rush job / hurry up and wrap it up, type thing, very anticlimatic, there should have been a 3rd act as everyone else said. Also the Glaring issue of 2 characters who are referenced through-out the game never showing up (from the Cloud city) - oh well i guess they just DIED, they don't even have names, just birdgirl one and two.


OVERALL: i would definitely put this game in the top 5 'New Point and click adventure games' one or two spots below thimbleweed park. i had fun playing it, and it was VERY SOLID despite its shortcomings.

Wow. WOW. Where to start. Let me just say, this game is absolutely AMAZING. I don't usually write reviews, but I simply had to for this gem of a game.

1. The graphics
The backgrounds are beautifully drawn, even when I was first in Shay's spaceship I was mesmerized by the amount of detail in the design of the ship. I could even see the brush strokes which gave a really cool texture to the walls. They have a childlike feel to them, and each place is so unique and imaginatively structured. There never seemed to be an end to the creativity!

2. Character design
Each character in this game has such a unique personality and design. I absolutely love the talking animations, even though they get repetitive (should they not? I mean, characters talk a lot) I don't mind at all. Once in a while when Shay or Vella picks a certain dialogue option you get a different talk animation than the usual, and I think that's so cool!

3. The puzzles
I see a lot of negative reviews solely based on the puzzles, and I do have to say, they are very difficult. Coming from a person who doesn't play a lot of puzzle/brain type games, I did have to use a guide to figure them out. However, that doesn't mean they're impossible. I'm 100% positive a large amount of people could figure them out with no help. I didn't mind using a guide, it didn't give or take away from the game experience for me.

4. Soundtrack
There's not much I can describe about the music, as everyone has their own opinion of what music they like. However, in my opinion the soundtrack was beautifully composed, with very lovely themes and dramatic tones when needed. It made the scenery and graphics so much more pleasant!

5. Voice acting
There is way more than you originally expect to this game. Twists, turns, and a lovely blending of the two story paths that perfectly ties together the ending. I'm not a very thourough game purchaser, and I tend to just skim over descriptions of everything I buy. (Not a very good choice, I know, but its given me some fun surprises in the past.) Fortunately not reading this game's description while I bought it on a whim when I had a gift card and found it on sale, left me the fun part of figuring out the voice actors of each character. 

Shay immediately became my favorite, because Elijah Wood, come on! I enjoyed his acting in Over the Garden Wall, and I was so excited when I learned he is expanding his repitoire. I have a bad habit of skipping dialogue in games like these, because I have a short attention span, and it just gets boring, y'know? But with this game, I sat through every single dialogue option (except for the repeats, of course) and [i] listened. [/i] It's not much to put in my review, but for me personally, that was a huge plus.


All in all, I hope I've convinced whoever's reading this review to purchase this game and give it a try. You'll come away in a good mood, eagerly awaiting the next masterpiece of Double Fine Productions in the coming years.
If you're really into click and point adventures that move at an extremely slow pace, this game is for you. If you're like me, it isn't.

appDetails.name: Broken Age
appDetails.detailed_description:
Broken Age is a family friendly, hand-animated, puzzle-filled adventure game with an all-star cast, including Elijah Wood, Jack Black and Masasa Moyo. Funded by a record breaking crowdfunding campaign and designed by industry legend Tim Schafer, Broken Age is a timeless coming-of-age story of barfing trees and talking spoons.

Vella Tartine and Shay Volta are two teenagers in strangely similar situations, but radically different worlds. The player can freely switch between their stories, helping them take control of their own lives, and dealing with the unexpected adventures that follow.

Starring:

Elijah Wood as Shay
Masasa Moyo as Vella
Jack Black as Harm'ny Lightbeard
Jennifer Hale as Mom
Wil Wheaton as Curtis
Pendleton Ward as Gus

igdb.name: Jotun
igdb.summary: Jotun is a hand-drawn action-exploration game set in Norse mythology. In Jotun, you play Thora, a Norse warrior who has died an inglorious death and must prove herself to the Gods to enter Valhalla.

reviews.review:
I was hoping for another game like TitanSouls, and while this is similar in layout its execution is very different.

-I like hand drawn art, but theres poor linework everywhere and the general lack of detail in the environments makes trudging slowly through them very tiresome.
-The character controls are very simple, very clunky and really boring.
-The bosses are interesting designs, but the boss fights are horrible because of how slow and clunky your character is, it makes certain boss attacks feel really cheap because its almost impossible to avoid them without lucking out on their random placement (particularly the lightning giant to the north)

If this game was designed to be a little bit faster paced and a more fluid character control, then it would probably be pretty neat.
But that's not how it is, can't reccomend buying this one.

Really mediocre game. I noticed this game for it's cool styling and design when it came out a few years ago. I'd been waiting for a while to buy, now I regret buying it. I haven't played that much, and I doubt I'll play a lot more. Besides the comic-book styling there's little to recommend it. You wander around, usually there's some kind of avoidance trick: vines, wind, sea monsters. Then there's checkpoints, places to get power ups, and bosses. That's about it. For an adventure exploration game there's very little sense of discovery. The fights are repetitive, the puzzles are annoying. I found myself accidentally throwing away my power-ups all the time, which are the only way to beat the big bosses. 
Speaking of the big bosses, the scale is kinda cool, the bosses are HUGE compared to your character, but when you fight them you become a tiny blob on the screen. Caveat, I'm couch playing this game, so that probably contributes to the small-blobiness of the character. 
I guess one more positive is the voice acting. I do like the old Norse, or fake Norse that's read at various intervals. 
I'd give this a 2 out of 5 stars.

It is a good game
The atmosphere is great and I like this cartoony style
GG

[b]Jotun[/b] is an action-exploration game, by [b]Thunder Lotus Games[/b], set in Norse mythology.

The game's setting and hand-drawn art style was what captured my attention. Both the art-style and music don't disappoint and kept me going. 
Exploration could be more rewarding. Regular combat could use more depth and the last boss suffers from an inappropriate difficulty spike.
In relation to the story, it plays a minimal role but it is compensated by the atmosphere that both the art and music immerse you in while playing.
It took me [b]9 hours[/b] to finish the game. It has a Metacritic [b]score[/b] of [b]79[/b] (critics) and a [b]6.9[/b] (users).

[b]Overall[/b], I liked it although I wish the gameplay and story were more developed.
[b]My score: 7/10[/b]

This game is extremely fucking stupid.
All I did was run around, without being told why, looking for where to go, getting stopped by rocks that look
exactly like the other rocks you can walk on.  Getting lost, and having a useless map that doesn't tell you where you are, 
or God forbid, where you're supposed to go.
The only enemy was some poison plant that hurts you in it's area, so I have to avoid it.  Wow, that's real fun.  All I did was
avoid some circle areas like I'm playing plant frogger.  Got to that huge game credits stone (you know, another dead end, where you have to figure out where to go next, because that's why I play video games), and I thought, "Wow it took that many people to design this waste of time?
Listening to some annoying viking language narrator the whole time, like I'm supposed to think it's epic or something.
Why do I have to play as a female?  As if she can swing around that 50 lb battle axe, and keep sprinting around.
If the game is this bad in the first few minutes, fucking forget it!

appDetails.name: Jotun: Valhalla Edition
appDetails.detailed_description:
Jotun is a hand-drawn action-exploration game set in Norse mythology.

In Jotun, you play Thora, a Viking warrior who died an inglorious death and must prove herself to the Gods to enter Valhalla.

Explore vast regions of Norse Purgatory to find runes to unleash the jotun, giant Norse elementals. Fight them using only your massive two-handed axe, the blessings of the Gods and your skills!

Jotun: Valhalla Edition features the brand new Valhalla Mode, the ultimate battle against even fiercer versions of the Jotun! A true challenge for those who wish to impress the Gods!

Features

  • Experience beautiful hand-drawn animation
  • Fight five epic jotuns, giant Norse elementals
  • Explore nine vast and mysterious levels filled with Viking mythology
  • Learn about Thora's life and death in an overarching story
  • Summon powers bestowed upon you by the Viking Gods
  • Hear authentic Icelandic voice-overs
  • Listen to an amazing original soundtrack, specifically composed for every gameplay moment by Max LL

  • Facebook
  • Twitter
  • Twitch

igdb.name: Fran Bow
igdb.summary: Fran Bow is a creepy adventure game that tells the story of Fran, a young girl struggling with a mental disorder and an unfair destiny.

reviews.review:
If you like any of the following, you'll enjoy this game: Labyrinth, Alice in Wonderland, Mirrormask, Neverending Story, etc etc.

Fran, a young girl, ends up in a twisted mental hospital, following the homicide of her parents. Who killed them and why? Fran is given a mysterious drug that lets her switch between realities and travel to new worlds parallel to ours. She sees weird monsters and imaginary friends. What is real? Is someone trying to kill her?

The game play is about 8 hours with 5 chapters, and very similar to The Silent Age, another point and click game that lets you switch between realities. The puzzles are not overly difficult but some of them are obtuse, requiring you to randomly click on things until something works.

There are some stupidly easy platform jumping and maze games, there's no fail state and some you can just skip over.

There's some very disturbing imagery (a la Hellraiser) and surrealistic horror. Lots of dead children, gore, and bad things happening to people. Not recommended for young children, but there's no sex or cursing. Fran remains optimistic even though really terrible things are happening to her. It falls into the realm of horror fantasy, and it's not all horrible. The middle bit is fantasy, and there's some murder mystery thrown in for good measure.

It was really fun to play, the art is delightful, and it'll leave you thinking. Highly recommended!

I freaking love this girl, she is so cool. I don't care about my life very much, but I was worried sick about this girl. Despite knowing how this game works and ways to solve puzzles, I looked into a walk-through few times, just to be sure that Fran absolutely definitely won't die (it actually ruined some moments of the game for me, don't do that).
I was a little disappointed in the end, because, well, I knew that nothing can be perfect in Fran's life anymore, but I still hoped it freaking will, because she is so cool. She was the one in the game, who calmed me down, with her childish and innocent attitude. You know, I see a monster and my instincts are screaming: "we're DONE, Fran will die because of me", and then this little girl just says something like: "hello mr. Monster, how is your day?" She is the only reason I finished this game. She is super great.

O M G!! I am super confused and in love with this game right now! First chapter was super duper disgusting and with every chapter shits got crazier and crazier. Ending was kinda confusing and now I have so many questions and I am like OMG WHAT JUST HAPPENED. I love this game so much that I needed to write a review. I hope you guys try this one and play til the end it is really worth it

this game is awesome
it's mixed psychological horror and mysteries
i strongly recommend it to those who didn't play game like this before
هي لعبة جيدة
Interesting point and click adventure game with not over complicated puzzles yet very engaging story, creepy visuals and unique characters.

I really enjoyed this game. The ending was a bit abrupt but the overall game was really interesting. It was very philosphical and fun with it's mindgames and puzzles. Would have loved for it to be a bit longer.

appDetails.name: Fran Bow
appDetails.detailed_description:
Fran Bow is a creepy adventure game that tells the story of Fran, a young girl struggling with a mental disorder and an unfair destiny.
After witnessing the gruesome and mysterious loss of her parents, found dismembered at their home, Fran rushes into the woods, together with her only friend, Mr. Midnight, a black cat that Fran had previously received as a present from her parents.

In the forest, Fran goes into shock over the loss of her parents and when she recovers, she’s at Oswald Asylum, an oppressive mental institution for children, and Mr. Midnight is nowhere to be found.

After having a dream about her beloved cat, Fran decides to escape from the mental institution to find him and go back home to Aunt Grace, her only living relative.

Features

  • Story driven creepy psychological horror adventure game.
  • Unique and peculiar hand drawn 2D Art-Style and 2D animation.
  • Self administer medication to open the terrible hidden world that will help solve puzzles and find objects.
  • A big variety of puzzles designed with different levels of difficulty and specifically based on the story.
  • Three arcade inspired mini-games all with different art style to be part of the transitions in the story.
  • Interactive and occasionally playable pet cat, Mr Midnight.
  • 50+ interactive unique characters with unique personalities.
  • Original Soundtrack.

igdb.name: Sneak 'n Peek
igdb.summary:
Sneak'n Peek is played in and around a spooky old house with a large yard and three weird rooms. Each room, including the yard, is a separate scene: 
- a living room 
- a pink bedroom 
- a blue bedroom 
- the yard 
 
Each scene contains up to five hiding places. That makes a total of twenty 
hiding locations. Some of them are in really strange places, and some of 
the locations can change depending on the level you select. 
 
GAME 1: One Player Game 
- Fixed Hiding Places 
- Computer Hides 
 
GAME 2: Two Player Game 
- Fixed Hiding Places 
- Players Both Hide 
 
GAME 3: Two Player Game 
- Variable Hiding Places* 
- Players Both Hide 
 
GAME 4: Two Player Game 
- Fixed Hiding Places 
- Computer Hides 
 
 
* Game 3 fixed hiding places and 2 variable hiding places. The 2 variable hiding 
places can change from their standard positions to new positions in the same 
scene. They change every time a player enters the scene to hide.

appDetails.name: Avernum 2: Crystal Souls
appDetails.detailed_description:
Avernum 2: Crystal Souls is an epic, indie, fantasy role-playing adventure in a unique, massive world. The subterranean land of Avernum is full of strange caves, cunning dungeons, and the alien inhabitants of the underworld. Explore a massive, underground nation of tunnels and caverns, packed with over 100 towns and dungeons. Fight to complete up to three distinct game-winning quests.

Avernum 2: Crystal Souls features:


  • Epic fantasy adventure with over 50 hours of gameplay. An enormous underworld, with multiple nations and alien cultures.
  • Rich game system with over 60 spells and battle disciplines and a multitude of beneficial character traits to choose from.
  • Over 100 towns and dungeons.
  • Three separate game-winning quests. There are many ways to fight the invaders. Do just one of them or all three!
  • Unique races and settings make Avernum different from any adventure out there.
  • Dozens of side quests and hundreds of magical artifacts.

The story of Avernum 2 is self-contained, and previous experience with Avernum games isn't required.

igdb.name: Nuclear Throne
igdb.summary: Nuclear Throne is an action roguelike-like by Vlambeer about mutants fighting their way through a post-apocalyptic world. The radioactive waste in the world allows mutants to get ahead by mutating new limbs on the fly, the abundant availability of powerful weaponry make the quest to become ruler of the Wasteland one fraught with peril.
igdb.storyline: One of 12 nuclear anomalies/ mutant creatures embarks on a quest across various post- apocalyptic dimensions to claim the Nuclear Throne - a super weapon, details of whose purpose or creation unknown. Meanwhile, the Inter-Dimensional Police Department try their best not to let the mutant heroes discover the secrets of portal-based inter-dimensional travel and the Throne.

reviews.review: Fish can roll
Once you get to the point where you're consistently looping, this game becomes an absurd amount of fun.

A very extreme bullet hell with a lot of connections to The Binding of Isaac and Enter the Gungeon. Every seed is like a present, waiting to be opened. It's a hell of a lot of fun, and it's a damn good recommendation.

I love this game, hands down one of my favorite games of all time. The only thing I could think that would make me play it less is getting all of the achievements, and even then I'd still play it.
Some beautiful people also made the mod Nuclear Throne Together, it allows for online co-op and it's amazing.
i want this game to stop abusing me ;(

I don't know but, I cannot help my self from playing.... 
Even on my macbook the game runs smooth af, and trust me when I say: playing with trackpad is hard! But I feel that I'm getting better and better. Seeing progress, slowly but it is there.


Really enjoying this game!
this game ruined my life.
Game is very hard. Game is very good. You're gonna die.

A beautiful game. Its success in conveying the story's themes to you with minimal words is amazing. The struggle to reach the coveted Nuclear Throne leads you to empathize with the mutants and their small community.

10/10

This is my second account, after i loast the first, so i have alot of hours. Easily the most fun game ive played, and you can check my library. Its a classic rogue action game with tons of powerfull weapons, bosses, areas, and characters. There is a character for every playstyle.

-Price of 11 bucks.
-lots of content, fun to replay.

This game is terrible, my brother bought it for me It was the worst choice of his life. The game only supports keyboard and mouse, I don't own a mouse so I cant shoot. I keep starting a match from my touchscreen but It doesn't support that either.

The strongest arguments against this game are the hardcoded 30fps framerate and enter the gungeon.  It has the problems inherent to a game locked at 30fps, with additional problems due to gameplay design choices.

Moving around is jittery in 30fps@240p.  Everything is.  The pixel art is kind of muddy.  There are a lot of cheap deaths.  Base movespeed is probably too slow for how fast enemy projectiles are, and you should probably be able to see further around you.

For comparison, let's talk about what enter the gungeon does that nuclear throne doesn't.   EtG goes on sale frequently for $7.50.  There are many more guns and they're a lot more distinct from each other.  There's a massive amount of items.  There are more bosses and enemies, which are mostly designed well.  The gameplay is more fair and intuitive.  There's a more compelling progression arc with more content to it.  Graphically, it's clean.  It supports widescreen and will run at 1440p and 144hz if you have the monitor for it.  Sound design is a lot better.

I'm okay with playing Nuclear Throne for some variety, but I generally wouldn't recommend it to other people.
People go on and on about this, and disappointingly it's just more generic instadeath roguelite pixel art bullshit.  Don't bother.

appDetails.name: Nuclear Throne
appDetails.detailed_description: Nuclear Throne is a post-apocalyptic roguelike-like top-down shooter. Not 'the final hope of humanity' post-apocalyptic, but 'humanity is extinct and mutants and monsters now roam the world' post-apocalyptic. Fight your way through the wastelands with powerful weaponry, collecting radiation to mutate some new limbs and abilities. All these things and more you could do if only you were good at this game. Can you reach the Nuclear Throne?

appDetails.reviews:
“Strip away all the punkish ingenuity piled on Nuclear Throne and you're left with this: a skin-fidgeting, hair-tingling battle of textures. Hard meets sticky. Bang meets squelch.”
Eurogamer

“It’s an anarchic thrash of a roguelike where everything goes boom or splat—or, more frequently, boom and splat.”
PC Gamer

“It’s a rapid-fire, deliciously crunchy randomized romp starring a cavalcade of characters from Vlambeer’s past.”
Rock, Paper, Shotgun
